<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 class="heading secondary"><span class="sw-version">23-12</span> Spring Update Improvements 1</h2>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>This update addresses recently introduced features and provides bug fixes, refinements and further enhancements.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <!-- features -->
        <h3>User Interface Enhancements</h3>
        <div class="section">
            <h4>New: Preset Info - Properties</h4>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Preset Info - Properties">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/preset/boled-pre-info-properties.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <div class="section">
                    <p>Preset metadata now includes a <q>Properties</q> field which provides automatically generated hashtags, depending on specific parameters of the preset. Similar to custom hashtags <i>(usable in the Comment section)</i>, searching for presets by using hashtags can be much more convenient.</p>
                </div>
            </div>
            <p>Depending on the preset's <span data-keyword="Sound">Type</span>, a <code>#Single</code>/<code>#Split</code>/<code>#Layer</code> hashtag is provided. A <code>#Poly</code>/<code>#Mono</code> hashtag is provided, depending on the <q>Mono Enable</q> parameter.</p>
            <p>A <code>#Unison</code>/<code>#1-voice</code> hashtag is provided, depending on the <q>Unison Voices</q> parameter. A <code>#Scale</code>/<code>#12-TET</code> <i>(12-Tone-Equal-Temperament)</i> hashtag is provided, depending on whether <q>Offset</q> parameters are used in the Scale group.</p>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Preset Info - Properties">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/preset/web-ui-preset-search-options.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <div data-highlight="note">
                    <p>In order to be able to search for specific property hashtags, the <q>Properties</q> checkbox in the search options has to be enabled.</p>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div class="section">
            <h4>New: Preset Scale Indicator</h4>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Scale Indicator">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/preset/boled-pre-scale-ind.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <div class="section">
                    <p>According to the <code>#Scale</code> hashtag, an &#xE042; indicator is shown next to the preset <i>(similar to &#xE041; - <code>#Unison</code> and &#xE040; - <code>#Mono</code>)</i>.</p>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div class="section">
            <h4 data-detail="Panel Unit">Setup Menu - Fine Mode support</h4>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup - Fine Mode">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-fine.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <div class="section">
                    <p>Numeric settings <i>(Edit Smoothing Time, Tune Reference, Transition Time, Encoder Acceleration, Ribbon Relative Factor)</i> can now also be fine-tuned by using the <span data-keyword="Fine">Button</span>.</p>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div class="section">
            <h4>Setup Menu - Single Setting default</h4>
            <p>The <span data-keyword="Default">Button</span> is now usable for most settings in the <span data-keyword="Setup">Menu</span>. In the <span data-keyword="Graphical">UI</span>, settings represented as sliders can be set to default by double-clicking.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section style="page-break-before: always;">
        <h3>Bugfixes and Improvements</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>
                <header>Signal Flow Indication - Feedback</header>
                <p>When any parameter of <q>Envelope C</q> is currently selected, the <q>FB Mix</q> <span data-keyword="Parameter">LED</span> of a particular Shaper will only blink if the corresponding "FB - Gate - Env C" parameter is greater than zero <i>(as otherwise, there is no influence of the Envelope on the Shaper mix)</i>.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header>Preset Store - Overwrite</header>
                <p>When the currently selected Bank is empty, overwriting a Preset will now store the Preset within the Bank, instead of creating a new Bank.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header>Ribbon Touch Behavior</header>
                <p>When a <span data-keyword="Ribbon"></span> is selected in the <span data-keyword="Parameter">Screen</span>, <span data-keyword="Soft Button">4</span> will now show <code>Touch</code> instead of <code>Mode</code>.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header data-detail="Graphical UI">Single Sounds - Copy FX</header>
                <p>In the <span data-keyword="Sound">Tab</span>, options for copying the FX chain into the other are now available as well.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header data-detail="Graphical UI">Parameter Tab - defaultable Modulation Aspects</header>
                <p>When a Modulation Aspect (Amount, Upper/Lower Limit) of a modulateable parameter is in focus, a double click will now set the modulation amount to its default value <i>(instead of defaulting the control position)</i>.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header data-detail="Panel Unit">FX Parameter Groups</header>
                <p>Similar to the <span data-keyword="Graphical">UI</span>, the group labels now have an indicator corresponding to the selected Part.</p>
            </li>
            <!-- potential bugfixes/improvements -->
            <li>
                <header>Numerical Settings - Precision and Ranges</header>
                <p>The <span data-keyword="Tune">Reference</span>, the <span data-keyword="Edit Smoothing">Time</span> and the <span data-keyword="Transition">Time</span> now show their values with consistent precision between both UIs. Both times can now be set to 0.0 ms.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header>Bidirectional Ribbons - MIDI issues</header>
                <p>When a non-returning <span data-keyword="Ribbon"></span> is bidirectionally associated to a <span data-keyword="Macro">Control</span>, MIDI will now only be sent if the Ribbon was changed directly <i>(by using the Touchstrip or changing the corresponding slider)</i>. If the Macro was changed directly or by a <span data-keyword="Pedal"></span>, the slider of the Ribbon will change as well, but no MIDI will be sent.</p>
                <p>With Local enabled and using MIDI Loopback <i>(having the C15 connected to a DAW for example, receiving and sending MIDI at the same time)</i>, using Ribbons will now cause less traffic and no more glitchy behavior <i>(see below)</i>.</p>
            </li>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="warn">
            <p>MIDI Loopback is only recommended when having Local disabled for Notes and <span data-keyword="Hardware">Sources</span>. When having Local enabled, MIDI Loopback will lead to a Note being played twice <i>(internally and in addition from MIDI In)</i>.</p>
        </div>
        <h4>Further Improvements</h4>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <ul>
                <li>after booting, LEDs of a <span data-keyword="Ribbon">Touchstrip</span> will correspond to the associated <span data-keyword="Macro">Control</span>, if the linking is bidirectional</li>
                <li>in the <span data-keyword="Sound">Screen</span>/<span data-keyword="">Tab</span>, the indication of feedback signal flow by displaying arrows is now more consistent</li>
                <li>the <span data-keyword="Preset">Search</span> window in the <span data-keyword="Graphical">UI</span> will refresh after restoring a backup</li>
                <li>in a <span data-keyword="Dual">Sound</span>, unused <span data-keyword="Parts"></span> (having no influence on the sound) will be indicated as a cross in the sound symbol, similar to muted Parts or unused FX in <span data-keyword="Single">Sounds</span></li>
            </ul>
            <ul>
                <li>when updating the C15 via the <span data-keyword="USB">Stick</span>, the update will now be installed once <i>(instead of starting the update again after successful installation)</i>.</li>
                <li>when a returning <span data-keyword="Hardware">Source</span> was changed on the <span data-keyword="Panel">Unit</span>, the control will automatically and now more consistently reset to zero when loosing focus (for example storing a Preset or invoking the Setup Menu will reset the source)</li>
                <!-- potential bugfixes/improvements -->
                <li>in the <span data-keyword="Parameter">Tab</span>, the <span data-keyword="Fine">Indicator</span> is now better integrated with the <span data-keyword="Shift">Key</span></li>
            </ul>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/change-log/index.html">Change Log</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/change-log/23-17.html">Spring Update Improvements 2</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 class="heading secondary"><span class="sw-version">23-17</span> Spring Update Improvements 2</h2>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>This update further refines newly introduced features and provides additional bug fixes and enhancements.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <!-- features -->
        <h3>Enhancements</h3>
        <div class="section">
            <h4>New: MIDI - Active Sensing</h4>
            <p>Some USB-to-MIDI adapters can flexibly change their MIDI ports and switch from <q>Send</q> to <q>Receive</q> automatically, when no MIDI has been sent for a while. Currently, ESI <i>(MIDIMATE)</i> and Swissonic <i>(MidiConnect2)</i> products are known to do this. The switching results in glitchy behavior, but can be avoided by repeatedly sending <q>Active Sensing</q> messages <i>(which should otherwise have no effect)</i>.</p>
            <p>Therefore, a new option has been added to the <span data-keyword="MIDI">Assignments</span> section. If enabled, active sensing messages will be permanently emitted, preventing the connected MIDI device from switching its ports. As this causes more traffic <i>(which may not be wanted)</i>, the option can be disabled.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <!-- bugfixes, improvements -->
        <h3>Bugfixes and Improvements</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>
                <header data-detail="Graphical UI">Preset Search - Hashtags</header>
                <p>The search algorithim has been improved and now distinguishes ordinary search terms from hashtags <i>(hashtags can now only be found when a search term starts with the <code>#</code> symbol)</i>. With this distinction, the <q>Properties</q> search option seemed redundant and has been removed.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header data-detail="Graphical UI">Presets - cut and paste</header>
                <p>After pasting a cut preset, the original preset will now be removed, as it should be.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header data-detail="Panel Unit">Unison - parameter selection</header>
                <p>In <span data-keyword="Layer">Sounds</span> with <span data-keyword="Part">&#xE082;</span> in focus, parameters of the <span data-keyword="Unison">Group</span> now show correct values when traversing the parameter stack with <span data-keyword="Soft Button">4</span>.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <!-- potential -->
                <header>MIDI - Local On/Off after booting</header>
                <p>After booting the C15 and then immediately changing the <q>Local Enable</q> option <i>(or specific Local options in the <q>Routings</q> section)</i>, <span data-keyword="Hardware">Sources</span> wrongfully changed their values. This has been fixed and the values now remain in sync.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header>Documentation - mobile layout</header>
                <p>On mobile devices, the appearance of the <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a> was compromised when viewing in portrait mode. The additional menu bar of the mobile browser overshadowed the internal navigation and menu, effectively disabling navigation alltogether. This has been fixed and the navigation and menu should now be permanently visible in portrait mode <i>(except for iPhones, in which case we recommend to fall back to viewing in landscape mode)</i>.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header>Base Unit - booting in Play Mode</header>
                <p>When booting the C15, the <span data-keyword="Base">Unit</span> will now always start in <span data-keyword="Play">Mode</span>, discarding the last active mode before shutdown. This ensures, that <span data-keyword="Note">Shift</span> is always visible after booting and can be modified directly.</p>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 class="heading secondary"><span class="sw-version">23-26</span> Spring Update Improvements 3</h2>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>This update provides a few additional bug fixes.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <!-- bugfixes, improvements -->
        <h3>Bugfixes and Improvements</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>
                <header>Backups - new file format</header>
                <p>The file format of backup files has been reworked in order to prevent download issues <i>(as some browsers will automatically unpack downloaded archives)</i>. So, instead of <code>.xml.tar.gz</code>, downloaded backups will now be provided in a custom <code>.nlbackup</code> format. <i>(The former tarball format is still supported when restoring backups, so existing backup files are still restorable without a file conversion.)</i></p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header data-detail="Graphical UI">Layer Sound - Fade Indicators</header>
                <p>In the <span data-keyword="Sound">Tab</span> of a <span data-keyword="Layer">Sound</span>, the Fade indicators incorrectly reacted on mouse clicks, which has been removed.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header>Flanger - Envelope</header>
                <p>In <span data-keyword="Single">Sounds</span>, the envelope of the Flanger had inconsistent behavior: only when no keys are priorly pressed, the next pressed key should always start the envelope. The mechanism now reworks reliably for both FX groups. In <span data-keyword="Split">Sounds</span>, pressed keys are counted for each <span data-keyword="Part"></span> individually.</p>
            </li>
            <li>
                <header data-detail="Graphical UI">Midi Settings - change detection</header>
                <p>In order to avoid hanging notes, changing Midi settings <i>(like Send or Receive channels)</i> require that the system resets all notes internally and also propagates the reset externally when Midi send is used.</p>
                <p>However, this only worked internally and hanging Midi notes were still possible. With this fix, changing Midi settings will lead to an internal and external reset as soon as any <i>(internal or external)</i> note is active.</p>
            </li>
            <li style="page-break-before: always;">
                <header>Documentation - broken links</header>
                <p>Sub chapters within chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a> of the User Manual had broken navigation links, which has been fixed.</p>
            </li>
        </ul>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<main>
    <section>
        <h2 class="heading secondary"><span class="sw-version">23-36</span> Service Update - Setting Improvements</h2>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>This Update provides a few reworked System Settings in order to streamline device configuration and test procedures of the C15. Besides speeding up the initial <q>Factory</q> configuration, this may also turn out to be helpful when checking the synth on-stage.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>Enhancements</h3>
        <div class="section">
            <h4 data-detail="Panel Unit, Graphical UI">Device Settings</h4>
            <ul>
                <li>
                    <header><b>New: Load Factory Defaults</b></header>
                    <p>Formerly only a Developer Option, this action is now also available as a proper Setting. When invoked, this action has to be confirmed, before all Settings will be reset to their Factory Default values.</p>
                </li>
                <li>
                    <header><b>New: Test Tone</b></header>
                    <div class="section">
                        <p>Formerly only an internal feature, the Test Tone has been reworked and is now introduced as a new Setting. A pure sine tone with a frequency corresponding to the <b>Tune Reference</b> Setting and an amplitude of -6 dB<sub>FS</sub> can be added to the stereo signal of the synth. There are four modes for this setting:</p>
                        <table>
                            <tr>
                                <th>Off</th>
                                <td>Only the stereo signal of the synth is audible.</td>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <th>Left</th>
                                <td>The Test Tone will be added only to the left channel of the stereo signal.</td>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <th>Right</th>
                                <td>The Test Tone will be added only to the right channel of the stereo signal.</td>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <th>Both</th>
                                <td>The Test Tone will be added to both channels of the stereo signal.</td>
                            </tr>
                        </table>
                    </div>
                </li>
            </ul>
        </div>
        <div class="section" style="page-break-before: always;">
            <h4 data-detail="Panel Unit, Graphical UI">System Info</h4>
            <ul>
                <li>
                    <header><b>Date/Time</b></header>
                    <p>In the <span data-keyword="Graphical UI"></span>, the Setting can now be adjusted as well.</p>
                </li>
            </ul>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>Bugfixes and Improvements</h3>
        <div class="section">
            <h4>MIDI Settings</h4>
            <ul>
                <li>
                    <header><b>Send Active Sensing</b></header>
                    <p>The Factory Default value for this Setting has been changed to <code>Off</code>, as this only applies for very specific MIDI devices.</p>
                </li>
            </ul>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<main>
    <section>
        <h2>C15 Synth Engine (detailed)</h2>
        <dl class="tabs h decorated">
            <dt>
                <label tab="highlight-none" onclick="selectTab(event)" selected>no<br/>highlighting</label>
                <label tab="highlight-fm" onclick="selectTab(event)">FM<br/>Synthesis</label>
                <label tab="highlight-sub" onclick="selectTab(event)">Subtractive<br/>Synth</label>
                <label tab="highlight-exres" onclick="selectTab(event)">Exciter +<br/>Resonator</label>
                <label tab="highlight-fbk" onclick="selectTab(event)">Feedback</label>
            </dt>
            <dd>
                <div tab="highlight-none" selected>
                    <figure  class="border maximize" data-label="Synth Engine (detailed)">
                        <picture class="content">
                            <svg class="image-container" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 316 146" >
                                <foreignObject width="316" height="146">
                                    <picture data-src="images/diagrams/se-illustrations/block-detail-*.svg"></picture>
                                </foreignObject>
                            </svg>
                        </picture>
                    </figure>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-midi-bridge/01-general">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/index.html">MIDI Bridge Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/01-general.html" data-number="1">General</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="1">General</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="1.1">Usage and Operation</h3>
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Usage</h3>
        <p>The MIDI Bridge is intended to connect two MIDI systems together when both systems are USB Hosts. A typical example is a Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) running on a PC and a NonlinearLabs C15 Synthesizer.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="MIDI Bridge connection">
            <picture class="content" data-src="images/package/c15-bridge-laptop.jpg"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>As the C15 only offers a USB host-type socket (USB Type A) it cannot be connected to the PC directly, therefore a data bridge is needed which has USB device-type sockets on both ends (USB Type B) so that the device can be connected to both hosts.</p>
        <p>The applications on both hosts then can communicate with each other in any direction through a USB MIDI Device which appears as <q>NLL-MIDI-Bridge</q>. The bridge does not change orinterpret the data in any way and is fully transparent.</p>
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Operation</h3>
        <p>he device waits for a MIDI data packet to be received on <i>one port</i> and when this happens, the packet is send out on the <i>other port</i>.</p>
        <p>This happens for both directions independently and simultaneously.</p>
        <p>The transfer process can be monitored with the two LED indicator lights on the top, one for each port, showing incoming data and its delivery status.</p>
        <p>The bottom plate of the MIDI Bridge is internally equipped with magnets so that you can attach the device to magnetically responsive surfaces, notably the steel chassis of a  NonlinearLabs C15 Synthesizer.</p>
        <div data-highlight="warn">
            <p>Those magnets have considerable strengths so keep the Bridge away (<i>&gt; 0.5m</i>) from mechanical watches, cathode ray displays/monitors, credit cards etc with magnet strips, audio or video magnetic tapes and recorders/players, and especially from body-implanted medical devices like pacemakers.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="1.2">Packet Latency</h3>
        <p>The typical transfer time for the usual short MIDI packet is about <i>100μs</i> (μs is <q>micro-seconds</q>;one-millionth of a second) of in either direction, assuming very little other traffic loads on the two USB busses.</p>
        <p>When a packet could be sent within less than <i>300μs</i>, the transfer is considered REALTIME.</p>
        <p>When a packet could be sent within <i>300μs</i> and <i>2ms</i>, the transfer is considered LATE.</p>
        <p>When a packet could be sent only after more than <i>2ms</i>, the transfer is considered STALE.</p>
        <p>All these considerations are for information, they do not represent error conditions.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="1.3">Dropped Packet Errors</h3>
        <p>When a packet cannot be sent out in due time, the transfer is considered DROPPED and will be aborted. This is an error condition and may happen either when the outgoing port is not connected/ready or the host computer is currently not reading data within due time, stalling the transfer.</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Windows will always accept MIDI data over USB and will never stall whereas on Linux and MacOs a running application that <i>actually reads</i> MIDI data is required to avoid the stalling condition</p>
        </div>
        <p>When the outgoing port is not ready (not connected or not detected by the USB-host) the packet is dropped immediately.</p>
        <p>When the port is ready and a first stalling condition occurs, a timeout of <i>100ms</i> is used and the packet is dropped. For subsequent stalling packets, the timeout is reduced to <i>5ms</i>. It then takes one successful packet delivery to reset the timeout to <i>100ms</i> again.</p>
        <div data-highlight="comment">
            <h5>Technical detail</h5>
            <p>Until a transfer has finished (or was aborted), receiving of further packets is blocked temporarily. There is no internal buffering, rather the transfers are in real-time, one at a time.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-midi-bridge/02-indicators">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/index.html">MIDI Bridge Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/02-indicators.html" data-number="2">Indicators</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="2">Indicators</h2>
        <p>Each port side has a RGB (true color) LED indicator which shows both the <i>port status</i> and the <i>packet status</i> while a packet is running through. Each port LED is referring to the incoming data on that port.</p>
        <p>The LED color basically indicates the port status, which is the largest latency range measured in recent packet delivery (ranging some seconds back).</p>
        <p>The LED is temporarily flashing brighter when an actual packet is running through the device and the color indicates the current latency.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="2.1">Continuous Port Status Display (dim colors)</h3>
        <p>The dim color of the LED represents the current status of the port:</p>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <p>Pulsing blue</p>
                    <p>(slowly blinking, <i>3s</i> period)</p>
                </th>
                <th style="max-width: 8.5em;">
                    <span class="led blue"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led blue"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led blue"></span>
                </th>
                <td>port is not connected.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <p>Pulsing cyan</p>
                    <p>(slowly blinking, <i>3s</i> period)</p>
                </th>
                <th>
                    <span class="led cyan"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led cyan"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led cyan"></span>
                </th>
                <td>port is connected and receives USB power, but no USB communication is present.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Green</th>
                <th>
                    <span class="led green"></span>
                </th>
                <td>port is connected and USB communication is ready to go.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Yellow</th>
                <th>
                    <span class="led yellow"></span>
                </th>
                <td>port is connected and USB communication is ready to go, but there were LATE packets within the last <i>two</i> seconds.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Red</th>
                <th><span class="led red"></span></th>
                <td>port is connected and USB communication is ready to go, but there were STALE packets within the last <i>four</i> seconds</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Magenta</th>
                <th><span class="led magenta"></span></th>
                <td>port is connected and USB communication is ready to go, but there were DROPPED packets (with data loss) within the last <i>six</i> seconds.</td>
            </tr>
        </table>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="2.2">Flashing Packet Status Display (bright colors)</h3>
        <p>On top of the steady-state port status display above, the MIDI Bridge independently indicates the status of the current packet while it runs through the device. This again is color-coded but can be distinguished from the port status in that the LEDs go full brightness.</p>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th>Green</th>
                <th>
                    <span class="led green"></span>
                </th>
                <td>packet is running for less than <i>300μs</i> (REALTIME).</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Yellow</th>
                <th>
                    <span class="led yellow"></span>
                </th>
                <td>packet is running for less than <i>2ms</i> (LATE).</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Red</th>
                <th>
                    <span class="led red"></span>
                </th>
                <td>packet is running for more than <i>2ms</i> (STALE).</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Magenta</th>
                <th>
                    <span class="led magenta"></span>
                </th>
                <td>packet had to be dropped (data loss).</td>
            </tr>
        </table>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Because the actual transfer times are normally very short (&lt; <i>100μs</i>) they are lengthened for display. Still the short true transfer time is directly indicated with even brighter colors, and notably the normal green color gets brighter and more cyan’ish when very dense traffic is present. In normal MIDI operation the traffic is very sparse, though.</p>
        </div>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>As long as you see any LED indicator activity (steady-state on or blinking) the device is powered up and consumes electrical current. Therefore, to save power, you may want to unplug the device from computers while those are in standby, hybernate or power-down modes but still apply supply voltage to their USB sockets.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-midi-bridge/03-special-error-codes">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/index.html">MIDI Bridge Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/03-special-error-codes.html" data-number="3">Special Error/Blink Codes</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3">Special Error/Blink Codes</h2>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>In normal operation, including a firmware update via MIDI SysEx message, none of the below errors will ever occur (except for <q>Programming Finished</q>)... but things might go wrong on very very seldom occasions.</p>
        </div>
        <p>These are unrecoverable but mostly non-persistent errors in general, the device is temporarily not operational after an incident. The device must be fully unplugged to reset and return to normal operation.</p>
        <p>The LED indicator patterns are meant for post-mortem diagnosis, so please write down the colors and blink states should you ever run into such an error. The blink rate is very fast.</p>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th colspan="2">First LED</th>
                <th colspan="2">Second LED</th>
                <th>Meaning</th>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>GREEN blinking</td>
                <td style="max-width: 8.5em;">
                    <span class="leed green-b"></span>
                    <!-- <span class="led green"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led green"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led green"></span> -->
                </td>
                <td>GREEN blinking</td>
                <td style="max-width: 8.5em;">
                    <span class="leed green-b"></span>
                    <!-- <span class="led green"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led green"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led green"></span> -->
                </td>
                <td>Programming Finished Successfully (NO ERROR)</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>WHITE</td>
                <td>
                    <span class="led white"></span>
                </td>
                <td>WHITE (blinking or not)</td>
                <td>
                    <span class="leed white-b"></span>
                    <!-- <span class="led white"></span> -->
                </td>
                <td>Severe Code Error (Lock-Up) <sup>*)</sup></td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>RED</td>
                <td>
                    <span class="led red"></span>
                </td>
                <td>RED blinking</td>
                <td>
                    <span class="leed red-b"></span>
                    <!-- <span class="led red"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led red"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led red"></span> -->
                </td>
                <td>USB Packet incorrect size</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>RED</td>
                <td>
                    <span class="led red"></span>
                </td>
                <td>YELLOW blinking</td>
                <td>
                    <span class="leed yellow-b"></span>
                    <!-- <span class="led yellow"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led yellow"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led yellow"></span> -->
                </td>
                <td>Unexpected USB Packet</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>YELLOW</td>
                <td>
                    <span class="led yellow"></span>
                </td>
                <td>RED blinking</td>

                    <span class="leed red-b"></span>
                    <!-- <span class="led red"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led red"></span>
                    <span class="led off"></span>
                    <span class="led red"></span> -->
                </td>
                <td>SysEx Data Error</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>YELLOW</td>
                <td>
                    <span class="led yellow"></span>
                </td>
                <td>YELLOW</td>
                <td>

                </td>
                <td>Waiting for SysEx End Marker</td>
            </tr>

                </td>

            </tr>
        </table>
        <p><b>*)</b> Software Bugs as well as Broken Code (for example from an update gone wrong) will often, but not always, end up with the WHITE-WHITE <q>code error</q> pattern.</p>
        <p><b>**)</b> Should one of these severe failures ever happen during a firmware update, it is very likely that the device is now <q>bricked</q>, containing a partial or broken code update and thus rendered inoperable and refusing to take further updates. It then should be returned to factory for servicing.</p>
    </section>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-midi-bridge/04-firmware-version">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/index.html">MIDI Bridge Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/04-firmware-version.html" data-number="4">Firmware Version Identification (Blink Pattern after Power Up)</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="4">Firmware Version Identification (Blink Pattern after Power Up)</h2>
        <p>To identify the current firmware version in the device, a specific blink pattern is displayed after power has been applied via one of the USB ports:</p>
        <p>The first LED blinking YELLOW <span class="led yellow"></span> <span class="led off"></span> for N times, like, say, two times:<br/>Major Revision Number is N = 2</p>
        <p>Then, second LED blinking CYAN <span class="led cyan"></span> <span class="led off"></span> for K times, say, three times:<br/>Minor Revision Number is K = 3</p>
        <p>Effective firmware Version is N.K, with K displayed with two digits. For the example:<br/>Version = 2.03</p>
        <p>There might be additional blink patterns following after the firmware version, like both LEDs blinking RED <span class="led red"></span><span class="led off"></span> three times which indicates the used firmware is a special beta/test version.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-midi-bridge/05-firmware-update">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/index.html">MIDI Bridge Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/05-firmware-update.html" data-number="5">Firmware Update</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5">Firmware Update</h2>
        <div data-highlight="warn">
            <h4>Important note</h4>
            <p>The MIDI Bridge only accepts a firmware update when *no* MIDI traffic has occurred since power-up, otherwise it will simply try to deliver the MIDI data on the other port as in normal operation.</p>
        </div>
        <ul style="list-style: none;">
            <li data-number="1">Fully disconnect the MIDI Bridge.</li>
            <li data-number="2">Connect MIDI Bridge to PC only (which port used on the MIDI Bridge does not matter).</li>
            <li data-number="3a">
                <span>For Linux Users, using <code><b>amidi</b></code> (<a href="https://www.systutorials.com/docs/linux/man/1-amidi/" target="_blank" class="label">www.systutorials.com/docs/linux/man/1-amidi/</a>):</span>
                <ul>
                    <li>find hardware port ID with <code><b>amidi -l</b></code>, say it was <code><b>hw:1,0,0</b></code> for example</li>
                    <li> send SysEx with <code><b>amidi -p hw:1,0,0 -s nlmb-fw-update-VX.YZ.syx</b></code><br/><i>(X.YZ must be replaced with the actual firmware number)</i></li>
                </ul>
            </li>
            <li data-number="3b">
                <span>For Windows/Mac users:</span>
                <ul>
                    <li> use an application like <q>MIDI Tools</q> (<a href="https://mountainutilities.eu/miditools" target="_blank" class="label">mountainutilities.eu/miditools</a>)</li>
                    <li>load the Firmware SysEx file</li>
                    <li>send it to MIDI Bridge</li>
                </ul>
            </li>
        </ul>
        <p>If the firmware update was successful, the MIDI Bridge will show that by both LEDs blinking fast in bright GREEN color <span class="led green"></span><span class="led off"></span><span class="led green"></span><span class="led off"></span><span class="led green"></span><span class="led off"></span> and then will reset itself after 5 seconds, afterwards showing the new Firmware Version during startup.</p>
        <p>If the update failed, try again the full cycle from step 1 (<i>note: try using also the other port of the MIDI bridge</i>).</p>
        <ul style="list-style: none;">
            <li data-number="4">
                <span>Optional Firmware Version Check (besides the visual Firmware Version Display):</span>
                <ul>
                    <li>Software like <q>MIDI Tools</q> must be restarted and then will show the new firmware version of a connected Bridge in the setup screen.</li>
                    <li>on Linux, use the command <code><b>usb-devices | grep -C 6 -i nonlinear</b></code></li>
                </ul>
            </li>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <h4>Windows hint</h4>
            <p>To remove stale entries potentially causing wrong display of the device name, go to device manager, select <q>show hidden devices</q>, then delete all <q>NLL-Bridge</q> entries. Do this while the MIDI Bridge is *not* plugged in, of course.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/index.html">MIDI Bridge Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/06-hardware-port.html" data-number="6">Hardware Port Speed Identification</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="6">Hardware Port Speed Identification</h2>
        <p>Technically, both ports of the Bridge are USB2.0 compatible but only one port offers the maximum speed of <i>480Mpbs</i> (<q>High-Speed</q>), the other runs at <i>12Mbps</i> (<q>Full-Speed</q>). Both speeds are way beyond the data rates that will normally ever be used or needed by MIDI, though. Only when an USB bus is almost saturated by other than MIDI traffic there could be cases where one wants to connect the High-Speed port of the Bridge to a specific bus.</p>
        <p>The High-Speed port side of the Bridge can by identified during the LED pattern display of Firmware Version, it is located at the side where the first blink pulse is seen, in yellow (see chapter <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/04-firmware-version.html" class="label" data-number="4">Firmware Version Identification</a>).</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-pedals/01-features">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/index.html">Pedal Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/01-features.html" data-number="1">Features</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="1">Features</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <ul>
            <li>Support for almost all types of expression pedals and damper pedals of different technology and connector pin-outs. Further, many model-specific pedal presets can be selected for optimized performance.</li>
            <li>Support for “Control Voltage” as additional type of controller.</li>
            <li>Auto-Ranging to fully use the available electrical travel of a pedal.</li>
            <li>Auto-Hold to de-noise and stabilize the controller output.</li>
            <li>Controller parameters (like current Auto-Ranging internal settings) are continuously saved, and re-loaded after power-up.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-pedals/02-quick-start">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/index.html">Pedal Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/02-quick-start.html" data-number="2">Quick Start</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="2">Quick Start</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <ol>
            <li>If the pedal has a detachable cable, then first connect a suitable cable to the pedal. If the pedal has a <q>minimum volume</q> setting adjust (like many Roland and Boss models do), set it to the fully counter-clockwise position.</li>
            <li>Connect the pedal cable to the C15 at one of the TRS Sockets numbered <q>Pedal 1...4</q>. The C15 may already be powered on or off, it does not matter. If on, try to insert the cable quickly into the TRS socket (in less than 1 second).</li>
            <li>Go to <q>Setup > Device Settings > Pedals</q> and select the proper type for the pedal from the pedal presets list. If your pedal is listed explicitly then please use that setting. Otherwise, try the generic <q>Pot, Tip-Active</q> (also known as Boss/Roland pin-out) or <q>Pot, Ring-Active</q> (Yamaha pin-out) presets.</li>
            <li>Do the Auto-Ranging cycle: Move the pedal to one end stop of its mechanical travel, wait a moment (1 second), then move it to the other end stop, wait a moment.</li>
            <li>Check if the position indicator in the Pedal Editor screen moves evenly and over the whole range of 0%...100% when operating the pedal over the complete travel. When using one of the generic <q>Pot</q> settings and you find that the approximate <q>center</q> position gives a way too high (or too low) reading, try the corresponding generic pedal presets with the swapped pin-out (swap <q>tip active</q> with <q>ring active</q>).</li>
            <li>During operation, when you find that the pedal does not move over the complete 0%...100% range anymore, reset the Auto-Ranging by temporarily selecting another pedal type. Alternatively, you can pull the cable from the TRS socket and re-plug it.</li>
        </ol>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/index.html">Pedal Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/03-pedal-presets.html" data-number="3">List of Pedal Presets</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3">List of Pedal Presets</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th>Name/Type</th>
                <th>Remarks</th>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>Pot, Tip-Active</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>Generic 3-Wire Expression/Damper Pedal, Tip-Active (<q>Roland</q> pin-out). If there is a <q>min</q> control, set it fully counter-clockwise.<br />
                    If there is a <q>range</q> control, set it fully clockwise.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 5%, 5%. Auto-Hold strength: medium.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>Pot, Ring-Active</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>Generic 3-Wire Expression/Damper Pedal, Ring-Active (<q>Yamaha</q> pin-out). If there is a <q>min</q> control, set it fully counter-clockwise.<br />
                    If there is a <q>range</q> control, set it fully clockwise.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 5%, 5%. Auto-Hold strength: medium.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>Pot, Tip-Act. Rev.</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>Generic 3-Wire Expression/Damper Pedal, Tip-Active (<q>Roland</q> pin-out). Reversed output vs. pedal travel.<br />
                    If there is a <q>min</q> control, set it fully counter-clockwise.<br />
                    If there is a <q>range</q> control, set it fully clockwise.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 5%, 5%. Auto-Hold strength: medium.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>Pot, Ring-Act. Rev.</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>Generic 3-Wire Expression/Damper Pedal, Ring-Active (<q>Yamaha</q> pin-out). Reversed output vs. pedal travel.<br />
                    If there is a <q>min</q> control, set it fully counter-clockwise.<br />
                    If there is a <q>range</q> control, set it fully clockwise.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 5%, 5%. Auto-Hold strength: medium.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>Resistor</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>Generic 2-Wire Adjustable Resistor, Tip-Active.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 5%, 5%. Auto-Hold strength: medium.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>Resistor, Rev.</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>Generic 2-Wire Adjustable Resistor, Tip-Active.<br />
                    Reversed output vs. pedal travel.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 5%, 5%. Auto-Hold strength: medium.</td>
            </tr>
        
            <tr>
                <td><em>Switch, Closing</em><br />Bi-Stable</td>
                <td>Generic 2-Wire Switch, Tip-Active.<br />
                    <q>100%</q> Output in closed position.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 1%, 1%. Auto-Hold strength: weak.<br />
                    You can use most tip-active expression and damper pedals as switches, too.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>Switch, Opening</em><br />Bi-Stable</td>
                <td>Generic 2-Wire Switch, Tip-Active.<br />
                    <q>100%</q> Output in closed position.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 1%, 1%. Auto-Hold strength: weak.<br />
                    You can use most tip-active expression and damper pedals as switches, too.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>CV, 0...5V</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>Control Voltage, Tip-Active, Fixed Range: 0...5V. Auto-Ranging: off, Auto-Hold strength: weak.<br />
                    Do not apply voltages outside a 0...5V range. Do not apply ANY voltage when the unit is off.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>CV, 0...5V<br />(Auto-Range)</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>Control Voltage, Tip-Active, Auto-Ranging within 0...5V. Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 1%, 1%. Auto-Hold strength: weak. Do not apply voltages outside a 0...5V range.<br />
                    Do not apply ANY voltage when the unit is off.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>— OFF —</em></td>
                <td>Use this to fully ignore a pedal even when connected.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>E:Boss EV-30</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>3-Wire Expression Pedal, Tip-Active.<br />
                    Set <q>min</q> controls to fully counter-clockwise.<br />
                    For direct reverse action, use output <q>EXP2</q> set to <q>INV</q>. Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 1%, 2%. Auto-Hold strength: medium.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>E:Boss FV-500L</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>3-Wire Expression Pedal, Tip-Active.<br />
                    Set <q>min</q> control to fully counter-clockwise.<br />
                    Use <q>EXP</q> output.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 1%, 1%. Auto-Hold strength: strong.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>E:Doepfer FP5</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>3-Wire Expression Pedal, Ring-Active.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 1%, 4%. Auto-Hold strength: medium.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>E:Fractal EV-2</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>3-Wire Expression Pedal, Tip-Active.<br />
                    Use <q>EXP</q> output.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 1%, 1%. Auto-Hold strength: weak.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>D:Korg DS-1H</em><br />Continuous</td>

            </tr>

            </tr>

            </tr>
            <tr>

                    Set <q>min</q> control to fully counter-clockwise.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 1%, 2%. Auto-Hold strength: weak.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>D:Yamaha FC3A</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>3-Wire Damper Pedal, Ring-Active, Reverse Action.<br />Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 4%, 1%. Auto-Hold strength: weak.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td><em>E:Yamaha FC7</em><br />Continuous</td>
                <td>3-Wire Expression Pedal, Ring-Active.<br />
                    Auto-Ranging dead-zones: 1%, 2%. Auto-Hold strength: strong.</td>
            </tr>
        </table>
    </section>
</main>

    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="4">Connection</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>Some expression and damper pedals have detachable cables. Typically, a 3-wire TRS cable should be used with TRS plugs on both ends.</p>
        <p>But there are certain battery- or mains-powered switching pedals that use the ring contact of their TRS jack to close an electric circuit to power up the pedal, for those only use a 2-wire cable with TS-plugs on both ends and the cable must first be connected to the switch before plugging into the C15, otherwise the function might not work properly and the input might even be damaged.</p>
        <p>In general, always connect the cable to the pedal first before plugging it into the C15.</p>
        <p>When connecting a Control Voltage source provided by, for example, a CV output from an analog synth, it is recommended to follow these steps:</p>
        <ul>
            <li>Check that the CV output does produce <em>output voltages only within the 0V...+5V range</em>, eg. do NOT connect to sources that range from -5V to +5V or 0V to +10V etc.</li>
            <li>Switch off both the source and the C15 before making the cable connection. CV input is recognized only on the tip of a TRS or TS plug, with the sleeve being the <q>ground reference</q>. The ring contact is not used.</li>
            <li>Switch on the C15 first, then the CV source. For switch-off, reverse that order, that is, switch off the source first, then the C15.</li>
            <li>You may need to do a <q>pedal reset</q> and restart Auto-Ranging for the <q>CV, 0..5V(Au- to-Range)</q> pedal presets after the C15 is fully up and running by selecting a different pedal preset temporarily.</li>
        </ul>   
        <p>It is important that the cable, no matter what type of source, is plugged in quickly into a running C15 (in less than one second). Otherwise, the Auto-Ranging function may not work properly because of wrong initial values being detected.</p>
        <p>For the same reason, sources with detachable cables must first be connected to the cable before plugging the cable into a running C15.</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>When a pedal or other source is unplugged during operation of the C15, the last readouts sent to a connected Macro Control may have arbitrary values not related to the actual pedal setting.</p>
            <p>Do NOT connect anything else to the C15 than passive expression and damper pedals, passive mechanical switches, and, with some care, control voltage sources and powered switch pedals, otherwise damage may occur.<br />
            <em>Please consult Nonlinear Labs (info@nonlinear-labs.de) if there are any questions.</em></p>
        </div>
        <p>Also make sure that you never mistakenly connect any audio TRS cables for the audio signal chain (mixer, amp) to the pedal jacks as that may produce very loud and dangerous <q>thump</q>-sounds from the speakers or the main PA.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5">Setup</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>The setup for the pedals, switches and CV sources is simple. Navigate to the Pedal Settings either using the Panel Unit or the Graphical User Interface and select the proper type from the list of presets. There are several groups of presets:</p>
        <ul>
            <li>generic presets for expression and damper pedals</li>
            <li>generic presets for switches</li>
            <li>generic presets for control voltage sources</li>
            <li>specific presets for a variety of commonly used expression and damper pedals, listed</li>
            <li>alphabetically by make and model. Expression pedals start with the prefix <q>E:</q>, whereas damper pedals start with <q>D:</q>. Please try to find your expression or damper pedal in this list first. Use one of the generic presets only when the pedal is not listed. In most cases either <q>Pot, Tip-Active</q> or <q>Pot, Ring-Active</q> then will work, but you might try other compatible presets as well (compatible in that they have the same general type and connector pin-out).</li>
            <li>an <q>OFF</q> pedal preset, intended to fully deactivate a pedal without having the need to unplug it.</li>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>If you are using a pedal preset not matching the general type of your actual pedal or ࠌ source, unexpected results with regard to produced output values may occur. Neither the C15 nor the pedal/source, though, are any likely to be damaged when selecting a wrong pedal preset (but please read the warnings with regard to control voltage sours and battery- or mains-powered switches, at any rate).</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/index.html">Pedal Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/06-usage.html" data-number="6">Usage</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="6">Usage</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="6.1">Auto-Ranging of the pedal travel</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>After a pedal has been plugged in while the C15 is running, or after selecting a different pedal preset, most pedal presets require an Auto-Ranging cycle where the available electrical travel produced by the pedal is measured and used for the corner points. Note that until a reasonable range of movement has been detected the pedal will not produce any output signals. The procedure is simple:</p>
        <ul>
            <li>move the pedal to one mechanical end stop, then wait about one second.</li>
            <li>move the pedal to the other mechanical end stop and again wait a second.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="6.2">Checking the Auto-Ranging and general pedal characteristic</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>After the Auto-Ranging procedure, you might want to check if all is well, that is a) the pedal output spans the whole 0%...100% range and b) that the output characteristic is reasonable, producing about 50% output when the pedal is at around the mechanical middle position. Both checks can be done by watching the pedal’s position bar graph and the corresponding numerical display in the Pedal Editor.</p>
        <p>Should you find that the output value at the approximate mechanical center position is way off from the 50% mark, something like 80...90% <em>*</em> or so, then the pedal likely requires a different setup with tip and ring connections swapped. That is, if you see this behavior and have currently selected <q>Pot, Tip-Active</q>, then select <q>Pot, Ring-Active</q>, and vice versa. On the other hand, a unique feature of the C15 is that a pedal generally keeps working even when selecting the wrong pin-out, you just get a somewhat skewed characteristic of output values vs. mechanical travel.</p>
        <p><small>* When you are using the reverse readout presets like <q>Pot, Tip-Active, Rev.</q>, <q>Pot, Ring-Active, Rev.</q> etc, you will instead get a 10...20% reading for the mechanical center position in case you have accidentally selected the swapped pin-out.</small></p>
    </section>    
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="6.3">Resetting the Auto-Ranging</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>The current internal settings for the Auto-Ranging of a pedal are stored and kept in non-volatile memory so there is no need to run the Auto-Ranging procedure each time the C15 is powered up.</p>
        <p>There are several cases, though, when a pedal might not reach the complete 0%...100% span and a reset of the Auto-Ranging will be required:</p>
        <ul>
            <li>The pedal has a <q>minimum</q> or <q>range</q> control that has been touched, reducing the effective electrical travel.</li>
            <li>The pedal has been replaced with another, different pedal while the C15 was off,notably when changing between compatible types. The C15 has no way of knowing that you changed the pedal and will continue to use the internal settings it had found and stored for the original pedal.</li>
            <li>in rare cases, both the pedal hardware and/or the electronics may have developed significant drift and the full 0%...100% range isn’t reached anymore, for continuous output pedal presets types.</li>
        </ul>
        <p>There are two ways to reset the Auto-Ranging:</p>
        <ul>
            <li>unplug and re-plug the pedal, at the C15 side (and note the need for the re-plugging procedure be finished in less than one second), while the C15 is running.</li>
            <li>or simply select a different pedal preset temporarily, then select the original pedal preset again.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>    
</main>
</div>
</body>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-pedals/07-pedal-types">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/index.html">Pedal Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/07-pedal-types.html" data-number="7">Pedal / Source Types</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="7">Pedal / Source Types</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="7.1">Expression and Damper Pedals with Continuous Output</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>Most expression and damper pedals use a 3-wire cable and have a TRS plug. The basis of their operation is the voltage divider principle, using a potentiometer: A voltage is applied to the potentiometer and the wiper is moved by the pedal action. The readout is taken from the voltage at the wiper divided by the applied voltage. The wiper is internally attached either to the tip of the TRS plug (this is the <q>Tip-Active</q> pin-out, also known as <q>Boss/Roland</q> pin-out) or the wiper can go to the ring contact of the TRS (the <q>Ring Active</q> pin-out, also known as <q>Yamaha</q> pin-out).</p>
        <p>However, there are a few pedals, for example the Korg DS-1H damper pedal, that work internally with a simple adjustable resistor whose value changes with pedal action. Such pedals use only 2-wires (even when a TRS plug is used at the cable end). Here, the read- out is basically directly proportional to the resistance value. The C15 supports this type of pedal provided that the adjustable element is connected between tip and sleeve contacts of the TRS or TS plug (<q>tip active</q>, which is the standard case, though).</p>
        <p>Some expression and damper pedals can be switched between <q>continuous</q> and <q>switch</q> modes, please set such selectors to <q>continuous</q> position.</p>
        <p>Some expression pedals, for example many Roland and Boss models, have a <q>minimum volume</q> control on the side or the front of the base, please set this control to its lowest position (fully counter-clockwise) for best results. The C15 can also handle those pedals correctly even with this <q>minimum volume</q> set to other positions but resolution and stability may be compromised (see Auto-Ranging and Auto-Hold feature descriptions).</p>
        <p>Some expression pedals, for example some Moog models, have a <q>range</q> control on the side or the front of the base which restricts the maximum value the output can reach and that includes zero output if the control is set fully counter-clockwise! Please set this control to the highest position (fully clockwise) for best results, otherwise again resolution and stability may be compromised (see Auto-Ranging and Auto-Hold feature descriptions).</p>
        <p>Some expression pedals, for example some Moog and M-Audio models, have a pin-out selector witch, typically on the bottom of the base, where the used connector pin-out can be selected. Often, this switch is marked with the pedal’s brand name on one side and <q>other</q> on the other side. The provided pedal presets indicate the required setting for some known pedals. For other pedals, please select the pedal brand name position which typically selects the <q>Boss/Roland</q> (Tip-Active) pin-out which is the preferred pin-out.</p>
        <p>Some expression pedals are intended to be used with external cables, therefore make sure to use a correct cable (usually 3-wire with TRS connectors on both ends). Some pedals are multi-function and have several output jacks. Please use the output explicitly marked as <q>Expression</q>, <q>Exp</q> or similar.</p>
        <p>Damper pedals (pedals which go back to their normal rest position when foot pressure is absent) come in two varieties. The first type produces minimum output in the rest position that increases when the pedal is pressed, and the other type does exactly the opposite, going from maximum output to minimum output when pressing the pedal. The C15 has pedal presets to handle either type correctly.</p>
        <p>All continuous pedal presets of the C15 use both the Auto-Ranging and Auto-Hold feature (see Auto-Ranging and Auto-Hold feature descriptions). There is no output from the pedal source until the Auto-Ranging has completed which requires that the pedal is moved across at least some fraction of its total travel.</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>You may use a physical switch as well for a continuous output, it will just jump between ࠌ the extremes (0%, 100%) with only one or two intermediate values. When using a physi- cal switch, select one of the <q>Resistor</q> types of presets.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="7.2">Switches with Bi-stable Output</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>Switches are also supported, technically a switch is handled like an adjustable resistor with the values only jumping between zero resistance (<q>closed</q>) and infinite resistance (<q>open</q>).</p>
        <p>While Auto-Ranging is used for the provided Switch presets as well, a difference is that
        a switch pedal gives output to a Macro Control immediately, the Auto-Ranging does not have to be completed. A <q>best guess</q> initial value is used for the output which is reflecting the correct state in 99% of the cases.</p>
        <p>The main difference is that the output of the switch, feeding the Macro Control, is chang- ing only between 0% and 100% endpoints and there are never any intermediate values, that’s why it’s called bi-stable.</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Note: You may perfectly use a continuous-type pedal for a switching type of response, the Auto-Ranging feature makes that work for potentiometer as well as adjustable resistor types of pedals. The only restriction is that the pedal must be of the <q>Tip Active</q> type.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="7.3">Control Voltages</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>Control Voltages can be used as an additional source type. A typical example would be the CV output of an LFO in an analog synth. Two pedal presets are available for this, one with Auto-Ranging to automatically adapt to the voltage range the source actually sends, creating the full 0%...100% span, and another pedal preset with a fixed range of 0V (=0%) to 5V (=100%).</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Note: The frequency of a modulated control voltage should not be larger than a few Hz, higher frequencies might produce strange results and the Auto-Ranging (if used) might not be working as intended.</p>
        </div>
        <div data-highlight="warn">
            <p>Warning: The voltage range of the CV source must be within 0V...+5V. Never connect sources with other output ranges (like -5V...+5V, 0V...+10V, etc) as they might damage the C15, regardless of selected pedal preset. Also, do not apply a control voltage while the C15 is switched off.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    </label>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="8">Features explained</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="8.1">Auto-Ranging</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>Many pedals don’t have their electrical output fully follow the mechanical position over the complete travel, there are mechanical <q>dead zones</q> where the electrical output does not follow the mechanical position anymore. There is nothing we can do about this.</p>
        <p>But many pedals also have the additional effect that the internal element (potentiometer or variable-resistor) in the first place is not used over the full range that it does have electrically, this is depending on the construction of the pedal. We have found pedals that don’t go any further than 70% or so, for example.</p>
        <p>Further, some pedals have additional control knobs to intentionally limit the output range in some way, very common is a minimum control that introduces a sort-of base value that is added to the actual setting. For example, the minimum control on Roland and Boss pedals can be dialed in to give a base value of 80% at the pedal’s <q>zero</q> position and the output value will increase to 100% when moving the pedal to the <q>full</q> position, spanning only 20% of the possible range.</p>
        <p>Finally, the already restricted obtainable electrical output range often is not very stable at the range ends, this is mostly for mechanical slack and other mechanical issues, notably on pedals with a construction that is not extremely rigid, mechanically.</p>
        <p>The C15 is designed so that all pedals will always actually reach the full value output from 0% to %100 regardless of the above short-comings and almost regardless of any setting of additional minimum and range control knobs found on the pedal. By this, you can change pedals and that won’t alter the playing experience at all just because the raw pedal behaves differently.</p>
        <p>In the Auto-Ranging process running continuously in the background, the C15 measures the maximum electrical range the pedal has produced so far and sets marker points for the conversion (scaling) to the final 0%...%100 range (black area in below drawing).</p>
    
    
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Auto-Ranging">
            <picture class="content" data-src="images/pedal-manual/autorange-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>


        <p>The measured electrical range can only increase over time of usage and once it is large enough for a successful scaling -- larger than about 1/4th of maximum range -- the pedal actually starts to produce output values. The only way to make the used electrical range smaller again is to reset the pedal.</p>
        <p>Once the pedal has been operated over the full range of mechanical travel the pedal will work with best resolution and stability.</p>
        <p>The marker point values actually used for the computation are slightly backed off from the measured min and max values. These <q>electrical dead-zones</q> (gray) allow that unstable electrical end point outputs will still give stable 0% or 100% output at the end stops but they also slightly reduce the effective range of pedal travel, so this is a trade-off. Ranging and stability characteristics for pedals of known make and model are stored in pedal-specific presets, for best results.</p>
        <p>The Auto-Ranging is reset when the pedal is (re-)plugged into a running C15 or when the pedal type is changed in the Pedal Settings.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="8.2">Auto-Hold</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>When using several hardware sources like two pedals or a pedal and ribbon feeding the same Macro Control, we do not want to always update the Macro Control with the source that produced the last change following every minute amount of change. Value updates shall only happen when the user is apparently moving the hardware source’s position intentionally, whereas small variations from general electric noise but also from mechanical vibration etc. shall have no effect. As long as the input is only noise and random fluctuation the final output value shall not change.</p>
        <p>On the other hand, when the user really operates the pedal the value should track what the user <q>meant</q> no matter how minute the changes are as long as they look reasonable.</p>
        <p>Therefore, a compromise solution is needed and this is the C15’s intelligent automated track-and-hold.</p>


        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Auto-Hold">
            <picture class="content" data-src="images/pedal-manual/autohold-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>


        <p>Normally, for fast and wide enough value changes, the track-and-hold mechanism is in <q>track</q> mode and the output strictly follows the momentary input (black).</p>
        <p>At point A, a window detector (dotted rectangle) decided that the momentary values are considered stable now for long enough, then a new output value (blue) is set up to reach an averaged level after a short time (at point 2), using a ramp (red).</p>
        <p>This output value is then frozen, held constant until the current margins of tolerance are hit, marked by point B in time, from where <q>track</q> mode is used again. A ramp (red) is used again to steer the output back to the train of momentary values. The system is in <q>hold</q> state between points A and B and the output value is frozen as denoted by the blue horizontal line.</p>
        <p>The <q>values-are-stable</q> window can be different than the <q>tolerance</q> window, and some specific settings are used for known pedals. Further, these windows partly adapt to the signal situation dynamically.</p>
        
        <p>As can be seen, ramps are not necessarily linear (straight lines). Actually, a ramp creates a cross-fade between two value trains, neither of which needs to be a constant value over time. Technically, the ramps are generated by ramping down a factor from 1.0 to 0.0. This factor is newly calculated for every point in time along the ramp and applied to deter- mine the contribution of the two value trains. For example, the ramp starting at point A is a cross-fade from the momentary input values to the sequence of the average values of the sliding window. The last value from this train of averages (dashed line) is calculated from the input values between points 1 and 2, and this determines the final value of the cross-fade at point 2 from where on the value is held constant.</p>
        <p>Not shown here, when the momentary values change very slowly but eventually drift beyond margins another ramp is generated but the <q>hold</q> state remains active with the tolerance window shifted up or down one window height.<br />Also, the detector always scans for fast and wide <q>shock</q> changes where <q>hold</q> mode is left and any active ramp speeds are tightened up to very quickly follow the momentary output again.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-pedals/index.html">Pedal Manual</a>

    </label>
