<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="9">Troubleshooting and Tips</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p><em>9.1 The selected pedal type is not working. When I repeatedly move from end stop to end stop, I don’t see any values changing in the Pedal-Editor</em></p>
        <p>First, select a different pedal preset temporarily then go back to the intended one and check again, or unplug and re-plug the pedal.</p>
        <p>Check if the general pedal preset type is correct for the pedal (if, for example, you have selected <q>Resistor</q> for a standard 3-wire pedal that is ring-active, you will never get any output from that because the C15 is sensing on the wrong pin).</p>
        <p>Check it the plug is inserted fully in to the C15. Check if the cable itself is not broken. Set any <q>minimum</q> knobs to fully counter-clockwise, and any <q>range</q> knobs fully clockwise. Check if any switches are set properly. Check that the <q>Expression</q> jack is used with multi-function pedals.</p>
        <p><em>9.2 The pedal has very uneven output over the mechanical travel</em></p>
        <p>Quite likely you have selected a pedal preset with the wrong pin assignment for a 3-wire Pedal. Try swapping tip-active with ring-active pedal presets and vice versa, and auto- range the pedal after a pedal preset change. Also check if any pin-out selector switch is in the correct position, those are often at the bottom of the pedal base and are prone to change position unintentionally when handling the pedal.</p>
        <p>If that doesn’t fix it, there is a rare chance that the pedal is not using a linear potentiometer but you might also happen to have used the wrong output jack of a multi-function pedal. Always use the output that is marked with <q>EXP</q>, <q>Expression</q> or similar.</p>
        <p><em>9.3 I don’t get the full 0% to 100% span of output values anymore when I move the pedal from end stop to end stop</em></p>
        <p>It’s possibly time to redo the Auto-Ranging as some characteristics of the pedal have changed which the C15 could not track, like a re-adjusted <q>minimum</q> level control on the pedal. Unplug and re-plug the pedal at the C15 or select a different pedal preset temporarily, then auto-range the pedal again.</p>
        <p>In rare cases you might want to select a compatible pedal preset that has larger electrical dead-zones to catch unstable values at the end stops. Those are <q>D:Roland DP-10 (cont.)</q>, <q>E:Moog EP-3 (std.)</q> and the generic presets. See table of pedal presets for details.</p>
        <p><em>9.4 The pedal output is high (100%) at the start position and low (0%) at the end position</em></p>
        <p>Try using a pedal preset with reverse output, those are available for the generic 3-wire potentiometer pedals as well as for 2-wire resistors, and of course for switches.</p>
        <p><em>9.5 The pedal output is very drifty and shows suddenly changing values</em></p>
        <p>Check cable for broken conductors. Note: If you are using a tip-active pedal (<q>Roland</q> pin-out) you might be able to save the gig by using the <q>Resistor</q> setting.</p>
        <p><em>9.6 The pedal constantly overwrites a shared Macro Control with new values even when I don’t touch it</em></p>
        <p>The pedal might have developed additional mechanical and electrical slack and instabil- ity over time and should be serviced or replaced. When it is a tip-active pedal preset, you might try to change to the <q>E:Moog EP-3 (std.)</q> pedal preset which is set up for about the strongest Auto-Hold behavior.</p>
        <p>Likewise, when you feel to have the opposite problem with the pedal not reacting close enough to pedal movement, you may want to try the <q>E:Fractal EV-2</q> pedal preset which is set up only weak Auto-Hold behavior. Again, useful only for tip-active pedals. With ring-active pedals, you can still try the other ring-active presets, also from the generic list and see if you get better results. See table of pedal presets for details.</p>
        <p><em>9.7 Can I use a continuous pedal as a makeshift solution for a true switching pedal?</em></p>
        <p>You may perfectly use a continuous-type pedal for a switching action (using one of the Switch presets), the Auto-Ranging feature makes this work for potentiometer as well as adjustable resistor types of pedals. The only restriction is that the pedal must be of the <q>Tip Active</q> type.</p>
        <p><em>9.8 Can I use a switch as a makeshift solution for a true continuous pedal?</em></p>
        <p>You may use a physical switch as well for a continuous output, it will just jump between the extremes (0%, 100%) with only one or two intermediate values. When using a physical switch, select one of the <q>Resistor</q> types of presets. Again, the restriction is that the switch must be of the <q>Tip Active</q> type.</p>
        <p><em>9.9 Can I use <q>powered/active</q> (relay- or electronic-switch based) switchers?</em></p>
        <p>With some caution this will work as expected.</p>
        <p>There are certain battery- or mains-powered switching pedals that use the ring contact of their TRS jack to close the internal electrical circuit, for those only use a 2-wire cable with TS-plugs on both ends and the cable must first be connected to the switch before plugging into the C15, otherwise the function might not work properly and the input might even be damaged.</p>
    </section>
</main>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="I">Safety Instructions, Precautions</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>Warning Symbols</h3>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <picture class="symbol large" data-src="./images/symbols/shocking-color.png"></picture>
                </th>
                <td>
                    <p>This symbol indicates a risk of electric shock.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <picture class="symbol large" data-src="./images/symbols/important-color.png"></picture>
                </th>
                <td>
                    <p>This symbol indicates important operating and maintenance instructions for the unit in the user manual.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
        </table>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>
            <span>Power Supply</span>
            <picture class="symbol" data-src="images/symbols/shocking-color.png"></picture>
            <picture class="symbol" data-src="./images/symbols/important-color.png"></picture>
        </h3>
        <p>Please use only the included power adapter. If this is not possible, obtain a power adapter with the following specifications:</p>
        <ul>
            <li>18 - 20 V DC</li>
            <li>2.5 A or higher</li>
            <li>Plug inner contact: 2.5 mm (+)</li>
            <li>Plug outer contact: 5.5 mm (-)</li>
        </ul>
        <p>Do not use a power adapter with different or unknown specifications, as this may electrically damage the device! You use a non-original power adapter at your own risk. Nonlinear Labs is not liable for damage caused by use of non-original power adapters.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>
            <span>Things to avoid doing</span>
            <picture class="symbol" data-src="./images/symbols/shocking-color.png"></picture>
            <picture class="symbol" data-src="./images/symbols/important-color.png"></picture>
        </h3>
        <p>Do not place the C15 on a soft surface (pillow, mattress, etc.) as this can block the circulation of air to the device while it is being used.</p>
        <p>The C15 is an electrical (and electronic) device: do not allow water to come into contact with it.</p>
        <p>Do not open the C15. The inner parts of the instrument compose an intricate network which is easily damaged and potentially hazardous for inexperienced users.</p>
        <p>Do not use the C15 in extreme ambient temperatures. Stable performance cannot be guaranteed in very hot or cold conditions. Also avoid high humidity and other difficult conditions.</p>
        <p>Always wait for the device to shut down completely before you disconnect its power supply. Do not disconnect the power supply during performance. Doing so can cause data to be lost.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>Pedal Integration</h3>
        <p>The C15 provides four <span data-keyword="Pedal Connectors"></span> (TRS sockets) allowing for the integration of external pedal controllers. As pedal controllers come with a wide variety of different behaviors and functionalities, there are a few things to consider in order to integrate them correctly.</p>
        <p>The <a href="./documents/man-pedals/index.html" class="label">Pedal Manual</a> will guide you through every step and aspect of connecting and setting up a pedal controller to the C15. Use it to avoid invalid integration of pedal controllers, which may lead to overheating or permanently damaging the C15.</p>
        <p>Once your pedal controllers are safely connected to the C15 and fully operable, it makes sense to explore them as a part of the <span data-keyword="Hardware Sources"></span>. In chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" class="label" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>, the general modulation concept can be found. Furthermore, chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-04-hw-sources.html" class="label" data-number="5.4">Using Hardware Sources</a> provides a detailed explanation of Hardware Sources and all their aspects and properties.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="1">Introduction</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>The C15 is an instrument for the performing musician, designed for playability and detailed sound editing. Its unique sound character ranges from crisp and organic to complex and experimental. The top-quality semi-weighted keybed drives a digital synthesis engine which responds with a wide spectrum of sound colors and intensities.</p>
        <p>As a dedicated real-time instrument, the C15 is built for human control. There are no modulation sources or sequencing modules to create rhythmic patterns - we leave this to the musician. Instead, the C15 is a decidedly responsive instrument which combines high-resolution keys, ribbons, and pedal inputs.</p>
        <p>Almost every parameter on the C15 can be selected directly by pressing a button. In other words, while all functions are software-defined, they have a dedicated haptic control surface. In addition, a <span data-keyword="Graphical"> User Interface</span> is available, which can be displayed and edited on any device with a browser application and Wi-Fi. Like many classical instrument builders, we have chosen wood for most parts of the housing. All other parts are made of steel or aluminium. Along with the excellent keyboard with monophonic <span data-keyword="Aftertouch"></span>, there is a specially-designed ergonomic (pitch) <span data-keyword="Bender"></span>, two very long <span data-keyword="Ribbons"></span> (touch-strips), and inputs for up to four <span data-keyword="Pedals"></span>.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>Symbols and formats used in this manual</h3>
        <div class="section" data-columns="2">
            <div>
                <p>Certain keywords appearing throughout the manual are highlighted.</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <p><span data-keyword="keyword"></span>, <span data-keyword="grouped"> keyword</span></p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <p>Important notes are highlighted as such and begin with an exclamation mark: &#xE171;.</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <div data-highlight="warn">
                    <p>This is an important message.</p>
                </div>
            </div>
            <div>
                <p>Similarly, a hint or a background information starts with an <q>i</q> symbol: &#xE162;.</p>
            </div>
            <div data-highlight="note">
                <p>This is some additional information.</p>
            </div>
            <div class="developer">
                <p>When using the Developer Mode, additional information will be visible: &#xE173;.</p>
            </div>
            <div class="developer" data-highlight="comment">
                <p>This is some additional developer information or comment.</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <p>A section which explains a user interaction or task has a (primary) heading on a grey background.</p>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <h4 class="heading primary">Interaction</h4>
                <p>Press a specific <span data-keyword="Button"></span> ...</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <p>Typically, such a task will be first explained for the <span data-keyword="Panel"> Unit</span>. If available (most cases) an explanation for the <span data-keyword="Graphical"> UI</span> and/or <span data-keyword="Base"> Unit</span> will follow. This type of heading has a lighter background.</p>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <h4 class="heading secondary" data-detail="Graphical UI"></h4>
                <p>Click on a specific <span data-keyword="Icon"></span> ...</p>
                <h4 class="heading secondary" data-detail="Base Unit"></h4>
                <p>...</p>
            </div>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>About this manual</h3>
        <p>The following chapters refer to different important aspects of using the C15. Each chapter excludes the broader picture by focussing only on the crucial related aspects.</p>
        <p>Nevertheless, the manual attempts to cover as many details as possible. When you use the manual, it is best to be sure you have identified the subject you are interested in before you look something up. The following overview explains how the manual is structured:</p>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <a href="./documents/man-user/02-setting-up/02-00-setting-up.html" data-number="2">Setting up the C15</a>
                </th>
                <td>
                    <p>Please read this chapter before you assemble the C15's components for the first time.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
                </th>
                <td>
                    <p>This chapter outlines the general approach to the C15, explaining how to perform with it, how the modulation mechanism works and how everything is organized.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-00-user-interfaces.html" data-number="4">User Interfaces</a>
                </th>
                <td>
                    <p>This chapter explains how to actually use the instrument. The navigation methods, editing and access to presets are described in detail for each available interface.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</a>
                </th>
                <td>
                    <p>All signal- and DSP-related aspects are covered in this chapter, including details on signal synthesis and flow, tutorials, and details on the integration of <span data-keyword="Hardware"> Sources</span>.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <a href="./documents/man-user/06-recorder/06-recorder.html" data-number="6">Recorder</a>
                </th>
                <td>
                    <p>This chapter explains the <span data-keyword="Studio Package">Recorder</span> feature of the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span>.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <a href="./documents/man-user/07-midi/07-00-midi.html" data-number="7">MIDI</a>
                </th>
                <td>
                    <p>This chapter explains the <span data-keyword="Studio Package">MIDI</span> features of the C15.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>
                    <a href="./documents/man-user/08-setup/08-setup.html" data-number="8">Setup (C15 System Settings)</a>
                </th>
                <td>
                    <p>When you have already gained some familiarity with the instrument, the setup chapter provides insight into the C15's advanced system settings.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
        </table>
        <div class="noprint" data-highlight="note">
            <p>Keep in mind that the HTML Manual provides some external links to the web, such as the Nonlinear Labs download section, for example.</p>
            <p>However, these links will only work when an internet connection is active, which is usually not the case when accessing the HTML Manual by using the C15 <span data-keyword="Graphical"> UI</span> (because the connection is already in use for the Wi-Fi hotspot, provided by the C15).</p>
            <p>When connected with the C15, a second Wi-Fi adapter can be used in order to access the internet from the mobile device in parallel.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>

    </label>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3 id="ch-2-1" class="heading" data-number="2.1">Installing the Panel Unit</h3>
        <p>Make sure the C15 is switched off before proceeding in the following four steps:</p>
        <div class="section" data-columns="2">
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Mounting Brackets">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/mounting-brackets.jpg"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p data-number="1">Attach the <span data-keyword="Mounting"> Brackets</span> to the <span data-keyword="Base"> Unit</span> by hooking and snapping them into place.</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Placing the Panel Unit">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/panel-unit.jpg"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p data-number="2">Place the <span data-keyword="Panel"> Unit</span> onto the installed Mounting Brackets. The two <span data-keyword="Mounting"> Screws</span> on the bottom of the Panel Unit fit into the holes at the top of each Mounting Bracket.
                </p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Mounting Screws">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/screws.jpg"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p data-number="3">Tighten down the Mounting Screws to lock the Panel Unit into place.</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Connecting Base Unit and Panel Unit">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/connector-cable.jpg"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p data-number="4">Connect <span data-keyword="Base"> Unit</span> and Panel Unit with the <span data-keyword="Connector"> Cable</span>.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <p>Now the C15 is ready to use and can be switched on. In order to disassemble the paired configuration, undo above four steps in reverse order. The C15's Base Unit can also be used without the Panel Unit.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3 id="ch-2-2" class="heading" data-number="2.2">Connections</h3>
        <p>The following external connections are provided by the <span data-keyword="Base"> Unit</span>:</p>
        <div class="section" data-columns="2">
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Headphone level and connector">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/headphone-connector.jpg"></picture>
                    <figcaption>
                        <span data-keyword="Headphone"> Output</span>
                    </figcaption>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p>The headphone output provides a 6.3 mm stereo headphone socket with separate, preset-independent adjustable headphone level. The headphone socket is suitable for all kinds of headphones but we strongly recommend to turn down the level when connecting low-impendance ear plugs.
                </p>
                <p>The headphone level is independent from the main output level (see below).</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Audio Output (level)">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/output-volume.jpg"></picture>
                    <figcaption>
                        <span data-keyword="Audio Output"> Level</span>
                    </figcaption>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p>The line output level is adjustable by the potentiometer at the right end of the front bar.</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Audio Output (connectors)">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/audio-output.jpg"></picture>
                    <figcaption>
                        <span data-keyword="Audio Output"> Connectors</span>
                    </figcaption>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p>The audio output provides two parallel line-level stereo pairs of audio sockets (6.3mm TRS and XLR). Both pairs of sockets provide identical signals. The signals are transformer-balanced and ground-free, therefore in most cases a DI-box is not necessary. Unbalanced and balanced plugs can be connected. When connecting to unbalanced inputs please use unbalanced cables and plugs.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Note that using both TRS and XLR outputs at the same time may cause hum.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="section" data-columns="2">
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Disconnecting Base Unit and Panel Unit">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/connector-cable.jpg"></picture>
                    <figcaption>
                        <span data-keyword="Connector"> Cable</span>
                    </figcaption>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p>For removing the cable pull the plastic housing of the connector. Avoid to stress the Connector Cable.</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Pedals">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/pedal-connectors.jpg"></picture>
                    <figcaption>
                        <span data-keyword="Pedal"> Connectors</span>
                    </figcaption>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p>Four 6.3 mm pedal sockets are provided for external pedal control. In general, any keyboard controller pedal can be connected. However, we recommend continuous pedals as they allow for the most nuanced performance.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <section>
            <h4>Connecting Pedals and mapping Hardware Sources</h4>
            <p>Most factory presets use the mapping shown below. For more information on <span data-keyword="Hardware"> Sources</span>, and especially modulation aspects, refer to chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-04-hw-sources.html" data-number="5.4">Using Hardware Sources</a>.</p>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Pedal Setup">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/pedal-setup-*.svg"></picture>
            </figure>
            <div class="section" data-columns="2">
                <div>
                    <figure class="border maximize" data-label="USB Conenctor">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/usb-connector.jpg"></picture>
                    </figure>
                </div>
                <div class="section">
                    <p>The USB connection is used for plugging in the USB flash drive included with the C15. The drive is used for transferring preset Banks and installing Updates. The <span data-keyword="MIDI">Bridge</span> as well as external MIDI devices can be connected here as well.</p>
                </div>
                <div>
                    <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Power">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/power.jpg"></picture>
                    </figure>
                </div>
                <div class="section">
                    <p>The C15 comes with its own external power adapter, which connects to the power inlet. A small LED next to the inlet indicates the power, boot and shut-down status of the C15.</p>
                </div>
            </div>
        </section>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/02-setting-up/02-00-setting-up.html" data-number="2">Setting up the C15</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/02-setting-up/02-03-start-shutdown.html" data-number="2.3">Start and Shutdown</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3 id="ch-2-3" class="heading" data-number="2.3">Start and Shutdown</h3>
        <div class="section" data-columns="2">
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Start and Shutdown">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/start-shutdown.jpg"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div>
                <p>To turn on the C15, press the power button for around one second. It will take several seconds for the device to boot up and be ready to use. The most recent settings are loaded on startup. To shut down the C15, press the power button again for around a second. The shutdown process takes several seconds, during which it stores the current settings for the next startup, before the device turns off. A small LED next to the power inlet indicates the C15's status as follows:</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div data-columns="1">
            <table>
                <tr>
                    <th>steady on</th>
                    <td>on/normal operation</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>slow flashing</th>
                    <td>booting up</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>fast flashing</th>
                    <td>shutting down</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>one flash every 2 seconds</th>
                    <td>standby</td>
                </tr>
            </table>
        </div>
        <p>A flickering LED indicates abnormal operation. For instance, it may mean that the supply voltage is too low.</p>
        <div data-highlight="warn">
            <p>Make sure not to disconnect the power supply while you are using the C15 (booting up, performance, shutdown), otherwise its data may be lost.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>

        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/02-setting-up/02-04-graphical-ui.html" data-number="2.4">Setting up a device for the Graphical User Interface</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3 id="ch-2-4" class="heading" data-number="2.4">Setting up a device for the Graphical User Interface</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="The Graphical User Interface">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/package/hw-setup/graphical-ui.jpg"></picture>
        </figure>
        <section>
            <h4>Concept</h4>
            <p>The C15 is designed for flexible operation and interaction, with the <span data-keyword="Base">Unit</span> being necessary for connections and performance. In addition, the <span data-keyword="Panel">Unit</span> provides the <span data-keyword="Hardware">User Interface</span>, with access to all parameters, presets and settings.</p>
            <p>
                Finally, the Base Unit also provides a Wi-Fi hotspot for connection to external devices like smartphones, tablets, laptops and desktop computers. When connected, the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span> can be accessed with a browser running on the external device. Multiple external devices can be connected simultaneously, and each can display different features. However, only one parameter can be focussed on at a time, which synchronises the Hardware User Interface with each external connected device.
            </p>
            <p>Furthermore, the Wi-Fi connection can be used for preset interchange, and hence the option to back up preset banks to the external device. The C15 Reference is also accessible in the browser.</p>
        </section>
        <section>
            <h4>System Requirements</h4>
            <p>Due to the browser-based implementation of the Graphical User Interface, there are almost no limitations concerning compatibility with operating systems and browsers. Basically, the only system requirements are that the device must be Wi-Fi capable and have a browser.</p>
            <p>However, given the vast variety of devices, operating systems and browsers, optimal performance cannot be guaranteed in all cases. Differences between browsers, fast changes in technologies and frequent updates contribute to a complex situation which makes it very hard to say what works best.</p>
            <p>Nevertheless, our experience in the development of the system enables us to make some recommendations and state some minimal requirements:</p>
            <ul class="list-section">
                <li>The device should have at least a 1 GHz processor and 2 GB RAM.</li>
                <li>The device's display should support multi touch, or a mouse should be connected. A connected or integrated keyboard is useful for using the Graphical User Interface.</li>
                <li>The device should have at least a 7'' diagonal display.</li>
                <li>Although the choice of browser is completely up to the user, currently (September 2020) the best performance is given by Google Chrome.</li>
            </ul>
            <div data-highlight="note">
                <p>If you encounter problems with your setup, try to restart your device or change to another browser (or device). If not, or if the problem won't go away, please contact us directly for help. We appreciate feedback and user reports and will do our best to solve your problem as soon as possible.</p>
            </div>
        </section>
        <section>
            <h4>Wi-Fi Settings</h4>
            <p>To set up a well defined Wi-Fi connection, enter the <span data-keyword="Setup"> Menu</span> on the Hardware User Interface (<span data-keyword="Setup"> Button</span>) and navigate to <b>System Info</b>. Here, all relevant aspects of the Wi-Fi connection are listed:</p>
            <table>
                <tr>
                    <th>Device Name</th>
                    <td>You can name your C15 instrument by focussing on the device name entry and pressing <span data-keyword="Enter"></span> to access the Rename Screen. Once the name is set, an SSID will be generated. The SSID is composed of a prefix (<code>NL-C15-</code>) and the name you just gave to the instrument.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>SSID</th>
                    <td>A Wi-Fi network with the same name as the SSID will be displayed when you scan for available networks on your external device. Connecting to this network enables your external device to control the C15 with a browser. The SSID is generated once during the booting process, so you will have to reboot the device when you rename it.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Passphrase</th>
                    <td>The network connection is secure, so a passphrase is needed to establish a connection. To connect to the network with your external device, use the displayed passphrase to confirm. The passphrase can be generated randomly by focussing on the corresponding entry and pressing <span data-keyword="Enter"></span>. Select and run the command <code>generate new</code>. If you suspect that the passphrase is no longer secure (because it has been shared with someone), a new passphrase should be generated.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Address</th>
                    <td>
                        <p><b>192.168.8.2</b></p>
                        <p>Once the connection is established, copy and past the address into your browser's address bar and the Graphical User Interface should appear in your browser.</p>
                    </td>
                </tr>
            </table>
            <p>The Wi-Fi connection can also be disabled to provide a more secure setup and prevent anyone else controlling the device remotely. This may be especially useful when performing live. Enter the Setup Menu (<span data-keyword="Setup"> Button</span>) and navigate to <b>Device Settings</b>. At the bottom of the list, find <code>Enable/Disable WiFi</code> and change the setting.</p>
            <div data-highlight="note">
                <p>If you encounter problems navigating the Setup Menu intuitively, please refer to chapters <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-00-user-interfaces.html" data-number="4">User Interfaces</a> and <a href="./documents/man-user/08-setup/08-setup.html" data-number="8">Setup (C15 System Settings)</a>.</p>
            </div>
        </section>
        <section>
            <h4>Browser-specific issues</h4>
            <p>As already mentioned, there may be restrictions on some browsers, as there is no real standard on functionality. We do our best to keep track of browser-specific issues and offer solutions if we can find them.</p>
            <!-- <p>Please refer to the <a href="./documents/known-issues/index.html" class="label">Known Issues</a> document for more information.</p> -->
        </section>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<main>
    <section>
        <h3 id="ch-2-5" class="heading" data-number="2.5">Pedal Integration</h3>
        <p>As mentioned, the safe way of integrating pedals into the system would be when the C15 is switched off. After all connections were made, the C15 can be switched on and all connected pedals will be recognized and integrated accordingly. For more information about pedal integration, refer to chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-04-hw-sources.html" data-number="5.4">Using Hardware Sources</a>.</p>
    </section>
</main>

        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3">Basic Concepts</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>Interacting with the C15</h3>
        <section>
            <p>There are multiple ways to interact with the C15, each consisting of a different organisation and optimized layout of the information it represents, depending on the interface you are using. However, the basic structure and handling options remain comparable, as each form of interaction follows the same underlying principle.</p>
            <p>This chapter covers these general concepts, terms and keywords in detail, and explains the various means of interaction with the <span data-keyword="Hardware"> User Interface</span> and <span data-keyword="Graphical"> User Interface</span>, along with the modulation mechanism and presets.</p>
            <p>Overall, three interfaces are available:</p>
        </section>
        <section>
            <h4 class="heading primary">The Base Unit</h4>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="The Base Unit">
                <picture class="content">
                    <svg class="image-container" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 468 144" >
                        <foreignObject width="468" height="144">
                            <picture data-src="./images/hardware-ui/base-unit-top-*.svg"></picture>
                        </foreignObject>
                        <g class="noprint">
                            <foreignObject x="50" y="120" width="70" height="20">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-1-base-unit-headphones.html" title="Headphone Connectors and Volume"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                            <foreignObject x="70" y="12" width="50" height="45">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-1-base-unit-bender-ribbons.html" title="Bender and Ribbons"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                            <foreignObject x="195" y="12" width="80" height="25">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-1-base-unit-control-panel.html" title="Base Unit Control Panel"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                            <foreignObject x="375" y="120" width="50" height="20">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-1-base-unit-output-volume.html" title="Output Volume"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                        </g>
                    </svg>
                </picture>
                <picture class="content">
                    <svg class="image-container" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 468 90">
                        <foreignObject width="468" height="90">
                            <picture data-src="./images/hardware-ui/base-unit-back-*.svg"></picture>
                        </foreignObject>
                        <g class="noprint">
                            <foreignObject x="40" y="60" width="25" height="20">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-2-base-unit-power.html" title="Power Connector and Switch"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                            <foreignObject x="85" y="43" width="33" height="37">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-2-base-unit-audio-outputs.html" title="Audio Outputs"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                            <foreignObject x="125" y="50" width="48" height="30">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-2-base-unit-pedal-connectors.html" title="Pedal Connectors"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                            <foreignObject x="175" y="50" width="20" height="30">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-2-base-unit-usb.html" title="USB Connector"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                            <foreignObject x="365" y="20" width="70" height="60">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-2-base-unit-connector-cable.html" title="Unit Connector Cable"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                        </g>
                    </svg>
                </picture>
            </figure>
            <p>The <span data-keyword="Base"> Unit</span> provides access to all performance-related items (<span data-keyword="Hardware"> Sources</span>, <span data-keyword="Keys"></span>). It can also be used to edit parameters and navigate presets and banks. Navigation of parameters may be provided in future upgrades to the system.</p>
        </section>
        <section>
            <h4 class="heading primary">The Panel Unit</h4>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="The Panel Unit">
                <picture class="content">
                    <svg class="image-container" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 405 75" >
                        <foreignObject width="405" height="75">
                            <picture data-src="./images/hardware-ui/panel-unit-top-*.svg"></picture>
                        </foreignObject>
                        <g class="noprint">
                            <foreignObject x="45" y="13" width="128" height="52">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-3-panel-unit-left-panels.html" title="Parameter Panels (left)"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                            <foreignObject x="173" y="13" width="60" height="52">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-3-panel-unit-edit-panel.html" title="Edit Panel"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                            <foreignObject x="234" y="13" width="128" height="52">
                                <div class="link">
                                    <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-3-panel-unit-right-panels.html" title="Parameter Panels (right)"></a>
                                </div>
                            </foreignObject>
                        </g>
                    </svg>
                </picture>
            </figure>
            <p>The <span data-keyword="Panel"> Unit</span> can be used to select and edit parameters, modulation controls and system settings. Presets, banks and the undo history can all be navigated and managed here. In short, all the C15's data can be controlled with the Panel Unit.</p>
            <p>Four <span data-keyword="Parameter"> Panels</span>, are provided, each consisting of 24 <span data-keyword="Parameter"> Selection Buttons</span>. Most of the parameters can be accessed this way.</p>
        </section>
        <section>
            <h4 class="heading primary">The Graphical User Interface</h4>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Graphical User Interface">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-webui-browser-tabs-*.svg"></picture>
                </figure>
                <div class="section">
                    <p>The <span data-keyword="Graphical"> User Interface</span> also provides full access to all parameters, modulation controls and system settings. However, it also offers more extensive helper features and settings, such as access to the <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>.</p>
                    <p>Since version <span class="sw-version">21-26</span>, a dedicated <span data-keyword="MC"> View</span> and <span data-keyword="Recorder"></span> are also available as separate tabs in your browser.</p>
                </div>
            </div>
        </section>
        <section>
            <h3>Key Range of the C15</h3>
            <h4>Key Range prior to version <span class="sw-version">20-12</span></h4>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="C15 Key Range">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-keyrange-prior-2020-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>In earlier versions, the C15 only operated on its physical key range of 61 keys (C1 ... C6). The <span data-keyword="Hardware UI"> Note Shift</span> was applied as a tuning, whereas Split Point and Fade From or Range parameters were bound to the physical key range, effectively ignoring the Note Shift.</p>
            <p>Polyphonic Key Pan in the Output Mixer was also bound to the physical key range, also effectively ignoring the Note Shift.</p>
            <p>With this static behavior of key ranges on polyphonic Part association, fade level and panning, it became apparent that there are limitations.</p>
            <h4>Key Range since version <span class="sw-version">20-12</span></h4>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="C15 Key Range">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-keyrange-since-2020-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>In this version, a virtual key range of 128 keys (C-2 ... G8) was added. The physical key range of 61 keys is now projected onto the virtual key range, depending on the Note Shift (which is now a real key shift and not a tuning anymore).</p>
            <p>Extreme Note Shift may exceed the virtual key range for certain keys, in which case no note is produced.</p>
            <p>Split Point and Fade From or Range parameters now operate within the virtual key range and the Note Shift can be used to transpose into or out of parts. The parameters still can only be set within the physical key range (C1 ... C6) - which will be addressed by a future update.</p>
            <p>Polyphonic Key Pan in the Output Mixer now also operates within the virtual key range and the Note Shift can be used to transpose into or out of more extreme panning. At 100%, the panning starts to clip at the physical key range’s edges (C1 ... C6), at 47.24 % the panning covers the whole virtual key range (C-2 ... G8).
            </p>
        </section>
        <section>
            <h3>About this chapter</h3>
            <p>Each <span data-keyword="User"> Interface</span> allows you to interact with a number of elements (most of which are contained in presets). We explain these items and their features in general terms in this chapter (the individual interfaces are explained in full detail in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-00-user-interfaces.html" data-number="4">User Interfaces</a>).</p>
        </section>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-1-base-unit-bender-ribbons.html">Bender and Ribbons</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3>Bender and Ribbons</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Bender and Ribbons">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="images/info-gfk/gfk-bu-ovw-bend-ribs-*.png"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div>
                <p>The two 800 mm <span data-keyword="Ribbons"></span> (touch strips) are equipped with 33 LED dots. They can be used as Hardware Source in absolute or relative mode, each combinable with individual return behavior (zero or center).
                </p>
                <p>The magnetical loaded <span data-keyword="Bender"></span> can be used for bending pitches or other parameters. Read how to assign a <span data-keyword="Macro"> Control</span> to Hardware Sources <a>here</a>.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<main>
    <section>
        <h3>Headphone Connectors and Volume</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Headphone Connectors and Volume">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/info-gfk/gfk-bu-ovw-hp-connector-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <div class="section">
                <p>The 6.3 mm stereo headphone socket is suitable for all kinds of headphones but we strongly recommend to turn down the level when connecting low-impendance ear plugs.</p>
                <p>The output level is independent from the <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-1-base-unit-output-volume.html">main output level</a> (adjustable by the right hand potentiometer).</p>
            </div>
        </div>

    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/03-basic-concepts/base-unit/audio-outputs">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-2-base-unit-audio-outputs.html">Audio Outputs</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3>Audio Outputs</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Audio Outputs">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/info-gfk/gfk-bu-ovw-audio-out-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <div class="section">
                <p>The audio output provides two parallel line-level stereo pairs of audio sockets (6.3mm TRS and XLR).</p>
                <p>The signals are transformer-balanced and ground-free, therefore in most cases a DI-box is not necessary.</p>
                <p>Unbalanced and balanced plugs can be connected. When connecting to unbalanced inputs please use unbalanced cables and plugs.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Note that using both TRS and XLR outputs at the same time may cause hum.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-2-base-unit-power.html">Power Connector, LED and Button</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3>Power Connector, LED and Button</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Power Connector">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/info-gfk/gfk-bu-ovw-power-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <div class="section">
                <p>The C15 comes with its own external power adapter, which can be connected to the corresponding appliance inlet.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <p>A small LED next to the inlet indicates the power, boot and shut-down states of the C15 as follows:</p>
        <div data-columns="1">
            <table>
                <tr>
                    <th>steady on</th>
                    <td>on/normal operation</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>slow flashing</th>
                    <td>booting up</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>fast flashing</th>
                    <td>shutting down</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>one flash every 2 seconds</th>
                    <td>standby</td>
                </tr>
            </table>
        </div>
        <p>A flickering LED indicates an irregular operation mode. It means for example the supply voltage is too low.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>

        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>

        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-3-panel-unit-left-panels.html">Parameter Panels (left)</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3>Parameter Panels (left)</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Parameter Panel 1">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/panels/param-panel-1.svg"></picture>
                <figcaption>Parameter Panel 1</figcaption>
            </figure>
            <div class="section">
                <p>The two <span data-keyword="Parameter"> Panels</span> on the left side provide parameters for <span data-keyword="Envelopes">(A, B, C)</span>, <span data-keyword="Oscillators">(A, B)</span> and <span data-keyword="Shapers">(A, B)</span>.</p>
                <p>When using the <span data-keyword="Rename">Screen</span>, the two panels will represent a keyboard input, with each button representing a specific key (see <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-12-rename-mechanism.html" data-number="4.12">The Rename Mechanism</a> for more information).</p>
            </div>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-01-sound-types">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-01-sound-types.html" data-number="3.1">Sound Types</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3.1">Sound Types</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div class="section" data-columns="2">
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Single Sounds">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/sound/boled-snd-single.png"></picture>
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/sound/webui-sound-single.png"></picture>

                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p>Originally, the C15 only supported <span data-keyword="Single"> Sounds</span>, where all voices are controlled by the same set of parameters. Since version <span class="sw-version">20-28</span>, <span data-keyword="Split"> Sounds</span> and <span data-keyword="Layer"> Sounds</span> are available consisting of two <span data-keyword="Parts"></span> (<span data-utf="ind-part-1"></span>, <span data-utf="ind-part-2"></span>). Each Part can use up to 12 voices based on its own parameter set - so most parameters will be available twice, per Part.</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Split Sounds">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/sound/boled-snd-split.png"></picture>
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/sound/webui-sound-split.png"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p>In <span data-keyword="Split"> Sounds</span> (&#xE0F2;) the Parts are assigned to two separate keyboard ranges. Part I can be played between the lowest key (C0) and the Split Point, Part II between the Split Point and the highest key (C6). The Parts have separate voice allocations, which means that they can have different settings for Mono and Unison. The Split Point is not affected by the <span data-keyword="Note"> Shift</span> function, the Master Tune or the Part Tune.</p>
            </div>
            <div>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Layer Sounds">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/sound/boled-snd-layer.png"></picture>
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/sound/webui-sound-layer.png"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p>In <span data-keyword="Layer"> Sounds</span> (&#xE0F5;) each voice of Part I will be played simultaneously with the corresponding voice of Part II. Both Parts share the same voice allocation, which means that they have identical settings for Mono and Unison.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Note that held Keys will reset when loading whole Presets or Parts of different types. </p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-02-performance">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-02-performance.html" data-number="3.2">Performance (Keybed and Hardware Sources)</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3.2">Performance (Keybed and Hardware Sources)</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Aftertouch">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/physical-controls/aftertouch.jpg"></picture>
            </figure>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Bender">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/physical-controls/bender.jpg"></picture>
            </figure>
        </div>
        <p>The <span data-keyword="Keybed"></span>, arguably the most important performance input, provides polyphonic control over notes (currently 24 voices) and monophonic <span data-keyword="Aftertouch"></span> (as shown above). The semi-weighted, high quality Keybed is produced by Fatar, and has 61 keys (5 octaves).</p>
        <p>Apart from its integrated monophonic Aftertouch, seven further monophonic <span data-keyword="Hardware"> Sources</span> can be used in performance. (The entire modulation mechanism is currently monophonic.) These are: the <span data-keyword="Bender"></span>, two <span data-keyword="Ribbons"></span> (see above) and four external <span data-keyword="Pedals"></span> (as shown below: a continuous pedal and a switching pedal) can all be integrated into the system for expressive play.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Pedals (continuous, switching)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/physical-controls/pedals.jpg"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>While performing, notes can be played (on the Keybed) and movements made (with the Hardware Sources) to bring motion and variation into your sound.</p>
        <p>The eight Hardware Sources are the first of three modulation stages. They gather the user's performance input and distribute the hardware source movements to the six <span data-keyword="Macro"> Controls</span>. The Hardware Sources work in various ways, depending on the behavior and settings of the individual sources.</p>
        <p>These are detailed in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-04-hw-sources.html" data-number="5.4">Using Hardware Sources</a>.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<html lang="en">

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-03-macro-controls">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-03-macro-controls.html" data-number="3.3">Macro Controls</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3.3">Macro Controls</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Macro Controls">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/physical-controls/macro-group.jpg"></picture>
            </figure>
            <div class="section">
                <p>Since version <span class="sw-version">20-28</span>, there are six additional parameters that don't have any connection or effect by default. These are the <span data-keyword="Macro"> Controls</span>, and they represent the second of three modulation stages.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <p>The Macro Controls are modulated by the <span data-keyword="Hardware"> Sources</span>, whereas the synthesis engine parameters themselves are modulated by the Macro Controls. The Macro Controls can thus be seen as the hub of the modulation mechanism, which distribute the control movements of the Hardware Sources to the synthesis engine's parameters.</p>
        <p>
            The function of a <span data-keyword="Macro"> Control</span> is defined by the sound designer. It acts as a primary tool for varying the sound, as Macro Controls are both interactive (they can be edited) and performant (they can be modulated by the <span data-keyword="Hardware"> Sources</span>).
        </p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-04-parameters">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-04-parameters.html" data-number="3.4">Parameters</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3.4">Parameters</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Parameters">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/panels/param-panel-3.svg"></picture>
            </figure>
            <div class="section">
                <p>Items that are relevant for synthesis are called <span data-keyword="Parameters"></span> and are organized in <span data-keyword="Parameter"> Groups</span>. Each group combines all parameters relating to a given synthesis engine process (such as an envelope).</p>
                <p>Some parameters are integrated into the modulation mechanism and can be referred to as <span data-keyword="Modulation"> Targets</span>.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <p>Currently, there are 286 parameters, organized into 21 groups, and 105 of these parameters act as modulation targets.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <!-- standard meta -->
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <!-- page title -->
    <title>User Manual - 03.5. Modulation Scheme</title>
    <!-- noscript fallback -->
    <noscript>
        <meta http-equiv="refresh" content="0;url=../../../_noscript.html">
    </noscript>
    <!-- url base -->
    <base href="../../../" target="_top">

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-05-modulation-scheme">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-05-modulation-scheme.html" data-number="3.5">Modulation Scheme</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3.5">Modulation Scheme</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Modulation Scheme">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-mod-scheme-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>The modulation mechanism translates the movements made by the performer (using the Hardware Sources) into movements of the parameters, thus increasing the variation and expression of the preset being used.</p>
        <p>The C15 does not have automatic modulation processes (like LFOs - with the exception of the <span data-keyword="Flanger"></span>): all modulating movements are made by the performer.</p>
        <p>In the sound engine, almost all parameters operate as smoothers. The <span data-keyword="Smoothing"> Time</span> depends on the instrument's settings and the operational context. The <span data-keyword="Edit"> Smoothing Time</span> applies for adjusting parameters, the <span data-keyword="Transition"> Time</span> for preset recalls and the <span data-keyword="Macro Control"> Smoothing Time</span> for modulations.</p>
        <p>In a given preset, the flow of movements is defined by several <span data-keyword="Amount"></span> parameters, which weight the amount and direction of a particular movement. Each <span data-keyword="Hardware"> Source</span> features a separate amount for each <span data-keyword="Macro"> Control</span>. Multiple Hardware Sources can be used to control any given Macro Control. The <span data-keyword="Target"> parameters</span> have an MC selector and modulation amount, thus completing the routing of modulations. Any given Target parameter can only be affected by one Macro Control.</p>
        <p>How Hardware Sources affect Macro Controls essentially depends on the type and settings of the source in question, so it is hard to make any general statement. But how Macro Controls affect target parameters is governed by general rules. The modulation aspects of a parameter are defined in relation to both the Macro Control in question and the parameter, as neither of them changes when modulation amounts are edited.</p>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Parameter Modulation">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-mod-unclipped-*.png"></picture>
                <figcaption>fig. 1</figcaption>
            </figure>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Parameter Clipping">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-mod-clipped-*.png"></picture>
                <figcaption>fig. 2</figcaption>
            </figure>
        </div>
        <p>The modulation amounts define the range within which target parameters move when the corresponding Macro Controls are moved. As neither the Macro Controls nor the target parameters change in position, the amounts always reflect the positions of the Macro Controls within the modulation range <i>(fig. 1)</i>.</p>
        <p>There may be cases in which the modulation range exceeds the parameter range: this is also known as virtual overdrive. When a modulation moves a parameter out of its operational range, it remains at the corresponding limit (clipped) until the modulation returns to within the parameter range again <i>(fig. 2)</i>.</p>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Parameter Polarity">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-mod-polarity-*.png"></picture>
                <figcaption>fig. 3</figcaption>
            </figure>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Parameter Scaling">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-mod-scaling-*.png"></picture>
                <figcaption>fig. 4</figcaption>
            </figure>
        </div>
        <p>If we compare unipolar and bipolar target parameters <i>(fig. 3)</i>, it is clear that the full modulation range (-100% ... 100%) of bipolar parameters is effectively twice the modulation range (0% ... 100%) of unipolar parameters.</p>
        <p>When a target parameter has linear scaling, the modulation amount can be displayed in the same format as the parameter's unit of measurement. Target parameters with nonlinear scaling display the modulation amount as a percentage <i>(fig. 4)</i>.</p>
        <p>Use this interactive <a href="./documents/illustrations/parameter-modulation.html">Modulation Scheme</a> for a better understanding of the modulation mechanism.</p>
        <p>More information about Hardware Sources and the modulation mechanism can be found in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-04-hw-sources.html" data-number="5.4">Using Hardware Sources</a>. The section <q>Modulation Aspects</q> explains the current standard setting, which is commonly used in the factory presets.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-06-presets">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-00-0-basic-concepts.html" data-number="3">Basic Concepts</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/03-basic-concepts/03-06-presets.html" data-number="3.6">Presets</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3.6">Presets</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>The current sound can be stored as a preset at any time for later use. Presets are organized into banks, so that each preset has a unique path (bank number/preset number). Some other aspects of presets are explained as follows:</p>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th>Preset Name</th>
                <td>
                    <p>Each preset can be given a unique user-definable name. When you store a preset, you will be prompted to name it. You can change the name of the preset at any time.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Preset Number</th>
                <td>
                    <p>Each preset has a certain position in its bank. This position and the bank number are combined to define a unique number for the preset, which displays on each user interface. For example, the unique number <q>1-001</q> refers to the first preset in the first bank.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Preset Type<br><i style="font-weight: normal;">(since <span class="sw-version">20-28</span>)</i></th>
                <td>
                    <p>The <span data-keyword="Sound"> Type</span> (Single, Split, Layer) will be stored and associated with the preset. It will be indicated for Split (&#xE0F2;) and Layer (&#xE0F5;) types.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Preset Info</th>
                <td>
                    <p>Each preset contains a small set of metadata, most of which are defined automatiocally when you store the preset. Besides the device name, the software version and the time stamp, some elements can be defined by the user: You can edit the name of a preset, set its position in its bank, assign it a color tag and set a comment text. The comment text can be used to describe the sound and give performance instructions.</p>
                    <p>In addition, the preset comment text will be checked when you search for presets using keywords. This works especially well when keywords are defined as tags with the hashtag symbol <q><code>#</code></q>.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
        </table>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3>Change Recognition</h3>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Change Recognition">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/preset/boled-pre-change-rec.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <div>
                <p>When you change a loaded preset, the system recognizes the change and indicates this by appending an asterisk (<code>*</code>) to the unique preset number. When you store a preset after making changes to it, the system considers it to be a new preset, unless you force it to overwrite an existing preset.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <p>More information about dealing with changes to loaded presets can be found in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-10-overviews.html" data-number="4.10">Overviews</a>.</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Note that modulations, which change parameters, are considered to be preset changes.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="3.7">Organization</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>All accessible items on the C15 are organized into functional groups. Parameters are grouped according to their functional relations as part of the synthesis engine, the <span data-keyword="Hardware"> Sources</span> and <span data-keyword="Macro"> Controls</span> are grouped next to each other, and other items are organized into menu structures.</p>
        <p>
            The <span data-keyword="Hardware"> User Interface</span> (consisting of the <span data-keyword="Base"> Unit</span> and <span data-keyword="Panel"> Unit</span>) gives quick access to all parameters. Most parameters are organised in groups, as reflected on the <span data-keyword="Parameter"> Panels</span>. However, not every parameter can be accessed with a single click, as several parameters may be stacked behind one <span data-keyword="Parameter"> Selection Button</span>. Furthermore, a few parameter groups (Master, Part, Unison, Mono) can only be accessed via the <span data-keyword="Sound"> Button</span>.
        </p>
        <p>
            In the <span data-keyword="Graphical"> User Interface</span>, every parameter and every bank is shown in the main area. This requires physical space to display all the necessary information, and some screens may not be large enough or sufficiently high resolution to do so. These limitations are dealt with by zooming into and out of the display, which is a crucial aspect of working with the Graphical User Interface, as different levels of detail emerge at different zoom levels.
        </p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
