<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-16-graphical-ui-functionality/04-16-5-gui-settings">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-00-user-interfaces.html" data-number="4">User Interfaces</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-16-0-graphical-ui-functionality.html" data-number="4.16">Graphical UI Functionality</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-16-4-gui-context-menus.html" data-number="4.16.5">GUI Settings</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="4.16.5">GUI Settings</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup Window">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-gui-setings.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <div>
                <p>There are some options concerning only the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span>. They are provided in the <span data-keyword="Setup">Menu</span>, which can be called via the topright <span data-keyword="View"></span> menu icon. These settings are not available on the <span data-keyword="Hardware">User Interface</span>.</p>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div data-columns="1">
            <table>
                <tr>
                    <th>Selection Auto Scroll</th>
                    <td>Determine if selected items should be automatically scrolled to. Available options are <code><b>Off</b></code>, <code><b>Parameter</b></code>, <code><b>Preset</b></code> and both (<code><b>Parameter and Preset</b></code>).</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Edit Parameter</th>
                    <td>Determine if parameters can be directly adjusted in the main area. Available options are <code><b>Always</b></code>, <code><b>If Selected</b></code> and <code><b>Never</b></code>. In the <span data-keyword="Parameter">Tab</span>, edits are always possible.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Highlight Changed Parameters</th>
                    <td>Determines, if parameters which have been changed are highlighted by yellow frames.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Context Menus</th>
                    <td>Determine if context menus are available in the main area. They can be invoked by a right-click or a long touch gesture. Available options are <code><b>On</b></code> and <code><b>Off</b></code>.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Preset Drag and Drop</th>
                    <td>Determine if presets can be moved in the main area by drag and drop gestures. Available options are <code><b>On</b></code> and <code><b>Off</b></code>.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Display Scaling Factor</th>
                    <td>Should the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span> appear too small or big for the device screen resolution, this option can compensate. Available scaling factors are <code><b>50%</b></code>, <code><b>75%</b></code>, <code><b>100%</b></code>, <code><b>125%</b></code> and <code><b>150%</b></code>.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Stripe Brightness</th>
                    <td>The main area background features a radial arrangement of lines pointing to the center position. They can help keeping track of the current position. Available options are <code><b>Off</b></code>, <code><b>10%</b></code>, <code><b>25%</b></code> and <code><b>50%</b></code>.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Bitmap Cache</th>
                    <td>Determine how objects of the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span> should be redrawn. Available options are <code><b>On</b></code> and <code><b>Off</b></code>. If the bitmap cache is activated, CPU consumption on the device will decrease, but more RAM will be required. If the cache is deactivated, CPU consumption will rise but RAM usage will decrease. The effect of this settings strongly depends on the external device.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Show Developer Options</th>
                    <td>There are some more options (beyond the usual interaction with the C15) that are not relevant for the user, but can be important for developers (when testing a device or running diagnostics of possible malfunctions). Therefore, the Developer Options can remain hidden in usual circumstances. If they are displayed, they can be found way above the parameters in the main area. We recommend to simply ignore these options.</td>
                </tr>
            </table>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</h2>
        <p>The C15’s first synthesis engine is named <q>Phase 22</q>. It can be seen as the latest stage of an ongoing, long-time development, combining and advancing experiences gained from precursor projects like Spark, Prism, Skanner and Kontour (available for Native Instruments’ acclaimed Reaktor series).</p>
        <p>There has been a steady evolution and optimization of the overall architecture and signal flow, as well as the modulation mechanism and feedback structures. This process will continue, further refining and advancing the synthesis engine.</p>
        <div>
            <p><a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-01-concept.html" data-number="5.1">Concept</a></p>
            <p><a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a></p>
            <p><a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-03-dual-mode-sig-flow.html" data-number="5.3">Dual Mode Signal Flow</a></p>
            <p><a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-04-hw-sources.html" data-number="5.4">Using Hardware Sources</a></p>
        </div>
        <p>For a detailed reference of all parameters see chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/11-parameter-reference/11-00-parameter-reference.html" data-number="11">Parameter Reference</a></p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>

        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">Synthesis Engine</a>

        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-01-concept.html" data-number="5.1">Concept</a>
    </label>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.1">Concept</h2>
        <p>The main design goal for the <q>Phase 22</q> project is to exploit digital synthesis algorithms in order to build a highly responsive and expressively playable instrument with a strong individual character. At the same time, the set of parameters should be small enough to be easily accessible. It is intended to harness complexity by a reduced, minimalistic engine architecture, avoiding multi-mode switches for multiple waveforms or selectable filter and effect types. Furthermore, (almost) all parameters of the synth engine are designed to be continuous and time-variant in order to produce smooth transitions between sounds and increasing the overall sensitivity of the instrument.</p>
        <p>The core structure is a phase modulation synth that is based on two sine oscillators and two sine shapers only (phase modulation is closely related to frequency modulation aka <q>FM</q>). The combination of an Oscillator and its Envelope can be understood as a classical FM operator. Together with a Shaper and a Feedback injection point it forms one of the two <q>branches</q>. The signals from Branch A and B can be passed through the Comb Filter, the State Variable Filter or directly to the Output Mixer.</p>
        <p>The Comb Filter is a tool for complex spectral shaping and also works as a resonator, the State Variable Filter can be applied for subtractive filtering. Signal routing is determined by both the Output Mixer (defining the mix being passed to the effect section) and the Feedback Mixer (defining the mix for flexibly applicable feedback loops).</p>
        <p>Both filters and the effects have a profound impact on the feedback behavior, their amplitude and phase responses determine the frequencies where the feedback can result in self oscillation. In fact, the feedback bus is a unique and versatile feature of the synth engine, raising the perceived acoustic complexity of a sound (if taken use of).</p>
        <p>On the other hand, the engine is also capable of producing classical subtractive and FM sounds, so a wide spectrum and variety of sounds can be produced.</p>
        <p>The combination of the components can also be understood in a physical modeling sense, as the branches can function as exciters for the Comb Filter as a resonator, while the State Variable Filter and the effect chain work as an acoustic body, amplifier and spatial setting at once.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

        <h2 data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</h2>
            <p>The overall signal flow of the synthesis engine is illustrated in the following diagram. For a more detailed version <a href="./documents/illustrations/synth-engine-simplified.html">click here</a>.</p>

            <p>The links below provide further information about particular components. (You can access the same subpages by clicking in the blue frames in the diagram).</p>

                <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-1-envelopes.html">Envelopes</a> |

            <p>Two Oscillators and Shapers produce signals which are passed to the Comb Filter, to the State Variable Filter, and to the Output Mixer. The filter output signals are also connected to this mixer. The resulting mix is passed to the effect section and finally to the output. A second mix from the filters and effects is defined for the Feedback bus.</p>
            <p>There is a symmetric approach for the Oscillators, Shapers and Envelopes. Envelope A, Oscillator A and Shaper A (also called <q>branch A</q>) are quasi-identical to Envelope B, Oscillator B and Shaper B (<q>branch B</q>). Envelope C can be mapped to the filters, pitches, and feedback amounts.</p>
</section>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-1-envelopes.html" data-number="5.2.1">Envelopes</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.1">Envelopes</h2>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Envelopes A, B">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/envelope-ab-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Envelope C">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/envelope-c-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Envelope C (Retrigger Hardness)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/envelope-c-retrigger-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>The primary purpose of the envelopes is to create modulation signals according to played keys. Their most crucial applications are certainly the amplitudes (peak levels) of the oscillators, which is predefined. So the amplitude of Oscillator A directly depends on the signal of Envelope A, as the amplitude of Oscillator B directly depends on the signal of Envelope B. Besides, there are other targets which can be influenced by the envelopes according to modulation amount parameters. They are referred to in the following sections.</p>
        <p>In total, there are four envelope signals to be taken use of. Three of them are flexibly definable, as provided by three parameter groups called Envelope A, B and C. Whereas Envelopes A and B are applyable in the two branches (Oscillators and Shapers), Envelope C can be used more globally for the modulations of pitches, cutoff frequencies, resonances or feedback levels. In addition, a non-parametric Gate signal is produced and applied for feedback control and the decay of the Comb Filter.</p>
        <p>The Gate signal is a very simple envelope that jumps to 100% intensity when a key is pressed. When this key is released, the signal drops back to zero within a few milliseconds.</p>
        <p>The signals of the other three envelopes are way more advanced. Lots of parameters define the behavior of each envelope, including variable sensitivities to the velocities and pitches of played notes.</p>
        <p>For a particular envelope (A, B or C), there are four consecutive segments defining the signal progression. When a key is pressed, the signal starts by rising from (usually) zero to the peak level within the Attack time. The peak level can depend on the key-down velocity, whereas the time can range between zero and 16 seconds and also can depend on the key-down velocity (shortening it for higher velocities). The Attack curve is linear by default but can be tweaked to get a concave or convex shape. With a concave shape it starts with a smaller slope and gets steeper, with a convex shape it is the opposite. The time and curve of the Attack segment determine the perceived sharpness of the beginning tone.</p>
        <p>When the signal has reached the peak level, a new transition to the Breakpoint level (between zero and the peak level) will begin. This segment will be active within the given Decay 1 time (also between zero and 16 seconds). It will impact the early evolution of the produced tone. The first two segments determine the start transients, which are important for the perceived character of a sound.</p>
        <p>When the signal has reached the Breakpoint level, the Decay 2 segment will become effective. Within a given time, the segment will exponentially approach the Sustain level (between zero and the peak level as well). The Sustain level defines how much the perceived tone will persist at a stationary level while holding the corresponding key. High Sustain levels are typical for pad and organ sounds, for example. If the Sustain level is low or zero, a percussive tone character will emerge, with the Decay 2 time controlling if it sounds shorter or longer. The Sustain level will hold as long as the key remains pressed.</p>
        <p>The final segment, called the Release phase will become effective as soon as the corresponding key is released. Within a given time the signal approaches zero exponentially. Regardless of the perceived loudness of the tone up to now, it will disappear by fading out. Similar to the Attack segment, the Release time can be sensitive to the key-up velocity.</p>
        <p>As explained, the key velocities can influence the perceived loudness of the tone as well as the speed of its start and demise. In addition, the Key Tracking parameters determine how much the key position influences both the levels and times of the envelope segments.</p>
        <p>In conclusion, an Envelope group can model quite a lot of different tonal processes with varying degrees of realism. It can produce spiky impulses as well as long, complicated and seemingly artificial contours. All parameters, but especially the timing are highly precise and their sensitivities to the performing user can be carefully defined as well.</p>
        <p>Finally, three more aspects are quite worth mentioning. Whereas the times of the first two segments (Attack, Decay 1) are well defined by (finite) transitions, the remaining two segments (Decay 2, Release) approach their destinations exponentially. This means, the signal takes an asymptotical path towards a specific value, but actually never reaches it. In order to define the speed of this infinite process by a particular time, the definition is as following: When the signal drops from 100% towards zero (as described for the Gate signal), after the given time the signal will be at approximately 37% still. This relationship may sound arbitrary or random, but actually reflects countless natural processes (like the behavior of a plucked string).</p>
        <p>Secondly and up to now, all three Envelope groups (A, B, C) have been described at once. A major difference of Envelope C as a global modulation source is, that its Breakpoint and Sustain levels are bipolar. This renders Envelope C more versatile and can make tonal evolutions even more complex.</p>
        <p>At last, another note on the Release segment in the context of the modulation mechanism. All segment times are represented as modulation target parameters, so they can be influenced by the Macro Controls. And whereas the times of the first three segments can be precisely tuned between zero and 16 seconds, the Release Time (target) parameter can be further set to infinite, allowing the Release segment to <q>freeze</q>. This allows for the integration of a <q>Sustain Pedal</q>, modulating the Release time up to infinity while holding it.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Envelope Examples (Shapes)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/envelopes-examples_2-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <h3>Envelope Amounts</h3>
        <p>The oscillator and shaper groups feature several envelope amount parameters. They can be understood as an additional multiplier for the corresponding main parameter value. This multiplier blends between a constant signal of one and the corresponding envelope signal, as the pictures below illustrate.</p>
        <p>As a result, the corresponding main parameter can be blended by the amount parameter between its pure value and a fully modulated version (by the corresponding envelope). On the other hand, for pitch-related parameters (Oscillators, Comb Filter, State Variable Filter) and the State Variable Filter resonance, the associated envelope amount parameters simply weight the corresponding envelope signals, before being added to the main parameter value.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Envelope Examples (Amounts)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/envelopes-examples_3-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>

    </section>
</main>
</div>

    </label>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.10">Gap Filter</h2>
        <p>The Gap Filter marks the third effect and provides further filtering of the signal. It consists of two four-pole filters (with a damping slope of 24 dB per octave) which can run in parallel or in series. The filter types are static, as the first filter is a highpass, followed by the second (lowpass) filter.</p>
        <p>The filter frequencies can be determined by a <q>Center</q> frequency, which can be spread in the stereo field and shifted by the <q>Gap</q> parameter, creating an offset between the high- and lowpass filters. The filter resonance can be adjusted as well, creating two resonance peaks in the signal spectrum.</p>
        <p>Both filter outputs can be blended by a Balance parameter, defining a crossfade mix of the two components.</p>
        <p>The bipolar Mix parameter determines the amount of filtering in the resulting signal, crossfading the input signal with the filtered signal. Positive mix values mean that the filter components run in parallel, resulting in a band-reject behavior. Negative values produce a bandpass effect, as the filter components are running in series.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Gap Filter">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/gapfilter-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Gap Filter (Details)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/gapfilter-dia-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

    </label>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.11">Echo</h2>
        <p>The fourth effect is a stereo delay, providing a spatial effect of repeating echoes. The delay time can be adjusted and spreaded between the left and right channel.</p>
        <p>Within the local feedback, a tunable lowpass filter allows for damping, and the feedback level can be defined by an amount and a cross-feedback (feeding one channel back to the other and vice versa). The echo can be blended into the mix by an adjustable amount parameter.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Echo">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/echo-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.12">Reverb</h2>
        <p>Finally, the signal is passed to the Reverb unit, providing another spatial effect in terms of hall, room or reverberation.</p>
        <p>The Size parameter determines how long it takes for a signal to fade out, which has a profound impact on the perceived room size. A Pre Delay parameter can also have a strong influence in the size perception.</p>
        <p>The local feedback behavior is determined by a Color parameter, affecting its brightness and a Chorus parameter which can lead to a less static feedback behavior.</p>
        <p>The Reverb signal can be blended into the mix by a separate amount parameter.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Reverb">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/reverb-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
    </section>
</main>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-sig-flow-components/05-02-13-main-parameters">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-13-main-parameters.html" data-number="5.2.13">Main Parameter Groups and Post Processing</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.13">Main Parameter Groups and Post Processing</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary">Master Group</h3>
        <h4 class="heading secondary">Volume and Tune</h4>
        <p>Besides the Master Volume, the Master group also contains a Master Tune parameter which can shift the whole tuning of the instrument by up to 48 semitones in both directions.</p>
        <h4 class="heading secondary">Scale</h4>
        <p>The Scale group allows for redefining the scale of the instrument, which is the equal temperament by default. The Base Key of a scale can be defined and all 12 keys of the corresponding octave can have an individual offset (up to 800.0 cents - eight semitones - in both directions) to the equal temperament. So a variety of different scales is achievable, including historical and traditional settings, pentatonic scalings or exotic and experimental types.</p>	
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Scale (equal tuning/temperament)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/scale-equal-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Scale (individual tuning/temperament)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/scale-micro-offset-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary">Voices Group</h3>
        <p>The voicing behavior of a preset is defined by the Mono and Unison parameter groups.</p>
        <p>In <span data-keyword="Single">Sounds</span>, these groups are present once and apply for all available 24 voices. In <span data-keyword="Split">Sounds</span>, these groups are present twice (per <span data-keyword="Part"></span>) and apply for all 12 voices of that Part. In <span data-keyword="Layer">Sounds</span>, these groups are present once and apply for all 12 voices of both <span data-keyword="Parts"></span> simultaneously.</p>
        <h4 class="heading secondary">Mono</h4>
        <p>When Mono is enabled, played keys will affect only one voice (or voice cluster, when using Unison). The behavior is defined by four parameters:</p>
        <div data-columns="1">
            <table>
                <tr>
                    <th>
                        <p><span data-keyword="Enable"></span></p>
                        <p><i style="font-weight: normal;">(On, Off)</i></p>
                    </th>
                    <td>
                        <div class="section">
                            <p>When on, only one note (containing the defined number of Unison Voices) will be playable, even when multiple keys are pressed. As long as one key stays pressed, the release of a key will not stop the envelopes.</p>
                            <div data-highlight="note">
                                <p>Note that changes to Mono Enable will reset held keys.</p>
                            </div>
                        </div>
                    </td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>
                        <p><span data-keyword="Priority"></span></p>
                        <p><i style="font-weight: normal;">(Lowest, Latest, Highest)</i></p>
                    </th>
                    <td>When hitting multiple keys, they are sorted by the chosen priority. Keys matching the chosen priority determine the pitch of the Mono voice. When releasing the priorized key, the pitch will be determined by the key with second closest priority match.</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>
                        <p><span data-keyword="Glide Time"></span></p>
                        <p><i style="font-weight: normal;">(0.0 ms ... 16000 ms)</i></p>
                    </th>
                    <td>This time can be used to create a portamento by smoothing the transitions of the pitches. Depending on the Legato options the smoothing is applied to each pitch change or only when the keys are played in <q>legato</q> style (in an overlapping manner).</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>
                        <p><span data-keyword="Legato"></span></p>
                        <p><i style="font-weight: normal;">(None, Envelopes, Glide, Env & Glide)</i></p>
                    </th>
                    <td>
                        <dl class="info">
                            <dt><span data-keyword>None</span></dt>
                            <dd>No difference between legato and non-legato playing. The envelopes will be retriggered by every key-down and the Glide parameter will be applied to every pitch step.</dd>
                            <dt><span data-keyword>Env</span></dt>
                            <dd>The envelopes will be retriggered only by key-downs that are played non-legato. The Glide parameter will be applied to every pitch step.</dd>
                            <dt><span data-keyword>Glide</span></dt>
                            <dd>The Glide parameter will be applied only to keys that are played legato. The envelopes will be retriggered by every key-down.</dd>
                            <dt><span data-keyword>Env & Glide</span></dt>
                            <dd>The envelopes will be retriggered only by key-downs that are played non-legato. The Glide parameter will be applied only to keys that are played legato.</dd>
                        </dl>
                    </td>
                </tr>
            </table>
        </div>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>The new <q>Reset</q> parameter of the Oscillators (accessed via the <q>Phase</q> <span data-keyword="Parameter Selection">Button</span>) can be set to Off to avoid glitches caused by the oscillator phases being reset at a key-down. They become noticeable if the Release phase of the Envelopes is longer than the time between two notes. Without the phase reset the Oscillators are <q>free-running</q> and the Phase parameter has no influence on the start phase. This will also affect the sound of unison voice stacks and will effectively disable the Unison Phase parameter.</p>
        </div>
        <h4 class="heading secondary">Unison</h4>
        <p>The Unison group provides additional control and allows for unison voices (more than one sounding voice per pressed key). The number of unison voices can be adjusted (one by default). Three spread parameters can determine, how each unison voice is spread against the others: Detune can spread the pitches, Phase can spread the oscillator start phases and Pan can spread the panning of individual unison voices.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Post Processing</h3>
        <p>The resulting signal (a mixture of the Output Mix and the Effects section) can be amplified or attenuated by the Master Volume parameter, before it passes through a soft clipper, preventing the signal from being clipped at the D/A converter.</p>
        <!-- recorder, test tone ? -->
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-2-oscillators.html" data-number="5.2.2">Oscillators</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.2">Oscillators</h2>
        <p>The branches A and B both contain an Oscillator – a source for a sine-wave signal.</p>
        <p>The perceived sound of a sine wave is rather simple, as there is just the fundamental, which is detected by the ear as a pitch. It lacks any further harmonics or partials in general, so the perceived sound is devoid of any timbre.</p>
        <p>By phase modulation, wave shaping or ring modulation, new partial tones can be created. The resulting waveforms and spectra can vary enormously and evolve over time. This is the foundation of a sound that later can be further manipulated by the two filters.</p>
        <p>When a key is pressed, each oscillator synchronizes to a particular start phase. This allows both oscillators to run in or out of phase up to the point, where they will cancel each other out. Besides, when using unison, the individual tones can have an individual phase offset as well. If the start phase of an oscillator is not zero, it will not start at the zero-crossing of the sine wave. With short Attack times, a clicking will be noticeable, as sharp transients can occur in that scenario.</p>
        <p>The frequency of an oscillator (the number of oscillations per second) is represented as a Pitch parameter, providing the familiar format of semitones and cents. The influence of the position of a pressed key can be weighted by the Key Tracking parameter, adding to the basic tuning of the oscillator. At 100% Key Tracking, the Oscillator pitch directly corresponds to the keyboard. However, there are other possible influences on the pitch as a modulation target, typically by the Bender. Envelope C can shift the pitch as well.</p>
        <p>By taking use of the Scale group, the pitches of played notes can even be set to different scalings apart from the familiar equidistant temperament of modern western music. If using unison in addition, a cluster of voices will sound where the Spread parameter can stretch the individual pitches apart from one another.</p>
        <p>Even each oscillation cycle can vary in frequency, as provided by a Fluctuation parameter. When Fluctuation is used, each cycle will have a random offset to the basic frequency. This converts the simple sine-wave to a band-limited noise. At high amounts, the oscillator frequency can randomly vary between 5% and 195% per cycle, which leads to a very irregular behavior and a wide-band spectrum. The Fluctuation can also be affected by Envelope C.</p>
        <p>In order to manipulate both harmonics and noisiness of the sine wave, phase modulation (<q>PM</q>, often also referred to as <q>FM</q>) can be exploited, as each Oscillator provides several parameters dedicated to define the complex relations of intermodulations.</p>
        <p>Basically, if a slow <q>modulator</q> signal modulates the phase of another fast and tonal <q>carrier</q> signal, the perceived frequency of the fast signal will change over time, increasing or decreasing the perceived pitch. The faster the modulator signal becomes, the faster the frequency of the carrier signal will change. If both signals are periodical, new perceived frequencies may emerge and others may disappear.</p>
        <p>In general, strong and bright spectra can emerge. The produced sounds can be harmonic and tonal (if the ratios of the Oscillator frequencies can be expressed by fractions of small integer numbers) as well as noisy and atonal (like a metallic character, emerging from non-harmonic partials). This strongly depends on relations that both involved oscillators would have, like their frequency ratios and amounts of phase modulation.</p>
        <div data-columns="1">
            <table>
                <tr>
                    <th>
                        <div>Difference <sup>1)</sup></div>
                    </th>
                    <td>0</td>
                    <td>3.87</td>
                    <td>4.98</td>
                    <td>7.02</td>
                    <td>12</td>
                    <td>14.04</td>
                    <td>15.87</td>
                    <td>19.02</td>
                    <td>21.69</td>
                    <td>24</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>
                        <div>Ratio <sup>2)</sup></div>
                    </th>
                    <td>1/1</td>
                    <td>5/4</td>
                    <td>4/3</td>
                    <td>3/2</td>
                    <td>2/1</td>
                    <td>9/4</td>
                    <td>5/2</td>
                    <td>3/1</td>
                    <td>7/2</td>
                    <td>4/1</td>
                </tr>
            </table>
        </div>
        <p><b>1)</b> tuning difference (in semitones) between Oscillator A and B<br /><b>2)</b> emerging Ratio</p>
        <p>More specifically, three modulation sources can be used in parallel for each Oscillator. Self modulation allows a particular oscillator to feed its own signal back, adding to its phase. This leads to a saw-like appearance of the oscillator signal and a brighter sound, depending on the modulation amount. The corresponding parameter is bipolar, affecting the direction of the saw curve. The corresponding shaper signal can be crossfaded into the modulation signal, further affecting the spectrum of the resulting oscillator signal. The corresponding Envelope can also be applied on the amount.</p>
        <p>The phase progression of a particular Oscillator can also be affected by the opposite branch (and vice versa). Similar to self modulation, the amount can be set, the branch shaper signal can be crossfaded and the branch envelope can shape the intensity. This allows for complex intermodulations and elevates each Oscillator to function as both a carrier and a modulator simultaneously.</p>
        <p>The third phase modulation source is the global Feedback bus, being defined by the Feedback Mixer. The amount can be defined and Envelope C can shape the intensity as well. As the feedback signal can consist of polyphonic and monophonic parts, intermodulations between several (parallel) voices can occur. In most cases, phase modulation by feedback rapidly leads to noisy behavior.</p>
        <p>After all phase modulation sources were weighted and added, their sum will be fed to a tunable but static lowpass <q>Chirp</q> filter. This can reduce aliasing effects or chaotic noisiness, when phase modulation is used excessively.</p>
        <p>The bipolar nature of many of the involved parameters further raises the complexity and lowers the predictability of the system as a whole. The intricate feedback network can be seen as a textbook definition of a <q>chaotic system</q>.</p>
        <h3>1. Oscillator Phase Modulation</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Oscillators (Phase Modulation)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/osc-1-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <h3>2. Oscillator Fluctuation</h3>        
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Oscillators (Fluctuation)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/osc-fluct-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>

    </section>
</main>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-3-shapers.html" data-number="5.2.3">Shapers</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.3">Shapers</h2>
        <p>Each of the two branches is completed by a sine shaper unit, which can further manipulate the oscillator signal and enhance its spectrum. It also allows for the integration of the global feedback and a ring modulation signal.</p>
        <p>The sine shaping mechanism can be compared to the computation of an oscillator signal, which is derived from a continuously growing phase that is folded over and over again, thus becoming periodical. From the periodical, wrapped phase signal, a sine approximation can be calculated.</p>
        <p>Within a sine shaper, the input signal is first amplified by a Drive parameter, which can be sensitive to the corresponding branch envelope. Afterwards, it will be interpreted as a phase signal that will be folded. The resulting signal could be broadly described as the <q>sine of a sine</q>.</p>
        <p>Certain overtones will emerge in proportion to the Drive level. The folding characteristic can be blended from a soft clipping behavior by a Fold parameter. With no fold present, the shaper effect resembles more a distortion or saturation effect, producing different harmonics.</p>
        <p>Furthermore, an Asymmetry parameter can shift the fundamental frequency by one octave. The resulting shaped signal can be crossfaded with the input signal by a bipolar Mix amount (as previously mentioned, the bipolar nature of lots of signal components can raise the complexity when using phase modulations or feedback).</p>
        <p>Two more signals can be blended into the mix. The feedback signal can be fed into a branch, the amount can be sensitive to Envelope C (blendable with the Gate signal). With the application of feedback, the global Feedback loop will be closed to some extent (depending on further settings).</p>
        <p>Finally, the two branch signals are multiplied and each branch can blend to the <q>Ring Modulation</q> signal by a certain amount. Ring modulation produces interesting patterns in the resulting spectrum, depending on the two incoming signals. Symmetrical frequency components emerge (one with the difference of the incoming frequencies, one with the sum of the incoming frequencies).</p>
        <p>Concludingly, the Shaper is another versatile module providing different ways to manipulate an oscillator signal. Distortion effects are as possible as sine shaping, and feedback and ring modulation can be applied. The shaper not only affects the signal of a branch, but can also be blended onto phase modulation sources for the oscillators.</p>
        <p class="developer">For a better understanding, have a look at the interactive <a class="label">Shaper Basics Page</a>.</p>
        <h4>1. The first set of diagrams shows how the <q>Drive</q> parameter is influencing the audio signal (0 dB &hellip; 16 dB)</h4>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Shapers (Drive)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/shaper_drive-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <h4>2. The second set of diagrams shows how the <q>Fold</q> parameter is influencing the audio signal (0 % &hellip; 100 %)</h4>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Shapers (Fold)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/shaper_fold-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <h4>3. The third set of diagrams shows how the <q>Asymmetry</q> parameter is influencing the audio signal (0 % &hellip; 100 %)</h4>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Shapers (Asymmetry)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/shaper_asym-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>

    </section>
</main>
</div>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-sig-flow-components/05-02-4-comb-filter">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-4-comb-filter.html" data-number="5.2.4">Comb Filter</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.4">Comb Filter</h2>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Comb Filter">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/comb-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>The branch signals (A, B) are provided as sources for two different filter units, the first of which is the <q>Comb Filter</q>. It is an accurately tunable delay with a versatile local feedback loop, fed by an adjustable crossfade mix of both branch signals.</p>
        <p>The term <q>Comb</q> describes the effect of a signal being combined with a delayed version of itself, leading to phase interferences (which can be constructive or destructive, mainly depending on the delay time). Certain harmonics of the input signal can be amplified or canceled, so the spectrum is affected.</p>
        <p>Furthermore, the term <q>tunable</q> refers to the relationship between the delay time of signal repetitions and a perceived tonal frequency, which emerges when the delay time is sufficiently small (smaller times produce higher frequencies, as usual). The <q>Pitch</q> parameter of the Comb Filter can be sensitive to Key Tracking and the influence of Envelope C.</p>
        <p>The delayed signal is passed to the local feedback branch, which includes two filter components. At first, a two pole allpass filter is applied, which has a tunable frequency which can be sensitive to Key Tracking and the influence of Envelope C and a resonance. Allpass filters do not affect the amplitudes of certain frequency components (as high- or lowpass filters do), but they will affect the phases of these components, which are comparable to individual delay times. Below the (center) frequency, the phase shift is minimal (zero), rising to 180 degrees at the frequency and then to 360 degrees above the frequency. The Resonance parameter defines the slope of that shift. This mechanism has a profound effect on the signal spectrum, as it can both create and destroy harmonic signal components.</p>
        <p>The allpass filter is followed by a lowpass filter, damping higher frequency components according to a tunable pitch parameter which can be sensitive to Key Tracking and the influence of Envelope C. The damping effect is closely related to acoustic processes (as substances like air have this property). It also affects the persistence of the local feedback.</p>
        <p>The amount of feedback determines how long it takes for the feedback to disappear after the input signal has faded out. This exponential process is referred to as the <q>Decay Time</q>, which can be sensitive to Key Tracking (modeling a tendency some musical instruments possess, like strings tend to dampen faster with higher notes).</p>
        <p>The Decay parameter is bipolar, as negative feedback amounts can cancel every second repetition, effectively tuning the signal down by one octave. The signal of the Gate envelope can also be applied to the local feedback loop, reducing the amount to a certain degree when a key is released (so the Comb Filter feedback only remains for sustained notes).</p>
        <p>The delay time can additionally be modulated by a crossfade mix of both branches, determined by a <q>Phase Modulation</q> parameter (as mentioned, in certain scenarios, delay times and phases can closely relate).</p>
        <p>So in a general sense, the Comb Filter can act as a tunable, delay based resonator that can strongly alter the spectrum of the incoming signal due to its integrated allpass filter.</p>
        <p>The following diagram shows a simplified frequency response for the Comb Filter. Consider a tonal signal (with a clear fundamental frequency) which feeds the Comb Filter. The Comb Filter output is added to the signal (upper graph) or subtracted from the signal (lower graph).</p>
        <p>Both graphs show the typical, generalized frequency response of a comb effect, as shown by the periodical peaks. The width of the peaks depends on the Comb Filter's pitch parameter (equivalent to a delay time), meaning that certain signal frequency components will be attenuated and other components will be amplified, depending on the delay time.</p>
        <p>In addition, when subtracting the Comb Filter signal from the incoming signal, the peaks are shifted, and the emerging comb tone will be lowered by one octave.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Comb Filter (Inverted Mix)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/comb-dia-1-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Comb Filter (Allpass)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/allpass-phase-response-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Comb Filter (Partials)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/allpass-effect-comb-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>

    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-5-state-variable-filter.html" data-number="5.2.5">State Variable Filter</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.5">State Variable Filter</h2>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="State Variable Filter">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/svf-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>The second applyable filter to the branches is called the <q>State Variable Filter</q>, a tool for multifunctional subtractive filtering that is fed by an adjustable crossfade mix of both branch signals. The Comb Filter can be faded into the input mix as well.</p>
        <p>The State Variable Filter consists of two two-pole filters with blendable characteristics (lowpass, bandpass, highpass) which can operate in parallel or in series by a continuously adjustable amount. In serial mode, the damping slope can be raised from 12 to 24 dB per octave (becoming a four-pole filter effectively). In parallel applications, the filters can also be used to create two formants (useful for vowel-like sounds).</p>
        <p>The filter frequencies are determined by a tunable center frequency which can be sensitive to Key Tracking and the influence of Envelope C. A Spread parameter determines how much the individual filter frequencies are shifted apart from the center frequency. With no spreading, one peak emerges at the center frequency. The strength of the peak depends on the filter resonance, which also can be sensitive to Key Tracking and the influence of Envelope C. When spreading is applied, the peak splits into two peaks, weakening strong resonances and creating formants.</p>
        <p>The filter type can be continuously blended between an overall lowpass, bandpass and highpass behavior. In serial mode with a negative spreading, a band-rejecting (notch) behavior can be achieved as well.</p>
        <p>A crossfade mix of both branches can also be applied for frequency modulation. Parallel behavior can be produced in two ways, by either adding or subtracting the second filter to/from the first. Subtraction will lead to phase cancellations.</p>
        <p>In conclusion, the State Variable Filter is a versatile subtractive filter capable of creating formants and different characteristics.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="State Variable Filter (Details 1)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/svf-dia-1-p1-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="State Variable Filter (Details 2)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/svf-dia-1-p2-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>

    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.6">Feedback Mixer</h2>
        <p>The global feedback signal, usable for phase modulation and within the Shapers, is defined by a mix of four signals provided by the two filters and the Effects section (blendable between pre and post Reverb). Each signal is weighted by a bipolar Amount parameter, as the polarity can have a noticeable influence on the feedback behavior.</p>
        <p>A sine shaper (providing Drive, Fold and Asymmetry, as described for the branch Shapers) can manipulate the sum signal and create additional harmonics. The sum also can be amplified or damped by a Level parameter that can be sensitive to Key Tracking.</p>
        <p>The feedback signal will be a mixture of polyphonic signals (provided by the filters) and monophonic signals (provided by the effects, having no more voice association and being a downmix of the original stereo signal).</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Feedback Mixer">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/fbmix-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Feedback Signal Flow">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/single-sig-flow-s-fbk-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>

    </section>
</main>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.7">Output Mixer</h2>
        <p>The (main) output signal, being passed to the Effects section, is defined by a stereo mix of four signals provided by the two branches (A, B) and the two filters (Comb, SVF). Each signal can be weighted by a bipolar amount and positioned in the stereo field by a panning parameter.</p>
        <p>A sine shaper (providing Drive, Fold and Asymmetry, as described for the branch shapers) can manipulate the sum signal and create additional harmonics. The sum also can be amplified or damped by a Level parameter. The key position of a note can also be applied for the tone's position in the stereo field by a <q>Key Pan</q> parameter.</p>
        <p>After the output mixer, the signal will be monophonic (the sum of all voices) and at the same time dual channel (with stereo spreading).</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Output Mixer">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/outmix-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
    </section>
</main>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-8-flanger.html" data-number="5.2.8">Flanger</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.8">Flanger</h2>
        <p>The first effect is a dynamic stereo delay capable of producing chorus-, phaser- or flanger-like sounds. Its basic mechanism can be compared to the Comb Filter, although the Flanger is not sensitive to Key Tracking. The usual sweeping effect arises when the delay time is changing (due to modulations), as the delayed signal is combined with the input signal and changing harmonics are created.</p>
        <p>As the delay times are relatively short, this effect is not able to create wide spatial effects, but a certain perception of depth will emerge nevertheless. The delay time can be spread for both channels with a <q>Stereo</q> parameter.</p>
        <p>The local delay feedback bus consists of two filters, the first of which is an allpass filter with a tunable frequency, affecting the phases of the signal’s frequency components. The second filter is a one-pole lowpass filter with tunable frequency, damping the feedback signal. The feedback level can be determined by an amount parameter and as this is a stereo effect, cross feedback can be applied as well, feeding some amount of a signal from one channel to the other (and vice versa).</p>
        <p>Modulation sources for the Flanger are provided by a stereo LFO (with adjustable Rate and stereo Phase offset) and a simple (monophonic) envelope signal (immediately jumping to the key velocity and then exponentially approaching zero within a time corresponding to the Rate parameter). The envelope will start with a key when no keys are priorly pressed (in <span data-keyword="Split">Sounds</span>, pressed keys are determined for each <span data-keyword="Part"></span> individually). A crossfade of the two sources can be applied as modulation for the delay time and for the allpass filter frequency independantly.</p>
        <p>Finally, the Flanger signal can be blended into the mix by a bipolar Mix parameter, as the signal polarity can have a strong effect when using the global feedback signal.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Flanger">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/flanger-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>

        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">The Synthesis Engine</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-0-sig-flow-components.html" data-number="5.2">Signal Flow and Components</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-02-9-cabinet.html" data-number="5.2.9">Cabinet</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.2.9">Cabinet</h2>
        <p>The second effect is called <q>Cabinet</q>, providing the possibility to further shape the signal in terms of saturation, overdrive and distortion. It can be regarded as a basic amp simulator.</p>
        <p>A sine shaper (providing Drive, Fold and Asymmetry, as described for the branch Shapers) is the central element of this effect, allowing for the creation of new harmonics to the signal.</p>
        <p>Before and after the actual shaping, filtering is applied in order to further manipulate the distortion effect. The signal passes through a highpass filter with adjustable frequency (cutting low signal components) before being fed into the shaper. After the shaping, a lowpass filter with adjustable frequency determines the amount of high signal components (boosted by the distortion).</p>
        <p>A Tilt parameter has a further influence on the signal spectrum before and after the shaping, as it can emphasize either low or high signal components that will be affected by the shaper.</p>
        <p>The shaped signal can be amplified by a separate <q>Cab Level</q> parameter, before being crossfaded with the input signal by the Mix parameter.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Cabinet">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/cabinet-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-03-dual-mode-sig-flow">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-00-synth-engine.html" data-number="5">Synthesis Engine</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-03-dual-mode-sig-flow.html" data-number="5.3">Dual Mode Signal Flow</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.3">Dual Mode Signal Flow</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Recap: Parameter Organization</h3>
        <p>As explained in <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-01-parameter-organization.html" data-number="4.1">Parameter Organization</a>, the C15 Synthesis Engine is divided into distinct <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Sections"></span> that operate differently according to the current <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Sound">Type</span>:</p>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th colspan="2"><span class="keyword" data-keyword="Global">Section</span></th>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td class="section" colspan="2">
                    <p>Global parameters are present once within a Preset of any <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Sound">Type</span> and form the global section, including <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Hardware">Sources</span> and their corresponding <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Hardware">Amounts</span>, <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Macro">Controls</span> and their corresponding <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Macro">Times</span> as well as the <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Master">Group</span> (containing Volume, Tune and Scale parameters).</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th colspan="2"><span class="keyword" data-keyword="Local">Sections</span></th>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Voicegroup<br>(poly)</th>
                <td class="section" >
                    <p>Parameters bound to polyphonic components (Envelopes A/B/C, Oscillators A/B, Shapers A/B, Comb and State Variable Filters, Feedback and Output Mixers) are present once for <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Single">Sounds</span> and twice for <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Split"></span> or <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Layer">Sounds</span> and form one (single) or two (dual) Voicegroups.</p>
                    <p>In the Feedback Mixer, there are special parameters facilitating polyphonic cross feedback between both <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Parts"></span> (A-B, A-B From I/II, Comb From I/II, SVF From I/II) that are only available in <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Layer">Sounds</span>.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Effects<br>(mono)</th>
                <td>Parameters bound to monophonic components (Flanger, Cabinet, Gap Filter, Echo, Reverb) also are present once for <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Single">Sounds</span> and twice for <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Split"></span> or <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Layer">Sounds</span> and form one (single) or two (dual) effect chains.</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <th>Part</th>
                <td>In <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Split"></span> or <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Layer">Sounds</span>, each Voicegroup and corresponding effect chain is bound to a Part component with additional Volume and Tune parameters.</td>
            </tr>
        </table>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Dual Sounds - Main Signal Flow</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Dual Mode Signal Flow (main)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/dual-sig-flow-s-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>The shown chart can be described as follows:</p>
        <ol>
            <li>The Output Mixer's main stereo signal of a particular Voicegroup is passed to the FX distributor, sending the signal to both Effect sections with different levels (similar to stereo panning of a mono signal).</li>
            <li>The Reverb's stereo output signal of a particular effect chain is then passed to the Part component, where the Part Volume is applied.</li>
            <li>Both Parts will then be added and passed to the global Master Volume for final gain control.</li>
        </ol>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Layer Sounds - Detailed Signal Flow</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Layer Mode Signal Flow (detailed)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/dual-sig-flow-m-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>With <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Layer">Sounds</span>, the emerging additional details of the shown chart can be described as follows:</p>
        <ol>
            <li>The Feedback Mixer of a particular Voicegroup can apply polyphonic self/cross feedback (cross: from the other Voicegroup), allowing signals from the Oscillators A/B as well as the Comb and State Variable Filters to be sent inbetween.</li>
            <li>The output of a particular effect chain provides an additional dry and wet signal (being downmixes of the stereo Reverb input and output signals). These signals are then sent back to each Voicegroup's Feedback Mixer for applying monophonic self/cross feedback.</li>
        </ol>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
