<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5.4">Using Hardware Sources</h2>
        <h3 class="heading">General Aspects</h3>
        <p>The eight <span data-keyword="Hardware">Sources</span> of the C15 can be seen as special controllers, which are designed for live performance. While playing a certain sound, the Hardware Sources can be used for modulations, changing the sound character.</p>
        <p>Four different types of Hardware Sources are provided, each type having its individual aspects (four <span data-keyword="Pedals"></span>, two <span data-keyword="Ribbons"></span>, one <span data-keyword="Bender"></span>, one <span data-keyword="Aftertouch"></span>). As for the (external) pedals, their aspects strongly depend on the type of pedal that is used. The following section contemplates all relevant aspects of Hardware Sources and external controllers in general.</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <h4><span class="sw-version normal">21-26</span> MIDI</h4>
            <p>The eight Hardware Sources are capable of receiving and sending MIDI messages, allowing for external control. For more information, please refer to chapter <a class="label" href="./documents/man-user/07-midi/07-00-midi.html" data-number="7">MIDI</a>.</p>
        </div>
        <h3 class="heading">Continuity</h3>
        <p>Controllers can essentially behave in two different manners. There are switches (like a <q>Sustain Pedal</q>) and there are continuous controllers (like a <q>Volume Pedal</q>). Although continuous behavior may be preferred in most use cases and can be seen as a general recommendation, switches can also be used when integrating external pedals (providing only two states: on and off). All four integrated Hardware Sources are continuous.</p>
        <h3 class="heading">Directionality and Polarity</h3>
        <p>Controllers with a switch behavior can behave in two different manners as well. There are opener switches (like a <q>Sustain Pedal</q>) and there are closer switches (like a <q>Mute Pedal</q> or <q>Damping Pedal</q>). The difference between these two types is the direction they are taking: opener switches go from minimum to maximum, closer switches operate in a reversed manner. Commonly (but misleadingly) this is referred to as <q>Pedal Polarity</q>. However, regardless of the direction of a controller, it can be integrated and directions can be manipulated by modulation amounts.</p>
        <p>Continuous controllers, on the other hand, can be unipolar (the usual case, providing one direction of possible movement: up or down) or bipolar (like a <q>Pitch Bender</q>, providing two directions of movement: up and down).</p>
        <h3 class="heading">Return Behavior</h3>
        <p>Some controllers (like a <q>Sustain Pedal</q> or a <q>Pitch Bender</q>) return to a certain position after using them (usually, the position would be zero or the center), whereas other controllers may remain at their position after releasing them. Controllers that are returning to their center position usually are bipolar (and the center position equals zero in this case). The return behavior affects the type of modulation amount of the corresponding Hardware Source, which can be either continuous (for a returning Hardware Source) or switch-like (for non-returning Hardware Sources, providing only <q>on</q> and <q>off</q>).</p>
        <h4>Direct and Additive Behavior</h4>
        <p>For the Pedals and Ribbons, the user can set the <span data-keyword="Return">Behavior</span> of the Hardware Source (<code>Non-Return</code>, <code>Return to Center</code>, <span data-detail="Pedal exclusive"><code>Return to Zero</code></span>). The non-returning and returning modes differ primarily in what is called <span data-keyword="Direct"></span> and <span data-keyword="Additive">Behavior</span>.</p>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th data-detail="Non-Return">Direct Behavior</th>
                <th data-detail="Return To Zero, Return To Center">Additive Behavior</th>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td class="section">
                    <p>In non-returning mode the value of the <span data-keyword="Hardware">Source</span> is transferred directly to the assigned <span data-keyword="Macro">Control</span>. This is especially important if two or more non returning Hardware Sources are assigned to one Marco Control.</p>
                    <p>The value then corresponds absolutely to the value of the last moved Hardware Source.</p>
                    <p>In the case of non-returning Ribbons, they can only affect one Macro Control exclusively and will be linked to it, which means that both Ribbon and Macro Control essentially act as one parameter (changes to either element are reflected in both).</p>
                </td>
                <td class="section">
                    <p>In contrast, returning Hardware Sources possess <span data-keyword="Additive">Behavior</span> and do not set the Macro Control absolutely to their respective value, but instead add their value to the Macro Control value.</p>
                    <p>A weighting factor (<span data-keyword="Hardware">Amount</span>) can be set here, which determines to which percentage the value of the Hardware Source is transferred to the Macro Control.</p>
                    <p>With this additive behavior several returning Hardware Sources can be combined in such a way that they do not interfere with each other in simultaneous use, instead all movements are combined. For interesting pitch modulations, <span data-keyword="Bender"></span> and <span data-keyword="Aftertouch"></span> can be combined in this way, for example.</p>
                </td>
            </tr>
        </table>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <h4>Changing the Return Behavior</h4>
            <p>When switching a <span data-keyword="Hardware">Source</span> from non-returning to returning behavior, keep in mind that the position of the Hardware Source no longer necessarily corresponds to the position of the assigned Macro Control. This is especially important for the <span data-keyword="Ribbons"></span>. While the Ribbons in the non-returning mode are bidirectionally connected to the assigned Macro Control and thus always show the actual Macro Control position, this is no longer the case in the returning mode.</p>
            <p>Here the Ribbon shows the value that is transferred to the Macro Control additively. If the returning Ribbon is in the center position, this does not necessarily mean that the assigned Macro Control is also set to its center as you would expect in non returning mode. The position and therefore the center/zero position of the Macro Control depends on any other Hardware Sources connected to the Macro Control or any setting made via the <span data-keyword="Graphical"></span> or <span data-keyword="Hardware">User Interface</span>.</p>
        </div>
        <h3 class="heading"><span class="sw-version normal">22-16</span> Integration and Recall Behavior</h3>
        <div data-highlight="comment">
            <p>In earlier versions, different Hardware Sources behaved differently when recalling a new Preset. When recalling while using Hardware Sources, a well-defined behavior was not guaranteed, so we recommended leaving the Hardware Sources untouched when loading a new Preset.</p>
            <p>In addition, only the two integrated Ribbons were able to successfully load their states in a Preset recall, if in Non-Return mode. Returning Hardware Sources did lead to unwanted effects, if differing from their return position when loading a Preset.</p>
            <p>On the other hand, the (external) pedals could (and still can) not be affected by loading new Presets. So, they could be at an unexpected position and produce a jumping behavior when used.</p>
        </div>
        <p>The recall behavior of Hardware Sources has been reworked, fixing long-known problems and better integrating the MIDI functionality. The Return Behavior of a particular Hardware Source still is part of a Preset and may change when loading a Preset. However, the positions of Hardware Sources are no longer part of a Preset, they instead remain in their arbitrary positions when Presets are loaded <sup>(1.)</sup>. Even when a Return Behavior changed, the Hardware Source position will persist <sup>(1.)</sup>.</p>
        <p class="footnote" data-number="1">except for non-returning Ribbons</p>
        <h4>Returning Hardware Sources</h4>
        <p>When the Preset is loaded, the position of a returning Hardware Source will be reflected on associated Macro Controls. When the returning Source stays untouched in its return position (the usual case), every load of the same Preset will look and sound identical. When the returning Source is in an arbitrary position, loading the same Preset will look and sound different, depending on the current position.</p>
        <h4>Non-Returning Pedals</h4>
        <p>When the Preset is loaded, the position of a non-returning Pedal will be ignored by associated Macro Controls. Loading the same Preset will look and sound the same. The Pedal and Macro are likely to differ in their positions. With the next movement of the Pedal, the Macro will jump to the next position and both Pedal and Macro positions are synchronized again.</p>
        <h4>Non-Returning Ribbons</h4>
        <p>When the Preset is loaded, the position of a non-returning Ribbon will be overwritten by the associated Macro Control (if present). Loading the same Preset will look and sound the same. Both Ribbon and Macro positions remain synchronized throughout.</p>
        <h3 class="heading">Additional Settings</h3>
        <p>There are more settings provided for each Hardware Source in the Setup menu, depending on the type of source. The Bender and Aftertouch provide a curve, weighting the movements, whereas the Ribbons provide a <q>Relative Factor</q>, amplifying movements on the Ribbons when using relative mode.</p>
        <h3 class="heading">Operation Modes</h3>
        <p>Except for the Ribbons, all Hardware Sources operate in absolute mode. Ribbons on the other hand, can operate in both absolute and relative mode (the relative mode can amplify drag gestures on the Ribbon).</p>
        <h3 class="heading">Functionality Overview</h3>
        <p>All the mentioned different aspects of Hardware Sources are shown in the following table:</p>
        <div data-columns="1">
            <table style="text-align: center;">
                <tr>
                    <th>Source</th>
                    <th>Pedal 1 ... 4</th>
                    <th>Bender</th>
                    <th>Aftertouch</th>
                    <th>Ribon 1, 2</th>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Continuity</th>
                    <td>continuous/switch</td>
                    <td colspan="4">continous</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Polarity</th>
                    <td>unipolar/bipolar</td>
                    <td>bipolar</td>
                    <td>unipolar</td>
                    <td>unipolar/bipolar</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>
                        <p>Return</p>
                        <p>Behavior</p>
                    </th>
                    <td>non/zero/center</td>
                    <td>center</td>
                    <td>zero</td>
                    <td>non/center</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Integration</th>
                    <td>external</td>
                    <td colspan="3">integrated</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>
                        <p><span class="sw-version">22-16</span> Recall</p>
                        <p>Behavior</p>
                    </th>
                    <td colspan="4">
                        <dl class="info">
                            <dt>returning Sources</dt>
                            <dd>The Preset will load reflecting the returning HW Source in its current (arbitrary) position, so the resulting state and sound depends on where the Source currently is.</dd>
                            <dt>non-returning Pedals</dt>
                            <dd>The Preset will load ignoring the non-returning Pedals. In most cases, associated Macro Controls will differ in their position. Once the Pedal is moved, the Macro Control will jump to the next Pedal position and both positions will be synchronized again.</dd>
                            <dt>non-returning Ribbons</dt>
                            <dd colspan="4">The Preset will load overwriting the non-returning Ribbons, if they are associated to a Macro Control.</dd>
                        </dl>
                    </td>
                    <!-- <td>no</td>
                    <td colspan="2">n/a</td>
                    <td>yes</td> -->
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>Settings</th>
                    <td>Pedal Preset (Pin Assignment)</td>
                    <td colspan="2">Curve</td>
                    <td>Relative Factor</td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <th>
                        <p>Operation</p>
                        <p>Mode</p>
                    </th>
                    <td colspan="3">absolute</td>
                    <td>absolute/relative</td>
                </tr>
            </table>
        </div>
        <h3 class="heading">Pedal Integration</h3>
        <p>For now, the safe and recommended method of integrating external pedals is to turn the device off beforehand. After all pedals are plugged in the provided sockets, the C15 can be switched on again. The booting process will recognize the pedals' circuit architectures and integrate them accordingly.</p>
        <p>There is a Setup menu provided as well, in which the pin assignment of each pedal can be set manually. However, this menu should only be used if the pin assignment of a pedal is known, as wrong assignments can easily lead to overheating, possibly causing permanent damage on the device. Besides, the menu is still in development and proper functionality is not guaranteed for now.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Pedal (Pin details)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-pedal-trs-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <h3 class="heading">Modulation Aspects</h3>
        <p>As already mentioned, the modulation amount of a certain Hardware Source on a Macro Control depends on the source’s Return Behavior (only returning sources allow for a continuous amount).</p>
        <p>Furthermore, when a non-returning Ribbon is assigned to a Macro Control, the assignment will be bidirectional. In other words, the Ribbon will move the Macro Control and vice versa. For a better understanding, have a look at this interactive <a href="./documents/illustrations/parameter-modulation.html">diagram</a>.</p>
        <p>Considering the Hardware Sources, their current settings and the modulation amounts on Macro Controls alltogether, they can be referred to as a <q>Modulation Template</q>. All included settings will be stored and recalled with presets, but for different use cases (like different pedals on another device), the template may not work properly. We plan to further investigate on template functionalities (like import and export functions) and may offer solutions in the near future.</p>
        <p>For the sound design (and included factory presets) so far, the following template appeared to be meaningful, and it can be found in most of the presets:</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Hardware Sources (standard routing)">
            <picture class="content" data-src="images/web-ui/parameter/webui-hw-src-group.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>The template defines two non-returning, continuous Pedals (1 and 2) for Macro Controls A and B, which are used to modulate different sound aspects like phase modulation intensities, filter frequencies, resonances or effect amounts, for example. Similarly, the two Ribbons are mapped on the two Macro Controls as well.</p>
        <p>In addition, Macro Control C is assigned to the Bender and primarily used for bending pitches. The remaining Macro Control D is assigned to a returning, continuous Pedal (4), which serves as a Sustain or Damper Pedal (depending on the sound).</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">

        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="6">Recorder</h2>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Recorder - Signal Flow">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/recorder-sig-flow-m-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        
        <h3 class="heading">General Function</h3>
        <p>The internal recorder enables you to capture the C15's output signal with the best possible audio quality at any time, without connecting a sound card. The stereo signal behind the Soft Clipper and before the D/A converter is written to the RAM, using the lossless compression of the FLAC format (24 bits, 48 kHz).</p>
        <p>A maximum of 500 MB can be stored in the RAM. Because of the FLAC compression this is enough for hours of permanent playing and for days of recording when there are pauses in the playing. If the recorded amount of data exceeds the limit of 500 MB, the oldest data will be overwritten. Therefore it works like a ring buffer that always contains the latest recording.</p>
        <p>The content of the RAM will be lost, when you switch off the C15. You can select a segment of the recorded audio and download it to your computer to use it in your production environment. The recorded audio can be downloaded in both the FLAC and WAV format.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Recorder Settings - Auto-Start</h3>
        <p>In the Setup you find a new page for <q>Recorder</q> settings. With the option <q>Auto-Start Recorder</q> the user can decide if the audio recording starts automatically when the C15 is switched on, or if the user has to start it by the Record button.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup window - Recorder">
            <picture class="content" data-src="images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-recorder.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - Recorder">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-recorder.png"></picture>
        </figure>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">User Interface</h3>
        <p>The Recorder tab can be opened by the <q>Open Recorder</q> entry in the <q>View</q> menu. The tab has the address: <code style="color: var(--theme-heading-color);">http://192.168.8.2/recorder/index.html</code></p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Recorder UI">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/recorder/webui-recorder.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>The recorder works independent from its browser tab being open or not.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Zoom and Scroll</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Scrollbar">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/recorder/webui-recorder-scroll.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Zoom icons">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/recorder/webui-recorder-zoom.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>At the bottom of the recorder display you find a dark stripe representing the whole length of the audio recording that is in the memory. It is the frame for a bar that is used for scrolling and zooming. By holding the bar in its grey center area and dragging it, you shift the visible section of the recorded audio, which means that the display content is scrolled. By the two handles at the ends of the bar you can change its length and therefore the zoom factor.</p>
        <p>The two buttons with magnifier <q>+</q> and <q>-</q> icons and the mouse wheel respectively the <q>+</q> and <q>-</q> buttons of your computer keyboard can also be used to zoom in and out.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Control Buttons</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Control Buttons">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/recorder/webui-recorder-controls.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>Restore  -  Play/Pause  -  Record  -  Download  -  Delete</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Computer Keyboard Shortcuts</h3>
        <table>
            <tr>
                <th>Command</th>
                <th>Shortcut</th>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>Play / Pause</td>
                <td>space bar</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>Record</td>
                <td>R</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>Restore</td>
                <td>Z</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>Download</td>
                <td>S</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>Zoom In / Out</td>
                <td>+ / -</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>Scroll</td>
                <td>left / right arrow keys</td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td>To Previous/Net Preset Marker</td>
                <td>up / down arrow keys (coming soon)</td>
            </tr>
        </table>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Playing Back Recorded Audio</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Play Cursor">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/recorder/webui-recorder-playback.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>The C15 can play back the recorded audio through its outputs. The playback start position is set by a click/touch in the darker outer lanes of the recorder display. A green line - the Play cursor - shows the position. A time label is attached.</p>
        <p>When the Play button is pressed, the Play cursor starts to move and the recorded audio is played back. The button gets a <q>Pause</q> symbol and can be used to interrupt and continue the playback. Alternatively you can press the space bar for toggling between Play and Pause.</p>
        <p>You can play the C15 live while the playback is running, but please be aware that the sum of the two signals can cause clipping distortion.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Restoring a Sound</h3>
        <p>The Undo system of the C15 memorizes every user action on parameters or presets. It allows to go back to the state of the synth engine at any point in time since the start of the session. Therefore it is possible to restore the sound at a certain position on the timeline of the Recorder and to use the same state of the synth engine as it was at the time of recording.</p>
        <p>For this you move the Play cursor to the point in time of which you want to restore the sound and press the Restore button or the Z key on your keyboard. The Undo System will go back to the state of the parameters at the selected point in time, takes a <q>snapshot</q> of them and copies it into the editbuffer.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Preset Labels</h3>
        <p>Please note that the selection and load status of a preset cannot be restored because the preset might have been changed, moved or deleted.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Preset Labels">
           <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/recorder/webui-recorder-labels.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>In order to not loose the information which presets were used, the Recorder creates a label when a preset is loaded. The left end of the label is aligned to the loading time. The label contains the number and name of the bank and the preset. This might have changed in the meantime, but often it can still be found under the same name at the same place.</p>
        <p>To be on the safe side we recommend to create copies of the banks that contain important presets by using the <q>Export</q> command.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Selecting a Segment for Download</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Selection and Download">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/recorder/webui-recorder-download-segment.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <p>By click/touch and drag in the inner lane you can select a time segment. The start and end points can be shifted by the two light-blue handles. Two labels are showing the times at the start and end points.</p>
        <p>The selected part can be downloaded by pressing the Download button or <q>S</q> on the computer keyboard. A dialog opens in which you can change the file name and choose between FLAC and WAV format (24 bit, 48 kHz). If the browser is set to ask for the destination for the downloaded file, it will open the referring dialog now. Otherwise it will store the file in the standard download folder.</p>
        <p>The selection can be disabled by a single click/touch in the inner lane.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Starting and Stopping the Recording</h3>
        <p>If the <q>Auto-Start Recorder</q> option in the Recorder Settings is <q>On</q> the Record button will be shown as active from the beginning. You can use it to stop the recording. This might be desired to save memory or to focus on reviewing the recorded material. When you press the button again the recording will be continued.</p>
        <p>If the <q>Auto-Start Recorder</q> option is <q>Off</q>, the Record button needs to be pressed to start recording.</p>
        <p>The keyboard shortcut for starting or stopping the recording is R.</p> 
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Deleting the Recorded Audio</h3>
        <p>When you press the Delete button the audio memory will be cleared and as a result the timeline will be empty.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

    </label>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="7">The MIDI Implementation of the C15</h2>
        <p>Since the Studio Package update the C15 can receive and send MIDI messages. Received MIDI messages can control the C15 and affect the sound, similar to playing the instrument itself. When playing on the C15, MIDI messages can be sent, reflecting the performance. Note that received MIDI messages will never be sent, so there is no <q>MIDI Thru</q> or loopback functionality.</p>
        <p>Receive and Send options include a Channel (Omni, 1 ... 16) specifier, filtering events accordingly. When a Split Sound is loaded, a secondary (Split) Channel can be used in order to separate both Parts from each other.</p>
        <p>As classical MIDI operates on 7 bit resolution (128 steps), there is a loss in accuracy (the C15 operates on much higher precision). Nevertheless, precision can be maintained by enabling <q>High Res.</q> options. When enabled, the resolution increases to 14 bit (16384 steps). Values are then encoded as a pair of MSB (coarse) and LSB (fine) components, effectively doubling the amount of messages. This is still compatible with the classical resolution, as the LSB component is optional when receiving MIDI messages.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/07-midi/07-01-midi-events">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/07-midi/07-00-midi.html" data-number="7">MIDI</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/07-midi/07-01-midi-events.html" data-number="7.1">MIDI Events</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="7.1">MIDI Events</h3>
        <p>The C15 can send and receive MIDI messages for the following events:</p>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Note On and Note Off</h3>
        <p>When enabled, the C15 will produce sounds when receiving MIDI Note messages. Likewise, the C15 will send MIDI Note messages when playing on the internal keybed, if enabled. Note On and Off velocities are supported and can optionally operate on high resolution, using an additional MIDI CC (Control Change) message on Control Number 88, encoding the LSB component.</p>
        <p>When a Split Sound is loaded, Notes can be received and sent on both Parts, using the secondary (Split) Channel setting.</p>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">The eight Hardware Sources</h3>
        <p>Physical control elements of the C15 like a pedal or the bender are called Hardware Sources. They can be flexibly mapped to the Macro Controls, each of which can modulate up to 90 assignable parameters.</p>
        <p>In the C15's user interface the Hardware Sources are represented by eight sliders. Their positions can be sent and received via MIDI in the following way:</p>
        
        <ul>
            <li>Pedal 1/2/3/4 can be assigned to MIDI CCs 01...31 for the MSB while CC 33...63 can work as LSB for 14 bit resolution. CC 64...69 can be assigned in a 2-state switching mode.</li>
            <li>Ribbon 1/2 can be assigned to MIDI CC 01...31 for the MSB while CC 33...63 can work as LSB for 14 bit resolution.</li>
            <li>The Bender can be assigned to MIDI Pitchbend or to MIDI CC 01...31 for the MSB while CC 33...63 can work as LSB for 14 bit resolution.</li>
            <li>Aftertouch can be assigned to MIDI Channel Pressure or to MIDI CC 01...31 for the MSB while CC 33...63 can work as LSB for 14 bit resolution, or to one half of the range of MIDI</li> 
            <li>Pitchbend (up or down).</li>
        </ul>
        
        <div data-highlight="note">Note that assignments are non-exclusive, so multiple Hardware Sources can be bound to the same received MIDI message, as well as being merged into indistinguishable MIDI messages when sent. This may be useful in certain scenarios, so there are no restrictions. However, it is up to the user to find a meaningful setting, apart from the provided default setting, consisting of distinct assignments.</div>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Preset Selection</h3>
        <p>One of the Preset Banks can be assigned to receive and send MIDI Program Changes. The Program Change numbers are mapped to the first 128 presets of this Bank.</p>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/07-midi/07-00-midi.html" data-number="7">MIDI</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/07-midi/07-02-midi-usb.html" data-number="7.2">Connecting the C15 to a USB Device</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="7.2">Connecting the C15 to a USB Device</h3>
        <p>The C15 has a Type A connector for USB, and its embedded computer system works as a <q>USB host</q> for <q>USB devices</q> connected to this port. This means that you only need a standard USB cable to set up a MIDI communication with an instrument, a hardware sequencer, or a MIDI interface that has a USB Type B connector. You can connect the C15 to multiple USB MIDI devices via a USB hub.</p>
        
        <div data-highlight="warn">Important: The USB port of the C15 can only supply a limited current to bus-powered devices. Devices that have a higher power consumption need to be run with their own power supply, or through a powered hub.</div>

        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Connecting C15 with USB Device">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-midi-connect-usb-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Connecting the C15 via 5-pole DIN Connectors</h3>
        <p>To use the classical MIDI cables and 5-pin DIN Ins and Outs a MIDI interface can be connected as an USB device directly to the USB port of the C15. The most convenient and cost effective solution are cables with integrated USB-MIDI interface.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Connecting 5-pole DIN Connectors">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-midi-connect-5pin-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Connecting the C15 to a Computer</h3>
        <p>A computer running a DAW or similar is the center of many setups. It functions as a USB host and can only be connected to USB devices. Since the C15 is also a USB host we provide the <q>MIDI Bridge</q> that functions as a double-sided USB device with two Type B connectors. One of the ports is connected to the C15 and the second to your computer.</p>
        <p>Our adapter will appear as <q>NLL-MIDI-Bridge</q> in the list of USB MIDI devices. The two LEDs on top of the box show the operation of the two USB Ports. If both are lit in green color the box is working normal. If one of the LEDs ist not green, the connection to its side is interrupted. More information about the operation of the MIDI Bridge can be found in the <a href="./documents/man-midi-bridge/index.html" class="label">MIDI Bridge Manual</a>.</p>
        <p>Besides its function for the C15 the MIDI bridge can also be used for the MIDI connection between other USB hosts, like two computers.</p>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="C15 - MIDI Bridge - Computer">
            <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-midi-connect-daw-*.png"></picture>
        </figure>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/07-midi/07-03-midi-settings">
<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/07-midi/07-00-midi.html" data-number="7">MIDI</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/07-midi/07-03-midi-settings.html" data-number="7.3">MIDI Settings</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="7.3">MIDI Settings</h3>
        <div data-columns="2">
            <div class="section">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup window - MIDI Settings">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-settings.png"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <div class="section">
                <p>In the Setup (both in the <span data-keyword="Graphical"></span> and <span data-keyword="Hardware">UI</span>) you find a new page for <q>MIDI Settings</q>. It is divided into the sections <q>Channels</q>, <q>Assignments</q> and <q>Routings</q>. Furthermore, you find direct access to <q>Panic</q>, <q>Local Enable</q> and <q>Program Change Bank</q> at the very top of the settings page.</p>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI Settings">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-settings.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Local enable">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-local.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Channels">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-channels.png"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
        </div>
        <div class="section">
            <h4>Panic</h4>
            <p>When triggered, the C15's Voice Allocation, Envelopes and Buffer will be reset and an <q>All Notes Off</q> MIDI message will be send on the respective channel(s). As a result, all internal audio and external gear will stop playing. A common method to face stuck MIDI notes, but it also can be helpful, when you lost control of the sound, e.g. through a feedback loop.</p>
            <p>Panic can also be triggered by pressing all four soft buttons on the base unit at the same time.</p>
            
            <h4>Local Enable</h4>
            <p>When set to <q>Off</q>, both the C15's keyboard and the eight Hardware Sources are disconnected from the synth engine but still can be used to send MIDI note and Control Change, Pitchbend or Channel Pressure messages.</p>
            <p>In this mode the base unit display is not showing the associated Macro Control, but the MIDI-CC number assigned to the Ribbons instead.</p>
            
            <div data-highlight="note">Please note that changing this setting while a note is active resets the voice allocation, the envelopes and the buffer of the C15, so that the audio playback is interrupted for a brief moment. In this case, a MIDI All Notes Off message is also sent on the respective channel(s).</div>

            <p><i>Next to this shorthand option, Local Enable modes are individually available for Notes and all eight Hardware Sources, see below (7.3.3 MIDI Settings: Routings).</i></p>
            
            <h4>Program Change Bank</h4>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup Window - MIDI - Program Change Bank">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-pc-bank.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Program Change Bank">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-pc-bank.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>Here you can assign the Preset Bank that is used for sending and receiving MIDI Program Change messages. By selecting <q>None</q>, no MIDI Program Change messages will be received or sent. Please see the next subchapter <q>Choosing a Bank for MIDI Program Change</q> for choosing a Preset Bank directly from the preset view.</p> 
            <div data-highlight="note">Please note, that every time you change the Program Change Bank, a corresponding MIDI message is sent.</div>
            
            <h4>Choosing a Bank for MIDI Program Change</h4>
            <p>To make use of MIDI Program Change messages one of the C15's preset banks has to be assigned as the source and target of Program Changes. A received Program Change would select the preset with the referring number in this bank and the selection of a new preset in the bank will send a MIDI Program Change with its number. Selecting a preset that has a higher number than 128 will not send a Program Change.</p>
            <p>The <q>Direct Load</q> switch decides if the C15 only sends a MIDI Program Change when you select a preset, or if the preset is also loaded into the sound engine. Therefore it has a similar effect like a <q>Local Off</q> for Program Changes.</p>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Bank Program Change Indicators (Graphical UI)">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/preset/webui-pre-bank-midi-pc.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Bank Program Change Indocators (Hardware UI)">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/hardware-ui/boled/preset/boled-soled-pre-bank-midi-pc.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>The header of the MIDI-assigned bank is marked by a symbol that looks like a 5-pole MIDI connector. The bank can be connected or disconnected in the following ways:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>In the graphical UI you find the entry <q>Connect Bank to MIDI PC</q> or <q>Disconnect Bank from MIDI PC</q> in the context menu of the bank header.</li>
                <li>In the Preset Screen of the Hardware UI activate the <q>Bank</q> focus by pressing the <span data-keyword="Soft Button">1</span> (with a dual preset hold the button for a second). In the <q>Edit</q> menu you find the entry <q>MIDI PC: On</q> or <q>MIDI PC: Off</q>, that can be toggled by the <span data-keyword="Enter">Button</span>.</li>
            </ul>
            <p>By connecting a bank to MIDI PC the previously connected bank will be disconnected. After disconnecting the currently connected bank, none of the banks will be connected. The currently assigned bank can also be found and changed in the <q>Program Change Bank</q> menu in the MIDI Settings.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="section">
            <h3 class="heading secondary" data-number="7.3.1">MIDI Settings: Channels</h3>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <div class="section">
                    <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup window - MIDI - Channels">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-channels-send-rec.png"></picture>
                    </figure>
                    <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Channels">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-channels-send-rec.png"></picture>
                    </figure>
                </div>
                <div class="section">
                    <p>Here you can select the MIDI channel that is used to send and receive MIDI messages for both Primary and Split Channel. The Split Channel is relevant only if a Split Sound is loaded. If you select <q>Omni</q>, messages from all 16 MIDI channels will be applied. <q>None</q> will block all incoming and/or outgoing MIDI messages. When <q>Split Channel</q> is set to <q>Common</q>, it will use the same MIDI channel as the Primary Channel.</p>
                    <p>Settings for Split Channels apply to Split Sounds only. It controls the MIDI channel for MIDI messages sent and/or received by Part II. If the Split Channel is not set to <q>Common</q>, the Split Point(s) are not applied to the received MIDI notes and both Parts can be played over the full MIDI note range.</p>
                </div>
            </div>

            <div data-highlight="note">Please note that changing this setting while a note is active resets the voice allocation, the envelopes and the buffer of the C15, so that the audio playback is interrupted for a brief moment. In this case, a MIDI All Notes Off message is also sent on the respective channel(s).</div>
        </div>
        
        <div class="section">
            <h3 class="heading secondary" data-number="7.3.2">MIDI Settings: Assignments</h3>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <div class="section">
                    <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup Window - MIDI - Assignments">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-assign.png"></picture>
                    </figure>
                    <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Assignments (Pedal 1)">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-assign-p1.png"></picture>
                    </figure>
                </div>
                <div class="section">
                    <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Assignments (Pedal 4)">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-assign-p4.png"></picture>
                    </figure>
            
                    <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Assignments (Bender)">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-assign-bender.png"></picture>
                    </figure>
                    <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Assignments (Defaults)">
                        <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-assign-classic.png"></picture>
                    </figure>
                </div>
            </div>
            <p>These settings determine which types and numbers of MIDI messages are assigned to the Hardware Sources. High Resolution options for Velocities and Hardware Sources as well as a Bank selector for Program Changes are also provided. The Assignments apply to both MIDI Send and MIDI Receive.</p>
        
            <h4>Pedal 1, 2, 3, 4</h4>
            <p>Each pedal can be assigned to a MIDI Control Change. The CC numbers 1 to 31 are available for continuous operation in 7-bit and 14-bit (High-Res.) mode. In 14-bit mode a second CC with a number between 33 and 63 is automatically assigned for the LSB.</p>
            <p>In addition, the CC numbers 64 to 69 are available. They work as 2-state switches, as it is typical for e.g. a MIDI sustain pedal. When the C15's pedal position rises above 50 %, a MIDI CC value of 127 is sent, when it falls below 50% a value of 0 is sent. A received MIDI CC value smaller than 64 sets the pedal position to 0 %. Values of 64 or larger set the pedal position to 100 %.</p>
            <p>By selecting <q>None</q> the pedal is disconnected from MIDI.</p>
            
            <h4>Ribbon 1, 2</h4>
            <p>Each ribbon can be assigned to a MIDI Control Change. The CC numbers 1 to 31 are available in 7-bit and 14-bit (High-Res) mode. In 14-bit mode a second CC with a number between 33 and 63 is automatically assigned for the LSB.</p>
            <p>By selecting <q>None</q> the ribbon is disconnected from MIDI.</p>
            
            <h4>Bender</h4>
            <p>In the typical application as a pitch bender the Bender can be assigned to MIDI Pitchbend. This has 14 bits resolution by definition.</p>
            <p>The Bender can also be assigned to a MIDI Control Change. The CC numbers 1 to 31 are available in 7-bit and 14-bit (High-Res) mode. In 14-bit mode a second CC with a number between 33 and 63 is automatically assigned for the LSB.</p>
            <p>By selecting <q>None</q> the Bender is disconnected from MIDI.</p>
            
            <h4>Aftertouch</h4>
            <p>The most common assignment would be MIDI Channel Pressure. This has only 7 bits of resolution.</p>
            <p>Aftertouch can also be assigned to a MIDI Control Change. The CC numbers 1 to 31 are available in 7-bit and 14-bit (High-Res) mode. In 14-bit mode a second CC with a number between 33 and 63 is automatically assigned for the LSB</p>
            <p>Two additional options are available to assign Aftertouch to one half of the MIDI Pitchbend. <q>Pitchbend up</q> has a range from the center to the maximum while <q>Pitchbend down</q> goes from the center to the minimum. These ranges have 13 bits of resolution.</p>
            <p>By selecting <q>None</q>, Aftertouch is disconnected from MIDI.</p>
            
            <h4>High-Res. CCs (use LSB)</h4>
            <p>Control Changes can be transmitted with a resolution of 14 bit by using two CCs, one for coarse (MSB) values and one for fine (LSB) values. The LSB message has to be sent before the MSB message. The number of the CC for the LSB is derived from the number of the CC for the MSB by adding 32.</p>
            <p>To avoid conflicts with other applications of the LSB CCs, their use can be disabled (q
                Off). This setting applies to all assigned MIDI Control Changes.</p>
            
            <h4>High-Res. Velocity (CC 88)</h4>
            <p>Note On and Note Off velocities can be transmitted with a resolution of 14 bit by sending a CC 88 message before each Note On or Note Off message. The value of the CC 88 represents the LSB that is providing additional 7 bits of resolution.</p>
            <p>To avoid conflicts with other applications of CC 88, its use as velocity LSB can be disabled (<q>Off</q>).</p>
        
            <h4>Default Mappings</h4>
            <div data-columns="1">
                <table>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="Source"></span></th>
                        <th>Classic MIDI</th>
                        <th>High Resolution</th>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="Pedal">1</span></th>
                        <td>CC20</td>
                        <td>CC20 + CC52 <i>(MSB + LSB)</i></td>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="Pedal">2</span></th>
                        <td>CC21</td>
                        <td>CC21 + CC53 <i>(MSB + LSB)</i></td>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="Pedal">3</span></th>
                        <td>CC22</td>
                        <td>CC22 + CC54 <i>(MSB + LSB)</i></td>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="Pedal">4</span></th>
                        <td>CC23</td>
                        <td>CC23 + CC55 <i>(MSB + LSB)</i></td>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="Ribbon">1</span></th>
                        <td>CC24</td>
                        <td>CC24 + CC56 <i>(MSB + LSB)</i></td>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="Ribbon">2</span></th>
                        <td>CC25</td>
                        <td>CC25 + CC57 <i>(MSB + LSB)</i></td>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="Bender"></span></th>
                        <td>Pitchbend</td>
                        <td>Pitchbend</td>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="Aftertouch"></span></th>
                        <td>Channel Pressure</td>
                        <td>CC26 + CC58 <i>(MSB + LSB)</i></td>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="High-Res.">Velocity</span></th>
                        <td>Off</td>
                        <td>On <i>(LSB CC88)</i></td>
                    </tr>
                    <tr>
                        <th><span data-keyword="High-Res.">CCs</span></th>
                        <td>Off <i>(MSB only)</i></td>
                        <td>On <i>(MSB + LSB)</i></td>
                    </tr>
                </table>
            </div>
        </div>

        <div class="section">
            <h3 class="heading secondary" data-number="7.3.3">MIDI Settings: Routings</h3>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup Window - MIDI - Routings (all on)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-routing-all-on.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup Window - MIDI - Routings (all off)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-routing-all-off.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Routings (Notes)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-routing-notes.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Routings (Pedal 2)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-routing-p2.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Routings (Bender)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-routing-bender.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Setup screen - MIDI - Routings (Ribbon 2)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-routing-rib2.png"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <p>These settings allow to set individual and specific MIDI routings. The matrix consists of five columns: <q>Send Primary</q> (SP), <q>Receive Primary</q> (RP), <q>Send Split</q> (SS), <q>Receive Split</q> (RS)  and <q>Local</q> (L). The rows list <q>Notes</q>, <q>Program Change</q> and the eight <span data-keyword="Hardware">Sources</span> (Pedal 1-4,  Bender, Aftertouch and Ribbon 1-2. In the Web UI, a check mark at the respective matrix position sets the entry to <q>On</q>, removing the check mark sets it to <q>Off</q>.</p>
            <p>On the hardware, a highlighted entry represents <q>On</q>, a dark one <q>Off</q>. Also, the access to the matrix is different on the hardware. When you choose one of the rows and press <span data-keyword="Enter"></span>, you reach a dedicated settings dialog for this row. In the center, the display shows you the name of the respective component, e.g. <q>Notes</q>. Use <span data-keyword="Soft Buttons">2</span> and <span data-keyword>3</span> to change between the rows. With <span data-keyword="Soft Button">4</span>, you can switch between the columns. The name of the actual column is also displayed below the chosen row, e.g. <q>Send Primary</q>. By turning the dial, you can set the entry to <q>On</q> or <q>Off</q>. When holding the <span data-keyword="Shift">Button</span> while turning the dial, you can set the whole row to <q>On</q> or <q>Off</q>. The status is also displayed by the check marks on the right side. By pressing <span data-keyword="Soft Button">1</span>, you get back to the matrix overview.</p>
            <div class="section" data-columns="2">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="MIDI Routing screen - Notes (Send Primary on)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-routing-notes-prim-on.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="MIDI Routing screen - Pedal 1 (Send Primary on)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-routing-p1-prim-on.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="MIDI Routing screen - Notes (Send Primary off)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-routing-notes-prim-off.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="MIDI Routing screen - Pedal 1 (Send Primary off)">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-midi-routing-rib-prim-on.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <div>
                    <h4>Send (Primary/Split)</h4>
                    <p>When set to <q>Off</q> the respective C15 component will not send MIDI messages on the respective channel.</p>
                </div>
                <div>
                    <h4>Receive (Primary/Split)</h4>
                    <p>When set to <q>Off</q> the respective C15 component will not receive MIDI messages on the respective channel.</p>
                </div>
            </div>

            <h4>Local</h4>
            <p>When set to <q>Off</q> the respective component is disconnected from the synth engine, but still can be used to send MIDI note and Control Change, Pitchbend or Channel Pressure messages.</p>
            <p>In this mode the base unit display is not showing the associated Macro Control, but the MIDI-CC number assigned to the Ribbons instead.</p>

            <p>Decoupling a Hardware Source from the synth by setting Local Enable to <code>Off</code>, changes their representation in the UI.</p>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Local On/Off on Hardware Sources">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/parameter/webui-hw-local.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <div>
                    <p>The Hardware Source is now shown differentiated into <q>Send</q> and <q>Receive</q>.</p>
                </div>
            </div>
            <p><q>Send</q> shows the physical status of the respective Hardware Source, for example the current position of a Ribbon and relates to all communication with external devices. This value is sent via MIDI.</p>
                    <p><q>Receive</q> assigns the value that is passed internally to the synth. This is either a value received via MIDI or, in the case of the bidirectional Ribbons, a value received via an adjusted Macro Control. This allows the audio engine of the C15 to be triggered by an external device and at the same time the Hardware Sources can be used to control other external devices without conflict.</p>
            
            <h4>Set all Routings to On/Off</h4>
            <p>Below the Routings Matrix, you find the options to enable or disable all routings by pressing <q>Set all Routings to On</q> or <q>Set all Routings to Off</q> (respectively <q>All On</q>/<q>All Off</q> in the <span data-keyword="Graphical">UI</span>).</p>
        </div>

        <div data-highlight="note">Please note that changing the routings setting while a note is active resets the voice allocation and the envelopes of the C15, so that the audio playback is interrupted for a brief moment. In this case, a MIDI All Notes Off message is also sent on the respective channel(s). </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>
</body>

<main>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-number="7.4">Practical Studio Examples</h3>
        <p>With the C15's MIDI features, it can be used as a master keyboard and production tool in the center of your studio or live performance set. In the following we want to show you exemplary scenarios, which will help you to understand the MIDI settings better and give you some orientation and helpful tips when using the C15 as a production tool.</p>
        <div class="section">
            <h3 class="heading secondary">Scenario 1: Studio Setup</h3>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="C15 - Studio Setup">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-midi-setup-example-1-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>A Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) is the heart of almost every modern music studio. Therefore, this first scenario will focus on using your C15 with the benefits of a DAW, but also as a controller for other instruments within the DAW. So, on the one hand, we will use the C15 as a sound generator, and on the other hand, to control a Plug-In.</p>
            <div data-highlight="note">Please note that this setup is not entirely applicable to a live situation as any change to the MIDI settings while a note is active can lead to a reset of C15's envelopes and voice allocation and an All Notes Off MIDI message. As a consequence internal and external audio will stop for a brief moment.</div>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="C15 - Local Off Setup">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-midi-setup-example-2-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>First, we want to record a MIDI track, that triggers a C15 bass sound. This MIDI track receives MIDI notes and CC values by the C15. As we send MIDI data to the DAW and back to the C15, we can benefit from the MIDI processing features of the DAW (arpeggiator, chord generator, etc.).</p>
            <p>For the bass track, we want to record MIDI-Notes and the ribbon's CC values.</p>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Local Off - Routings">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-routing-scen-1a.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>For this purpose, we have to change some of the routing settings: turn on <q>Send</q> and <q>Receive</q> for both Notes and Ribbon 1 & 2 for Primary Channel. As we don't want MIDI Echo issues to appear, we turn off Local for them. The direct connection between the keys and both ribbons and the C15 is now interrupted and completely controlled via MIDI. MIDI-Monitoring of your DAW should be activated. You can now record the track.</p> 
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="C15 - DAW perspective">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-routing-daw.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>The track <q>C15 Bass</q> of the DAW now controls the C15 and the ribbon's LEDs reflect the incoming CC values. You can now use the keys and the remaining Hardware Sources to control a Plug-In in the DAW. In this example we use Arturia's Mini V3. Therefore, we want to turn off track 1's MIDI monitoring and choose track 2 for recording. The C15 keeps on playing, run by the recorded Bass track.</p>         
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="C15 - selective Setup">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-midi-setup-example-3-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="selective Setup - Routings">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-routing-scen-1b.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>As the C15 is still hearable, we do have to make some adaptions to the Routings settings. We want to turn off Local and Receive for all other Hardware Sources as they would interfere with the playing bass sound otherwise. You can now turn on Local for the Ribbons again, as this allows you a direct impact on the bass sound. Further, turn on <q>Send</q> for Pedals 1-4, Bender as well as Aftertouch and Notes, as we want to use these to control the Plug-In.</p>
            <p>We can now control the Plug-In without changing the bass sound unintentionally.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="section">
            <h3 class="heading secondary">Scenario 2: Controlling two Plug-Ins at the same time</h3>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="C15 - Dual Setup (PlugIns)">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/info-gfk/gfk-midi-setup-example-4-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>Thanks to C15's Split Mode, we can use MIDI to control and play two Plug-Ins at the same time. For this scenario, we need to load an existing Split-Preset or create a new one, as only then MIDI data is sent and received on the Split Channel as well. Next, we have to set the <q>Send</q> and <q>Receive</q> channels according to our settings in the DAW. In this case, we have two Plug-In tracks set to MIDI Channel 1 and 2. Therefore, we set Primary Channel to 1 and Split Channel to 2 for both <q>Send</q> and <q>Receive</q>. We can now control Plug-In 1 with the left and Plug-In 2 with the right Split Part.</p>
            <p>In the Routing settings, you can distribute the Hardware Sources on the channels or use them on both simultaneously - there are reasonable scenarios for both use cases.</p>
            <p>As you wish, you can turn off Local, so you don't hear the C15 and the MIDI-CCs will pop up on the small base unit display.</p>
            <p>As this setup is just about sending MIDI, all <q>Receive</q> entries were deactivated for the sake of clarity.</p>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Dual Setup - parallel Routings">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-routing-scen-2a.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Dual Setup - selective Routings">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-midi-routing-scen-2b.png"></picture>
            </figure>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>

        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>

<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="8">Setup (C15 System Settings)</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>The C15 also features a few global settings that are preset-independent. They are organized in the <span data-keyword="Setup">Menu</span> and mainly define the interaction with peripherals (such as sensitivities for velocities, external pedal integration, MIDI, or connected devices via Wi-Fi). Besides, the Setup menu allows for installing updates and transferring backups.</p>
        <p>Chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-13-setup-navigation.html" data-number="4.13">Setup Navigation</a> provides all information on accessing and navigating the Setup menu both on the <span data-keyword="Panel">Unit</span> and on the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span>. The following passages explain all provided menu items.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-detail="Panel Unit, Graphical UI">Device Settings</h3>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-device-settings.png"></picture>
            </figure>
        <h4>Velocity Curve</h4>
        <p>The Velocity Curve determines the sensitivity of the instrument for key velocities. A soft setting increases the sensitivity for low velocities, a hard setting increases the sensitivity for high velocites. With the normal setting, the sensitivity remains equal for all velocites.</p>
        <h4>Aftertouch Curve</h4>
        <p>The Aftertouch Curve determines the sensitivity of the instrument for Aftertouch gestures. A soft setting increases the sensitivity for low aftertouch intensities, a hard setting increases the sensitivity for high aftertouch intensities. With the normal setting, the sensitivity remains equal throughout.</p>
        <h4>Bender Curve</h4>
        <p>The Bender Curve determines the sensitivity of the instrument for Bender gestures. A soft setting increases the sensitivity for low bending intensities, a hard setting increases the sensitivity for high bending intensities. With the normal setting, the sensitivity remains equal throughout.</p>
        <h4>Pedal Settings</h4>
        <p>As described in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/05-synth-engine/05-04-hw-sources.html" data-number="5.4">Using Hardware Sources</a> the integration of pedals can be done manually. External Pedals can be connected to the C15 while the device is running. In the Settings menu, the pedal’s <span data-keyword="PIN">Assignment</span> can be selected. Those may vary depending on the pedal vendor (Roland uses <q>Pot Tip Active</q>, Yamaha uses <q>Pot Ring Active</q>, for example). If uncertain, which setting should apply to your external pedal, try the different options until the pedal works as intended.</p>
        <p>When an external pedal has been connected, it needs to be calibrated. This can be achieved by slowly turning the pedal to its minimal state and after remaining there for around a second, slowly turning the pedal to its maximal state and remaining there for around a second. The calibration will be stored by the C15, so the calibration is only necessary once after a pedal has been plugged in, even after restarts of the device.</p>
        <h4>Preset Glitch Suppression</h4>
        <p>This option can be enabled in order to avoid drastical changing pitches and other emerging artifacts, being provoked by a preset change. The suppression will be realized by clearing (flushing) all delay buffers when a new preset is loaded.</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Note that this feature is not fully implemented yet, as the suppression is not perfect in every case and can still produce small artifacts, depending on the preset change's circumstances. But in general, the effect is quite noticeable.</p>
        </div>
        <h4>Sync Parts across User Interfaces</h4>
        <p>For <span data-keyword="Split"></span> and <span data-keyword="Layer">Sounds</span>, different Parts can be shown on the C15’s <span data-keyword="Panel Unit">Display</span> and on one or multiple instances of the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span>. This can be useful but in many cases it was confusing. Therefore the normal behaviour is that the Part selection is applied once to all UIs, corresponding to <q>Sync Parts across UIs</q> being on. When the option is set off the Parts can be selected separately.</p>
        <h4>Edit Smoothing Time</h4>
        <p>When editing a parameter, the new adjusted value will be approached within the Edit Smoothing Time, which can range between zero and 200 ms. Higher times will lead to a slower response of the sound engine. This time does not affect preset recalls or modulations (having their own, individual times).</p>
        <h4>Transition Time</h4>
        <p>The transition time will be effective when recalling presets, defining the smoothing time of the parameters as they approach their new values.</p>
        <h4>Tune Reference</h4>
        <p>The tuning of the C15 can be adjusted in order to fit with acoustic instruments, spanning from 400.0 Hz up to 480.0 Hz (default: 440.0 Hz). When using default parameter values<sup><i>(1)</i></sup>, pressing the A3 key will produce a tone with the exact frequency provided by this setting.</p>
        <p><i><b>1)</b> required default parameter values for: Transposition (no Note Shift), Pitch (at 60.00 st, incl. Key Tracking of 100.0 % and Env C at 0.0 st), Scaling (Offset for A at 0.0 ct).</i></p>
        <h4>Init Sound</h4>
        <p>As described in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-03-1-parameter-editing.html" data-number="4.3.1">Editing a Parameter</a> (and <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-07-2-sound-manipulation.html" data-number="4.7.2">Manipulating Sounds</a>), specific parameters (and whole Sounds) can be set to their default values. The current Sound can be used for overwriting these default values by pressing <code><b>Store</b></code>. In order to restore the Factory default values, press <code><b>Reset</b></code>.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-detail="Graphical UI only">GUI Settings</h3>
        <p>A complete reference to the settings of the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span> can be found in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-16-5-gui-settings.html" data-number="4.16.5">GUI Settings</a>.</p>    
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-detail="Panel Unit only">Hardware UI</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="">
            <picture class="content" data-src="images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-hardware-ui.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <h4>Encoder Acceleration</h4>
        <p>The <span data-keyword="Encoder"></span> in the <span data-keyword="Edit">Panel</span> can detect acceleration gestures and apply them to an item in focus accordingly. With sufficient acceleration, even high resolution parameters can be completely traversed with only one or a few turns of the Encoder.</p>
        <h4>Ribbon Relative Factor</h4>
        <p>Similarly, drag gestures on the two <span data-keyword="Ribbon"></span> touchstrips can be amplified by the Ribbon Relative Factor. This option is only effective, when a Ribbon is in relative mode.</p>
        <h4>Signal Flow Indication</h4>
        <p>As described in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-10-overviews.html" data-number="4.10">Overviews</a> the Flow Overview allows for a fast and easy impression on how signals of a preset are routed. However, blinking LEDs may distract the user in some cases, therefore the Flow Overview is optional.</p>
        <h4>Screensaver Timeout</h4>
        <p>An optional timeout setting has been added in order to prevent possible pixel deterioration in the two displays, which can occur when the C15 is running for longer periods of time without any interaction.</p>
        <p>When the screensaver is running, any interaction will interrupt it and reset the timeout.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-detail="Panel Unit, Graphical UI">MIDI Settings</h3>
        <p>A complete reference to the MIDI settings can be found in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/07-midi/07-00-midi.html" data-number="7">MIDI</a>.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-detail="Panel Unit, Graphical UI">Recorder (Settings)</h3>
        <p>With the option <q>Auto-Start Recorder</q> the user can decide if the audio recording starts automatically when the C15 is switched on, or if the user has to start it by the <span data-keyword="Record">Button</span> <i>(see chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/06-recorder/06-recorder.html" data-number="6">Recorder</a> for more details)</i>.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary">System Info</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="">
            <picture class="content" data-src="images/web-ui/setup/webui-setup-system-info.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <h4>Device Name</h4>
        <p>The Device Name of the C15 instrument can be chosen by the user. It will appear in the meta data of presets and determine the SSID of the Wi-Fi network. In order to complete the renaming process, restart the instrument afterwards.</p>
        <h4 data-detail="Panel Unit only">SSID</h4>
        <p>During the booting process, the SSID will be generated according to the Device Name. A Wi-Fi network with the SSID should be available after booting. Besides the Device Name, the SSID contains a static prefix (<q>NL-C15-</q>). When establishing a Wi-Fi connection, choose the network with the corresponding SSID.</p>
        <h4>Passphrase</h4>
        <p>The secured Wi-Fi connection has to be confirmed by a passphrase. This passphrase can be seen and changed in the System Info (effective after rebooting). The passphrase can be set manually, it can be randomly generated or set to default (<code>88888888</code>).</p>
        <h4 data-detail="Panel Unit only">Website Address</h4>
        <p>When a Wi-Fi connection was established, the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span> is available with the shown address, which can be typed into your browser's address bar.</p>
        <h4>Free Disk Space</h4>
        <p>The remaining free disk space is displayed in order to see, if the instrument is capable of holding more presets.</p>
        <h4 data-detail="Panel Unit only">RAM usage</h4>
        <p>For developers, the system's current RAM consumption is indicated.</p>
        <h4>Software Version</h4>
        <h5><i>(Device Hardware ID, Branch, Head, Commits, Commit Date, RT Version)</i></h5>
        <p>For developers, the Device Hardware ID and versions of integrated components are displayed as well.</p>
        <h4>Date/Time</h4>
        <p>The instrument contains its own system clock, which will be included in preset meta data in the form of timestamps. It can be adjusted as well.</p>
        <h4 data-detail="Panel Unit only">Update Available</h4>
        <p>If a USB stick with a new (not already installed) update file is connected to the C15, this entry will indicate this with <code><b>Yes</b></code>. When restarting the C15, the update will be installed.</p>
        <h4 data-detail="Panel Unit only">Buffer Underruns</h4>
        <p>For developers, the number of detected Audio buffer underruns is indicated, hinting at performance issues.</p>
        <h4 data-detail="Gaphical UI only">Upload Software Update</h4>
        <p>If an external device is connected to the C15, a software update file can be directly uploaded. The C15 will then restart and install the update.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-detail="Panel Unit, Graphical UI">About</h3>
        <p>In the About section, the Nonlinear Labs developer team is listed.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" data-detail="Panel Unit only">Backup</h3>
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="">
            <picture class="content" data-src="images/hardware-ui/boled/setup/boled-setup-backup.png"></picture>
        </figure>
        <h4>USB Available</h4>
        <p>In order to backup all banks or restore a preexisting backup, a USB stick has to be plugged in. The <q>USB Available</q> indicator shows if a USB stick is currently present.</p>
        <h4>Save all Banks</h4>
        <p>When entering the <q>Save all Banks</q> option, a dialog will indicate that this process may take a while (when many banks are present) and ask for confirmation. After confirming, a backup file will be created on the USB stick.</p>
        <h4>Restore all Banks</h4>
        <p>When entering the <q>Restore all Banks</q> option, a dialog will indicate that all present banks will be discarded when proceeding. After confirming, another dialog screen will provide a list of all backup files found on the USB stick. After selecting the right file, the backup process can be started by confirming.</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>Details on how to save or restore backups on the <span data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span> can be found in chapter <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-14-backups.html" data-number="4.14">Backups</a>.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

</main>
</div>
