<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="9">Updating the C15</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Before starting an Update</h3>
        <div data-highlight="warn">
            <p>Please save your preset banks before installing the update!</p>
        </div>
        <p>The most convenient way is to use the menu entry <q>Save all Banks as Backup File...</q> in the <span data-keyword="Graphical">UI</span> or with <q>Backup</q> and <q>Save all Banks...</q> in the Setup menu in the <span data-keyword="Panel Unit">Display</span>. For more information, see <a href="./documents/man-user/04-user-interfaces/04-14-backups.html" data-number="4.14">Backups</a>.</p>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Steps to proceed</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>The latest installer is offered on <a href="https://www.nonlinear-labs.de/support/updates/updates.html" class="label" target="_blank">www.nonlinear-labs.de/support/updates/updates.html</a><br />By clicking its button you download the file <q>nonlinear-c15-update.tar</q> to your computer.</li>
            <li>Your computer might offer to unpack this type of file. Please make sure that the file is NOT unpacked or changed in any way.</li>
            <li>
                <u>When using the C15 USB Stick:</u>
                <ul>
                    <li>Copy the file (<q>nonlinear-c15-update.tar</q>) to the root folder of the USB memory stick that was delivered with the C15. (Other memory sticks will only work if they have the FAT32 format.)</li>
                    <li>Switch off the C15 and plug the memory stick into the USB connector at the backside of the C15.</li>
                    <li>Switch on the C15. The update process will start automatically.</li>
                </ul>
            </li>
            <li>
                <u>When using the Graphical User Interface:</u>
                <ul>
                    <li>Open the Setup Window in the Graphical User Interface and navigate to the Symstem Info tab.</li>
                    <li>The file (<q>nonlinear-c15-update.tar</q>) can be directly uploaded from your computer by clicking on the corresponding button next to the <q>Upload Software Update</q> option. Once the file was successfully uploaded, the C15 will automatically restart and start the update process.</li>
                </ul>
            </li>
            <li>The update process may take several minutes. The <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Panel Unit">Display</span> will indicate different phases of the process by showing <q>Updating...</q> messages.</li>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="warn">
            <p>Do not power off the C15 during the update installation!<br />An interruption of the power in this phase can cause irreversible damage.</p>
        </div>
        <ul>
            <li>When the update is finished, the display will show: <q>Updating C15 DONE! Please restart!</q> Please switch off the instrument, (remove the memory stick) and switch it on again.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading">Further Notes on Updates</h3>
        <div data-highlight="warn">
            <p>If you update from version 21-02 you might get the error message <q>Updating C15 FAILED</q> during the installation. In this case the installer needs to be run a second time. Please restart the C15 without removing the USB stick. Now the update should be successful.</p>
        </div>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>After a successful update the file on the memory stick is automatically renamed to <q>nonlinear-c15- update.tar-copied</q>. Please delete this file before using the stick for another update.</p>
        </div>
        <p>All downloaded update files have identical names (<q>nonlinear-c15-update.tar</q>). This is the file name required by the C15 to detect an update on the memory stick. If there is an earlier update file with this name in the download folder of your browser, the name of the new update will be modified (e.g. by adding <q>-1</q>). Therefore please check if the file has been renamed and restore the original name. It is recommended to remove all C15 update files from the download folder.</p>
        <p>If you want to store different updates on your computer, please keep them in separate folders or rename them, so that you can identify them later.</p>
        <p>You can check the current software versions in the <q>System Info</q> section of the <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Setup">Menu</span>. For this press the<span class="keyword" data-keyword="Setup">Button</span> on the <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Edit">Panel</span> or the <q>Setup</q> entry in the <span class="keyword" data-keyword="View">Menu</span> of the <span class="keyword" data-keyword="Graphical">User Interface</span> and select <q>System Info</q>. Here you find the <q>Software Version</q>. It shows the release date as well as year and week in the format YY-WW (e.g. 20-40 - week 40 in year 2020).</p>
        <div data-highlight="note">
            <p>If a <q>FAILED</q> message appears in the display, the update was not successful. In this case please repeat the installation. Rename the installer file to the original name <q>nonlinear-c15-update.tar</q>, plug in the USB stick and start the C15 again. If this is without success please contact us. On the USB stick you will find a log file (<q>nonlinear-c15-update.log.txt</q>) which you can send us to help us analyzing the problem.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
</main>
</div>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/index.html">User Manual</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/man-user/10-specifications/10-specifications.html" data-number="10">Specifications</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="10">Specifications</h2>
        
        <h3>Synthesis Engine</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>2 Oscillators (sine wave, adjustable jitter/noise)</li>
            <li>Phase modulation: Self, A > B, B > A, via the Shapers, and by the feedback signal</li>
            <li>2 Shapers (sine curve, adjustable folding and asymmetry)</li>
            <li>Ring Modulator</li>
            <li>Comb Filter (tunable, with allpass and lowpass)</li>
            <li>State Variable Filter (2 - 4 poles, multi-mode, spread cutoffs, FM)</li>
            <li>Feedback Mixer (4 inputs, shaper for the sum)</li>
            <li>Feedback bus with 4 destinations</li>
            <li>Output Mixer (4 inputs, stereo output, shaper for the sum)</li>
            <li>3 ADBDSR Envelopes, adjustable Attack Curve</li>
            <li>Velocity amounts for envelope levels and all times</li>
            <li>Note-off velocity can be applied to the release times</li>
            <li>24-voice polyphony</li>
            <li>Split and Layer modes for two Parts of 12 voices</li>
            <li>Unison: 2 - 24 voices, adjustable detune, phase and pan spreading</li>
            <li>Monophonic mode, adjustable priority, legato modes, and glide time</li>
            <li>Micro-tuning for the 12 steps of the octave</li>
            <li>5 Stereo Effects:
                <ul>
                    <li>Flanger/Chorus/Phaser/Tremolo</li>
                    <li>Cabinet (amp simulation)</li>
                    <li>8-pol Gap/Band Filter</li>
                    <li>Echo</li>
                    <li>Reverb</li>
                </ul>
            </li>
            <li>Parameter resolution: typically 1000 steps (250-15000 steps)</li>
            <li>6 Macro Controls, each can be routed to up to 106 target parameters</li>
        </ul>

        <h3>Keys and Controls</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>61-key Fatar TP/8S keybed with semi-weighted long-arm keys</li>
                <li>Two 800 mm ribbons (touch strips), each with 33 LEDs</li>
                <li>Ribbon modes: absolute, relative, combinable with return-to-center</li>
                <li>Lever (magnetic force loaded) for pitchbending and similar applications</li>
                <li>Aftertouch (global)</li>
                <li>Resolution of velocity, ribbons, bender, aftertouch, pedals: 4000 steps</li>
                <li>Free mapping of pedals, ribbons, bender and aftertouch to the 6 Macro Controls</li>
            </ul>
    
        <h3>User Interface</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>96 high-quality buttons for quick access to all parameters</li>
                <li>Magnetic front panel foils are replaceable to support future synthesis engines</li>
                <li>The base unit can be used without the panel unit</li>
                <li>Graphical user interface, available in the browser on WiFi-enabled devices</li>
                <li>Designed for mouse and touch input, unique zoom-and-pan navigation</li>
                <li>Drag and drop handling of presets</li>
            </ul>
    
        <h3>Preset System</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>Unlimited number of banks and presets per bank</li>
                <li>User-editable comment and color tag per preset</li>
                <li>Functions for searching and comparing presets</li>
                <li>Morphing transition between presets</li>
            </ul>
    
        <h3>Undo System</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>Unlimited undo for all user interactions, including sound editing steps</li>
                <li>Undo list with support for multiple editing branches (tree view)</li>
                <li>Change indication and comparison with the original parameter value</li>
            </ul>
    
        <h3>Continuous Digital Audio Capture</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>Permanent lossless recording of the digital output signal</li>
                <li>Hours of FLAC-compressed audio (at least 80 min) stored in a ring buffer</li>
                <li>Browser-based graphical UI for review, play-back and download</li>
                <li>The states of the synth engine along the time line can be restored</li>
                <li>Download of selected segments to the computer as WAV or FLAC files</li>
            </ul>
    
        <h3>Connections</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>Stereo line outputs, balanced by transformers (TRS and XLR connectors)</li>
                <li>Headphones output at the front with separate volume control</li>
                <li>Four inputs for pedals, switches or CV (TRS, flexible pin-assignment)</li>
                <li>USB host connector for data storage, software updates, and MIDI</li>
                <li>Directly connectable to USB MIDI devices</li>
                <li>Optional MIDI Bridge accessory for connection to a computer</li>
                <li>High resolution (14-bit) option for MIDI velocities and control values</li>
            </ul>
    
        <h3>Dimensions, Weight</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>Base unit only: 900 x 290 x 100 mm (width x depth x height), 10.5 kg</li>
                <li>Including panel unit: 900 x 410 x 160 mm (width x depth x height), 13.5 kg</li>
            </ul>
            
    </section>
</main>
</div>

<body class="main-grid" data-path="root/man-user/13-kb-shortcuts">

<div class="tutorial">
    
    <section>
        <h2 data-number="1">About these tutorials</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>These tutorials were written to make you find your way into the secrets of your C15 synthesizer quickly and easily. Please consult the Quickstart Guide or the User Manual to learn everything about the basic concept and setup of your C15 before using these tutorials. Please also consult the User Manual any time to delve deeper into the capabilities of the C15 synthesis engine, and to learn about all the details of any of the parameters of the instrument.</p>
        <p>A tutorial will teach you basic aspects of the C15’s concepts as well as the various components of the sound engine, and how they interact with each other, in a hands-on manner. It is an easy way to familiarize yourself with your C15, and a starting point for your sound design work on the instrument it is, too.</p>
        <p>If you feel like learning more about the details of a specific parameter (e.g. value ranges, scaling, modulation capabilities etc), please refer to chapter 8.4. <q>Parameter Reference</q> of the User Manual at any time. You can use the tutorials and the User Manual in parallel.</p>
        <p>The tutorials use the front panel of the instrument. In case you would rather like to work with the Graphic User Interface, please refer to the Quickstart Guide or chapter 7 <q>User Interfaces</q> of the User Manual first to learn about the basic concepts of the GUI. After this, you will be able to easily apply the programming steps described and transfer them from the hardware panel to the GUI.</p> 
    </section>    
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" >Formats</h3>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>These tutorials describe fairly simple programming examples you can follow step by step. You will find lists boasting programming steps and figures that show the C15’s user interface state. To make things perfectly clear, we make use of specific formatting throughout the entire tutorial.</p>
        <p>Buttons (Section) that need to be pressed are formatted in yellow. The name of the section follows in (brackets). The Encoder is labelled the same way:</p>
        <p><em>Sustain</em> (Envelope A) … <em>Encoder</em> … </p>
        <p>Secondary parameters that can be accessed by repeatedly hitting a button are labelled in yellow italic:  <em><i>Asym</i></em></p>
        <p>Data values are yellow and in square brackets: <em>[60.0 %]</em></p>
        <p>Controllers, as the Ribbons and Pedals, are labelled in yellow Capitals: <em>PEDAL 1</em></p>
        <p>Programming steps to be performed are indented to the right and marked with a triangle, like this: &#xE01A;</p>
        <p>Notes on the previous programming step are even more indented to the right and marked with a double slash:  //</p>
        <p>This will look e.g. like this:</p>
    
    <h3 class="heading secondary">Applying modulation to the PM self modulation of Oscillator A:</h3>
    <ul>
        <li>Press <em>PM A</em> (Oscillator B) two times. <em>Env A</em> is highlighted in the display.</p> 
        <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[30.0 %]</em>.</p>
        <li class="indent-b">Oscillator B is now being phase-modulated by the signal of Oscillator A. The modulation depth is controlled by Envelope A at a value of 30.0%.</p>
    </ul>
    
    <p>Every once in a while, you will find some notes of particular importance (at least we believe so...). They are marked by an exclamation mark (which looks like this:</p> 
    
        <p>&#xE172;&ensp;Please note that there is …</p>

    <p>Sometimes, you will find some explanations within a list of programming steps. They provide a little more in-depth knowledge and are called <q>Excursions</q>. They look like this:</p>

    <div data-highlight="excursion">
        <h3>Excursion: Parameter Value Resolution</h3>

    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary" >Basic Conventions</h3>
        <p>Before starting, it is crucial to understand some basic conventions of the front panel – more on this in the Quickstart Guide:</p>
        <ul class="nontutorial">
            <li>When a button on a Selection Panel is pressed, the parameter is selected and its value can be edited. Its LED will light up permanently. Additional <q>Sub Parameters</q> can be accessed by pressing the button multiple times.</li>
            <li>There can be some flashing LEDs to show the targets of the signal that is generated in the selected Parameter Group.</li> 
            <li>When a Macro Control is selected, flashing LEDs dislay the parameters it is modulating.</li>
            <li>When the Preset screen is on, the currently active signal flow or active parameters respectively are indicated by LEDs lighting up permanently.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>

<!-- menu: location -->
<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/tut-sound-generation/index.html">Sound Generation Tutorial</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/tut-sound-generation/02-init-sound.html" data-number="2">Init Sound</a>
    </label>

<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
<div class="tutorial">

    <section>
        <h2 data-number="2">Init Sound</h2>
    </section>
    <section>
        <p>The first tutorial describes the basic functions of the sound generation modules, their interaction (resp. modulation capabilities), and the signal path. You will learn how to create specific waveforms using the oscillators, blend them, and feed them into subsequent modules like filters and effects. We will be dealing with the filters as sound-processing devices as well as with the sound-generating capabilities of the Comb Filter. The tutorial will be topped off by an insight into the feedback capabilities (which is another very interesting way of creating sounds).</p>
        <p>As you certainly know already, the C15’s oscillators initially generate sine-waves. The real fun starts when these sine-waves are warped to generate complex waveforms with amazing sonic results. We will start right there:</p>
        
        <h3 class="heading primary" >Init Sound</h3>
        <p>Starting with the Init Sound is the best thing to do. When loading the Init Sound, parameters are set to their default values (same thing happens when using the default button). The Init Sound uses the most basic signal path with no modulations at all. Most of the mix parameters are set to zero value.</p>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Initializing all parameters (resp. the edit buffer):</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Sound</em> (Edit Panel).</li>
            <li>Press <em>Init</em> (Edit Panel / Soft Button 1).</li>
            <li>Press <em>Enter</em> (Edit Panel).</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now the edit buffer has been initialized. You will hear – nothing. Don’t worry, you are not the one to blame. Please proceed:</li>
            <li>Press <em>A</em> (Output Mixer).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[60.0 %]</em>.</li>
            <li>Play some notes.</li>
            <li>You will hear the typical Init sound – a simple, slowly decaying one-oscillator sine-wave sound.</li>
    </ul>
    </section>
    <section>
        <div data-highlight="excursion">
            <h3>Excursion: A Short Glimpse at the Signal Path</h3>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Signal Path">
                <picture class="content" data-src="./images/diagrams/block-simple-tmb-*.svg"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>Starting point are the two oscillators. They produce sine-waves for a start but these sine-waves can be warped in various ways to produce complex waveshapes. This is done by phase modulation (PM) and by using the Shaper sections.</p> 
            <p>Each oscillator can be phase-modulated by three sources: itself, the other oscillator, and the feedback signal. All three sources can be used at the same time in variable proportions.</p>
            <p>Three Envelopes control both Oscillators and Shapers (Env A → Osc/Shaper A, 
            Env B → Osc/Shaper B, while Env C can be routed pretty flexibly, e.g. for controlling the filters).</p>
            <p>To process the oscillator signals even further, there is a State Variable Filter as well as a Comb Filter. When operating at high resonance settings and being pinged by an oscillator signal, both filters can work as signal generators in their own right.</p>
            <p>Oscillator/Shaper outputs and filter outputs are fed into the Output Mixer. This section allows you to blend and balance various sonic components with each other. To avoid undesired distortion at the output stage, keep an eye on the Output Mixers Level parameter. Values around – 4.5 or – 5 dB are mostly on the safe side. If you want to use distortion deliberately to produce timbral variations, please consider using the Drive parameter of the Output Mixer or the Cabinet effect instead.</p>
            <p>The final stage of the signal path is the effects Section. It is fed from the Output Mixer where all voices are combined into a monophonic signal. When using the Init sound, all five effects will be bypassed.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    
</div><!-- Ende Tutorial (Listen) -->
</main>
</div>

<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
<div class="tutorial">

    <section>
        <h2>Oscillator Section / Creating Waveforms</h2>
        <p>A typical parameter screen of the Panel Unit display looks like this:</li>
    
        <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Typical Parameter Screen">
            <picture class="content" data-src="images/tutorials/sound-generation/boled-typic.png"></picture>
            <figcaption data-columns="2">
                <ol start="1">
                    <li><span data-keyword="Group Header"></span></li>
                    <li><span data-keyword="Parameter"> Name</span></li>
                    <li><span data-keyword="Graphical"> Indicator</span></li>
                </ol>
                <ol start="4">
                    <li><span data-keyword="Parameter"> Value</span></li>
                    <li><span data-keyword="Soft Button"> Labels</span></li>
                    <li><span data-keyword="Main and Sub"> Parameters</span></li>
                </ol>
            </figcaption>
        </figure>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary">Oscillator Basics</h3>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Let’s (de)tune Oscillator A:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator A)</li> 
            <li><em>A–B</em> (Comb Filter) <em>A–B</em> (State Variable Filter) and <em>A</em> (Output Mixer) are flashing to show you that both filters and the Output Mixer are receiving a signal from the selected Oscillator A (even though you are not hearing much filtering right now).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> and detune Oscillator A by semitones.</pclass="indent-a">
            <li class="indent-b">The pitch is displayed in MIDI-note numbers: <q>60</q> is MIDI note 60 and equal to note <q>C3</q>. It is the pitch that you hear when playing the third <q>C</q> of the keyboard.</li>
        </ul>
    
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Now let’s play around with Key Tracking:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator A) two times. Its light stays on. Now watch the display. It shows the highlighted parameter <em><i>Key Trk</i></em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Note that multiple hitting of a parameter button toggles between the upper <q>main</q> parameter (here <q>Pitch</q>) and several <q>sub</q> parameters (here <em><i>Env C</i></em> and <em><i>Key Trk</i></em>) that are related to the main parameter.</li>
            <li>Turn the Encoder to <em>[50.00 %]</em>. Oscillator A’s keyboard tracking is now halved which equals playing quarter-tones on the keyboard.</li>
            <li>Turn the Encoder to <em>[0.00 %]</em>. Each key is playing at the same pitch now.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">A key tracking close to 0.00% can be very useful when an oscillator is used as LFO-like modulation source or slow PM-carrier. More on this later…</li>
            <li>Turn the Encoder back to <em>[100.00 %]</em> (the usual semi-tone scaling).</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Reset every parameter to its default value by hitting <em>Default</em> (Edit Panel).</li>
        </ul>
    
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Let’s introduce some envelope parameters:</h3>
        <ul>
            <p>(please consult the User Manual for all details of the envelope parameters or use the Info button on the Edit Panel).</p>
            <li>Press <em>Attack</em> (Envelope A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> and play some notes.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Release</em> (Envelope A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> and play some notes.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Envelope A is always connected to Oscillator A and controls its volume.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Sustain</em> (Envelope A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[60,0 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Oscillator A is now providing a static signal level.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary">Oscillator Self-Modulation</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>PM Self</em> (Oscillator A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> back and forth.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Oscillator A’s output is fed back into its input. At higher rates, the output wave gets increasingly warped and generates a sawtooth wave with rich harmonic content. Sweeping the Encoder will produce a filter-like effect.</li>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="excursion">
            <h3>Excursion: bipolar parameter values</h3>
            <p>PM Self works at positive as well as negative parameter values. You will find many more parameters with positive and negative values, not only modulation depth settings (as you might know from other synthesizers) but also mixing levels etc. In many cases, a negative value represents a phase-shifted signal. Only when mixing such a signal with other signals, phase cancellations will generate audible effects.</p>
            <p>With Self PM active, a positive value will generate a sawtooth-wave with rising edge, negative values generate a falling edge.</p>
            
            <h3>Let’s make Oscillator self-modulation dynamic and control Self-PM of Oscillator A by Envelope A:</h3>
            <ul>
                <li>Set the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[70,0 %]</em> self modulation amount.</li>
                <li>Press <em>PM Self</em> (Oscillator A) again. Watch the Display: <em><i>Env A</i></em> is highlighted</li>
                <li class="indent-b">You have just accessed the first sub-parameter <q>behind</q> PM-Self (<q>Env A</q>). It is the amount of Envelope A modulating PM-Self of Oscillator A.</li>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Screen PM Self">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="images/tutorials/sound-generation/boled-pm-self.png"></picture>
                </figure>            
                <li class="indent-b">Alternatively, you can toggle through the sub-parameters behind the currently active button with the rightmost soft button at any time.</li>
                <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[100,0 %]</em>.</li>
                <li class="indent-b">Envelope A now provides a dynamic modulation depth for PM Self of Osc A. As a result, you will hear a transition from bright to soft or the other way round, depending on the settings of Env A.</li>
                <li>Now tweak the different Envelope A parameters a bit (see above): Depending on the settings, you will hear some simple brassy or percussive sounds.</li>
                <li class="indent-b">Since Envelope A is influenced by keyboard velocity, the sound will also depend on how hard you are hitting the keys.</li>
            </ul>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary">Introducing the Shaper</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>First, please reset Oscillator A to a simple sine-wave by selecting <em>PM Self</em> and <em>PM Self - Env A (Env A)</em> and hitting <em>Default</em>. Envelope A should be providing a simple organ-like setting.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Mix</em> (Shaper A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> slowly to <em>[100.0 %]</em> and play some notes.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">At increasing Mix values, you will hear the sound getting brighter. Note that the sound is somewhat different from the results of <q>PM Self</q>. Now the Oscillator A signal is being routed through Shaper A. <q>Mix</q> blends between the pure oscillator signal (0 %) and the output of the Shaper (100 %).</li>
            <li>Press <em>Drive</em> (Shaper A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> slowly and play some notes.</li>
            <li>Then set the Drive to <em>[20.0 dB]</em>.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Fold</em> (Shaper A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> slowly and play some notes.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Asym</em> (Shaper A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> slowly and play some notes.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Fold, Drive and Asym(metry) warp the signal to generate various waveshapes with very different harmonic content and timbral results.</li>
            <li>Press <em>PM Self</em> (Oscillator A) again.</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[50.0 %]</em> and play some notes.</li>
            <li>Press <em>PM Self</em> (Oscillator A) again.</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> slowly and play some notes.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now you have just fed the Shaper with the self-modulated (resp. sawtooth wave) signal instead of a sine wave.</li>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="excursion">
            <h3>Excursion: what’s that Shaper doing?</h3>
            <p>In simple words, the Shaper distorts the oscillator signal in various ways. It maps the input signal to a shaping curve to produce a more complex waveform. Depending on the settings, a vast range of different harmonic spectra can be created.</p> 
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Shaper Diagram">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/tutorials/sound-generation/shaper-drive-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>The <em>Drive</em> parameter controls the intensity of distortion induced by the Shaper and can produce a vaguely filter-like effect.</p>
            <p>The <em>Fold</em> parameter controls the amount of ripples in the waveform. It emphases some odd harmonics while the fundamental is attenuated. The sound gets some characteristic <q>nasal</q> quality, not unlike a resonating filter.</p>
            <p><em>Asymmetry</em> treats the upper and the lower part of the input signal differently and generates even harmonics (2nd, 4th, 6th etc) that way. At high values, the signal is pitched one octave higher while the fundamental is eliminated.</p>
            <p>All three parameters interact with each other, producing countless variations of distortion curves and resulting waveforms.</p>
        </div>
        <div data-highlight="excursion">
            <h3>Excursion: the C15’s signal routing / blending</h3>
            <p>As with all signal routings in the C15, the Shaper is not switched in or out of the signal path but continuously blended with another (usually the dry) signal. This makes sense since it provides great morphing capabilities without any steps or clicks in the sound. More on this later.</li>
        </div>
        <div data-highlight="excursion">
            <h3>Excursion: parameter value fine resolution</h3>
            <p>Some parameters need a very fine resolution to fine-tune a sound the way you desire. In order to do this, the resolution of every parameter can be multiplied by a factor of 10 (sometimes even 100). Simply hit the <em>Fine</em> button to toggle fine resolution on and off. To get an impression of that effect, try out <q><em>Drive</em> (Shaper A)</q> in fine resolution mode.</p>
            <p>By selecting a new parameter, the fine <q>mode</q> will automatically be disabled. To enable fine resolution permanently, press <em>Shift + Fine</em>.</p>
        </div>
        <ul>
            <li>Now set <em>PM Self</em> to <em>[75 %]</em>.</li>
            <li>Press <em>PM Self</em> (Oscillator A) another two times (or use the <em>rightmost soft button</em>) to access the sub-parameter <em>Shaper</em>. It is highlighted in the display.</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> slowly and play some notes.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now the signal for the phase-modulation of Oscillator A is fed back post Shaper: Instead of a sine-wave, a complex waveform is now used as modulator. This generates even more overtones and, beyond a certain degree, it can produce increasingly chaotic results, noisy or <q>chirpy</q> sounds in particular. You will hear the effect of the shaper even when you set the shaper’s Mix parameter to zero.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>
    <section>
        <h3 class="heading primary">Both Oscillators together</h3>
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Mixing both Oscillators:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>First, please reload the Init Sound. Both Oscillators are now generating simple sine-waves again.</li>
            <li>Press <em>A</em> (Output Mixer).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[60.0 %]</em>.</li>
            <li>Press <em>B</em> (Output Mixer).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[60.0 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now, both oscillators are sending their signals through the Output Mixer.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Level</em> (Output Mixer).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[-10.0 dB]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">You have just reduced the mixer’s output signal enough to avoid unwanted distortion.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Sustain</em> (Envelope A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[50 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Oscillator A is now providing a sine-wave at a constant level whereas Oscillator B is still fading out over time.</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Creating intervals:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[67.00 st]</em>. Play some notes.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now Oscillator B is tuned seven semitones (a fifth) above Oscillator A. You may also try out different intervals like e. g. an octave (<q>72</q>) or an octave plus an additional fifth (<q>79</q>).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> back to <em>[60.00 st]</em> or use the Default button.</li>
            <li>Press <em>PM Self</em> (Oscillator B).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[60.0 %]</em>. Play some notes.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Oscillator B is modulating itself now, sounding brighter than Oscillator A.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Decay 2</em> (Envelope B).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[300 ms]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Oscillator B is now fading out at a medium decay rate. The resulting sound is vaguely reminiscent of a piano of sorts.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Sustain</em> (Envelope B).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[50%]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now, both Oscillators are producing steady tones. The resulting sound is vaguely reminiscent of an organ.</li>
        </ul>
        <p>You have just created some sounds that are made up of two components: A basic sine-wave from Oscillator A and some sustained / decaying overtones from Oscillator B. Very simple still, but with lots of creative options to choose from …</p>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Detuning Oscillator B:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>PM Self</em> (Oscillator A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[60.00 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">We simply wanted to make the entire sound somewhat brighter, to improve the audibility of the following example.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B).</li>
            <li>Press <em>Fine</em> (Edit Panel).</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> slowly up and down and dial in <em>[60.07 st]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Oscillator B has now been detuned by 7 Cents above Oscillator A. Detuning generates a beat frequency that we all love so much because it makes the sound so <q>fat</q> and <q>vibrant</q>.</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Tweaking the sound a bit more:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Attack</em> (Envelope A and B).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em>.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Release</em> (Envelope A and B).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Adjust PM Self level and Envelope parameters as you please. Depending on the settings, the results will vary between string and brass-like sounds.</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">The same beat frequency at all pitch ranges with Key Tracking</h3>
        <p>As you may have noticed, the beat frequency changes across the range of the keyboard. Higher up the keyboard, the effect can grow too strong and sound a bit <q>unnatural</q>. To achieve a steady beat frequency at all pitch ranges:</p>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B) three times. <em>Key Trk</em> is highlighted in the display.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Fine</em> (Edit Panel).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> slowly to <em>[99.80 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">At a Key Tracking below 100%, the pitch of higher notes will be increasingly reduced resp. not proportional to their position on the keyboard. This detunes high notes a bit less than low notes and keeps the beat frequency lower in high ranges, resp. steady across a wide pitch range.</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">One oscillator modulating the other:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>First, please reload the Init-Sound. Don’t forget to turn up <em>Level A</em> on the Output Mixer to <em>[60.0 %]</em>. Both Oscillators are now generating simple sine-waves. What you are hearing right now is Oscillator A.</li>
            <li>Press <em>PM B</em> (Oscillator A).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> and dial in approx. <em>[75.00 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Oscillator B is not added to the output mixer but used to modulate the phase of Oscillator A instead. Since Oscillator B is currently generating a sine-wave at the same pitch as Oscillator A, the audible effect is similar to self-modulation of Oscillator A. But here comes the fun part, we are now detuning Oscillator B:</li>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B).</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> and play some notes. Then dial in <em>[53.00 st]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">You will now be hearing some soft <q>metallic</q> timbres that sound quite promising (but that’s only us, of course...).</li>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="excursion">
            <h3>Excursion – The Secrets of Phase Modulation (PM) – Oscillator Pitches and Modulation Index</h3>
            <p>When modulating the phase of one oscillator by another one at a different frequency, lots of sidebands or new overtones respectively are generated. Those were not present in the source signals. The frequency ratio of both oscillator signals defines the harmonic content resp. the overtone structure of the resulting signal. The resulting sound remains harmonic as long as the ratio between the modulated oscillator (called <q>carrier</q> – here Oscillator A) and the modulating oscillator (called <q>modulator</q> – here Oscillator B) is a proper multiple (1:1, 1:2, 1:3 etc).</p> 
            <p>If not, the resulting sound will become increasingly inharmonic and dissonant. Depending on the frequency ratio, the sonic character is reminiscent of <q>wood</q>, <q>metal</q> or <q>glass</q>. This is because the frequencies in a vibrating piece of wood, metal or glass are very similar to the frequencies generated by PM. Obviously, PM is a very good tool to generate sounds that feature this type of timbral character.</p>
            <p>A second crucial parameter is the intensity of the phase modulation or <q>modulation index</q>. In the C15, the appropriate parameters are called <q>PM A</q> and <q>PM B</q>. Different values will produce radically different timbral results. The interaction between the pitch of the respective oscillators and their modulation depth settings (<q>PM A / B</q>) is also crucial to the sonic results.</p>
        </div>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Controlling the Modulator by an Envelope:</h3>
        <p>As you have learned in the meantime, frequency and mod depth of the modulator (here Oscillator B) are crucial for shaping sound using PM. Unlike classic subtractive synthesis, it is very easy to generate a wide range of noisy and <q>metallic</q> timbres that offer lots of potential when emulating acoustic instruments, like e.g. mallets or plucked strings. To explore this, we will now add some sort of percussive <q>stroke</q> to a simple sound:</p>
        <ul>
            <li>Load the Init sound and turn up Oscillator A (the carrier): <em>A</em> (Output Mixer) = <em>[75.0 %]</em>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B).</li>
            <li>Set the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[96.00 st]</em>.</li>
            <li>Press <em>PM B</em> (Oscillator A).</li>
            <li>Set the <em>Encoder</em> to approx <em>[60.00 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now you are hearing Oscillator A being phase-modulated by Oscillator B. The sound is bright and slowly decaying.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B) until <em>Key Trk</em> is highlighted in the display.</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> and dial in <em>[0.00 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">The Key Tracking of Oscillator B is off now, providing a steady modulator-pitch for all keys. In some key ranges, the sound is now becoming somewhat odd.</li>
            <li>Press <em>PM B</em> (Oscillator A) until <em>Env B</em> is highlighted in the display. 
                Set the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[100.0 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now Envelope B is controlling the phase-modulation depth (PM B) over time.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Decay 1</em> (Envelope B).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[10.0 ms]</em>.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Decay 2</em> (Envelope B).</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[40.0 ms]</em> and play some notes. Keep Breakpoint (BP Level) at default value 50%.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Envelope B is now producing a short percussive <q>stroke</q> that quickly fades out. In every key range, the percussive <q>stroke</q> sounds slightly different since the pitch ratio between carrier and modulator is a bit different for every key. This helps to make emulations of natural sounds pretty realistic.</li>
    </ul>
    
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Using Key Tracking as a sound parameter:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B) until <em>Key Trk</em> is highlighted in the display.</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> and dial in <em>[50.00 %]</em> while playing some notes.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">The Key Tracking of Oscillator B has been enabled again which forces Oscillator B to change its pitch depending on the note played. As you remember, pitch ratios between oscillators are altered and hence the harmonic structure of the resulting sound will also be altered across the entire note range. Enjoy trying out some timbral results.</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Using the Modulator Pitch to change the sonic character:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Now change <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B).</li>
            <li class="indent-b">You will notice the timbral transition from <q>wooden</q> (medium pitch ranges) through <q>metallic</q> to <q>glassy</q> (high pitch ranges). Re-adjust <em>Decay 2</em> (Envelope B) a bit also and you will hear some simple but amazing <q>tuned percussion</q> sounds. As a pretty nice-sounding example, dial in e.g. Pitch (Oscillator B) 105.00 st and <em>Decay 2</em> (Envelope B) 500 ms. Have fun and get carried away (but not too much) …</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Cross modulation:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>PM A</em> (Oscillator B).
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> slowly up and dial in approx. <em>[50.00 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">The phase of Oscillator B is now being modulated by Oscillator A. That means, both oscillators are now modulating each other’s phase. This is called cross- or x-modulation. That way, lots of inharmonic overtones are produced and, accordingly, the sonic results can be quite odd and often noisy. They depend very much on the frequency/pitch ratios of either oscillators (please see above). Please feel free to explore some nice Pitch B values and Envelope B settings as well as variations of PM A and PM B and the modulation of PM A by Envelope A. At proper parameter value ratios, you may create some nice <q>plucked strings</q> – nylon and steel strings included.</li>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="excursion">
            <h3>Excursion – Adjusting velocity sensitivity</h3>
            <p>You certainly want to explore a lot of expressive potential when enjoying your sounds. The C15 provides a lot of capabilities to do so (Ribbon Controllers, Pedals etc). For starters, we would like to introduce Keyboard Velocity. Its default setting is 30.0 dB which works pretty well in many cases.</li>
        </div>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Level Vel</em> (Envelope A).
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> and dial in <em>[0.0 dB]</em> first, then increase the value slowly to <em>[60.0 dB]</em> while playing some notes.
            <li>Repeat the process with Envelope B.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Since Envelope A controls the level of Oscillator A, a change of its velocity value affects the loudness of the current sound. Oscillator B level (the Modulator) is controlled by Envelope B. Since Oscillator B determines the timbral character of the current setting to some extent, its level has a huge effect on the current sound.</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Oscillator as LFO (Low Frequency Oscillator):</h3>
        <p>Now set up your C15 so that:</li>
        <p>Oscillator A produces a steady sine-wave (no Self-PM, no Envelope modulation)</li>
        <p>Oscillator A is constantly phase-modulated by Oscillator B (again no Self-PM, no Envelope modulation here). <em>PM B</em> (Oscillator A) should have a value around <em>[90.0 %]</em> to make all the following sonic results easily audible. Oscillator B should not be part of the audible output signal, i. e. B (Output Mixer) is <em>[0.0 %]</em>.</li>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B).</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> up and down while playing some notes. 
            Then dial in <em>[0.00 st]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">You will hear a fast pitch vibrato. Its frequency is depending on the note played.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Pitch</em> (Oscillator B) until <em>Key Trk</em> is highlighted in the display.</li>
            <li>Turn the <em>Encoder</em> and dial in <em>[0.00 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">The Key Tracking of Oscillator B is set to Off now which results in a constant pitch (and vibrato speed) across the entire note range. <br />Now Oscillator B is behaving like an (almost) ordinary LFO and can be used as a source for periodic modulation in the sub-audio range. Please note that, in contrast to most other (analog) synthesizers with a dedicated LFO, the C15 sports an oscillator/LFO per voice. They are not phase-synced which helps to animate many sounds in a natural way.</li>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="recap">
            <p>Recap: Oscillator section</li>
            <p>The C15’s combination of two oscillators and two shapers, controlled by two 
            envelopes, allows the generation of many different kinds of waveshapes from simple to complex:</li>
            <ul class="nontutorial">
                <li>Initially, both Oscillators produce sine-waves (without any overtones)</li>
                <li>With Self PM active, each Oscillator generates a variable sawtooth wave (with all overtones)</li>
                <li>When routed through the Shaper, depending on the settings of Drive and Fold, various rectangle and pulse-like waveforms can be generated (with odd- numbered overtones).</li>
                <li>The Shaper’s Asym(metry) parameter adds even harmonics.<br />
                &#xE172;&ensp;Interaction of the parameters mentioned above produces a wide timbral scope and dramatic timbral shifts.</li>
                <li>Mixing both Oscillator/Shaper outputs in the Output Mixer produces sounds with two sonic components, as well as intervals and out-of-tune effects.</li>
                <li>Phase Modulation (PM A / PM B) of one Oscillator by the other as well as cross-modulation can produce inharmonic sounds. The pitch ratios of the Oscillators and the modulation settings mainly determine the timbral results.<br />
                &#xE172;&ensp;Careful adjustment of pitch, Key Tracking and mod depth settings is important for timbre as well as for making pitched sounds playable! Use Fine resolution to adjust the crucial parameters.</li>
                <li>Introduction of Envelope A and B produces dynamic control over level and timbre.</li>
                <li>Oscillators can be used as LFOs when key tracking is disabled.</li>
            </ul>
        </div>
    </section>

</div><!-- Ende Tutorial (Listen) -->
</main>
</div>
</body>
</html>

<div class="main-grid" id="menu-wrapper">
    <label id="menu-location" class="label reverse">
        <a href="./index.html">C15 Documentation</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/tut-sound-generation/index.html">Sound Generation Tutorial</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/tut-sound-generation/04-state-variable-filter.html" data-number="4">The State Variable Filter</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
<div class="tutorial">

    <section>
        <h2 data-number="4">The State Variable Filter</h2>
        <p>To introduce the State Variable Filter (S.V. Filter), we should first set up the oscillator section to produce a sawtooth waveform which is rich in overtones. This is a good input signal fodder to explore the State Variable Filter.<br />First, please load the Init sound – this time, you do not need to crank up <q>A</q> on the Output Mixer!</p>
        <ul>
            <li>Set Oscillator A’s PM Self to 90 % for a nice sounding saw-wave.</li>
            <li>Set Envelope A’s Sustain to 60 % in order to produce a steady tone.</li>
        </ul>
        <p>Now please proceed like this:</p>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Enabling the S.V. Filter:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>S.V. Filter</em> (Output Mixer).</li>
            <li>Set the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[50.0 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">The <q>S.V. Filter</q> input of the Output Mixer is fully open now and you can hear the signal passing the filter. Since input <q>A</q> is closed, all you are hearing is the plain S.V. Filter signal.</li>
            <li>Press <em>A – B</em> (State Variable Filter).</li>
            <li class="indent-b">This parameter determines the ratio between the Oscillator/Shaper signals A and B, fed into the S.V. Filter input. For now, keep it at its default setting <q>A</q>, i. e. <em>[0.0 %]</em>.</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">The very basic Parameters:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Cutoff</em> (State Variable Filter).</p>
            <li class="indent-b">S.V. Filter (Output Mixer) is flashing to let you know that the S.V. Filter is part of the signal path.</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> across the entire value range and dial in the default value <em>[80.0 st]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">You will hear the characteristic transition from bright to dull since overtones are gradually being eliminated from the signal.<br />&#xE172;&ensp;At very low settings, when the cutoff setting is below the frequency of the fundamental note, the output signal might become inaudible.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Reson</em> (State Variable Filter).</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> across the entire value range and dial in the default value <em>[50.0 st]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">When increasing resonance values, you will hear frequencies around the cutoff setting becoming increasingly edgier and more pronounced. Cutoff and resonance are the most effective filter parameters.</p>
        </ul>
        <div data-highlight="excursion">
            <h3>Excursion – Controlling the current Parameter using Ribbon 1</h3>
            <p>Sometimes, it can be more useful (or funnier) to control a parameter using a ribbon controller rather than an encoder. This is useful when performing with the parameter as well as adjusting values very accurately.<br />To assign a Ribbon to a specific parameter (here the Cutoff of the S.V. Filter), simply:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>Press <em>Cutoff</em> (State Variable Filter).</li>
                <li>Press <em>Mode</em> (Base Unit Control Panel) until the Base Unit Display shows <em><i>Cutoff</i></em>. This mode is also called Edit Mode.</li>
                <li>Slide your finger across <em>RIBBON 1</em>.</li>
                <li class="indent-b">The parameter currently selected (Cutoff) is now controlled by <em>RIBBON 1</em>, or your finger tip</li>
            </ul>
            <div data-columns="2">
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Base Unit Control Panel 1">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="images/tutorials/sound-generation/soled-a.png"></picture>
                </figure>
                <figure class="border maximize" data-label="Base Unit Control Panel 2">
                    <picture class="content" data-src="images/tutorials/sound-generation/soled-b.png"></picture>
                </figure>
            </div>
            <p>&#xE172;&ensp;When using the C15’s Macro Controls, the Ribbons / Pedals can control various parameters at the same time. This very interesting topic will be covered in a later tutorial. Stay tuned.</p>
        </div>
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Exploring some of the more advanced S.V. Filter parameters:</h3>
        <p>&#xE172;&ensp;Our word of advice: No matter whether you are familiar with filters in general or not, please grab the user manual and take some time to study all those flashy S.V. Filter parameters in detail.</p>
        <div data-highlight="excursion">
            <h3>Excursion: The S.V. Filter functionality</h3>
            <p>The S.V. Filter is a combination of two resonating two-pole state-variable filters, each with a slope of 12 dB. Cutoff and Resonance can be controlled manually or modulated by Envelope C and Key Tracking.</p>
            <figure class="border maximize" data-label="S.V. Filter Signal Flow">
                <picture class="content" data-src="images/diagrams/svf-*.png"></picture>
            </figure>
            <p>The spacing between both cutoff-points is variable (<q>Spread</q>). The filter characteristics can be swept continuously from low through band to high-pass mode (<q>L–B–H</q>). Both filters work in series by default but can be continuously shifted to parallel operation (<q>Parallel</q>).</p>
            <ul class="nontutorial">
                <li>Setting Spread to 0.0 st creates a simple four-pole filter. At higher Spread values, the spacing between the two Cutoff frequencies increases.</li>
                <li>Cutoff and Resonance always affect both filter sections in the same manner.</li>
                <li>L–B–H determines the characteristics of both filter sections:</li>
                <li>L – both filter sections work in lowpass mode. High frequencies are attenuated, producing a sound that can be described as <q>round</q>, <q>soft</q>, <q>fat</q>, <q>dull</q> etc.</li>
                <li>H – both filter sections work in highpass mode. Low frequencies are attenuated, producing a sound that can be described as <q>sharp</q>, <q>thin</q>, <q>bright</q> etc.</li>
                <li>B – the first filter section works as a highpass, the second as a lowpass. Low and high frequencies are both attenuated and a frequency band with variable width (<q>Spread</q>) passes the S.V. Filter. Particularly at higher Resonance settings, vowel/vocal-like sounds can be achieved.</li>
                <li>FM provides a Cutoff modulation by the Oscillator/Shaper signals A and B. Very good for aggressive and distorted sounds.</li>
            </ul>
        <p>Check out the parameters mentioned above and keep in mind that they all interact with each other in some way. Use the Default button to reset a parameter value.</p>
        </div>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Envelope / Key Tracking modulation of Cutoff and Resonance:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Cutoff</em> (State Variable Filter) until <em><i>Env C</i></em> is highlighted in the display.</li>
            <li>Set the <em>Encoder</em> to <em>[70.00 st]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">You will hear the sound becoming increasingly dull over time since the Cutoff is modulated by Envelope C.<br />Vary the settings of Envelope C parameters and the modulation depth (<q>Env C</q>). For more dramatic filter <q>sweeps</q> set the Resonance of the S.V. Filter to higher values.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Cutoff</em> (State Variable Filter) until <em><i>Key Trk</i></em> is highlighted in the display.</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> across the entire range and dial in <em>[50.0 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">When set to 0.0 %, Cutoff has the same value across the entire keyboard range. When reducing the Key Tracking value, the Cutoff value will increase in higher keyboard ranges and the sound grows brighter – an effect you can find with many acoustic instruments.<br />Please check Env C / Key Trk modulation of the Resonance as well.</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Changing the Filter Characteristics:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li class="indent-b">The S.V. Filter is a four-pole filter composed of two two-pole filters. The Spread parameter determines the interval between the two cutoff frequencies of these two parts.</li>
            <li>Set the <em>Resonance</em> to <em>[80 %]</em>.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Spread</em> (State Variable Filter).</li>
            <li>By default, Spread is set to 12 semitones. Try settings between 0 and 60 semitones and also vary the Cutoff.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">When reducing the Spread value, the two peaks will emphasize each other and the result will be a very intensely resonating, <q>peaking</q> sound.</li>
            <li>Press <em>Spread</em> (State Variable Filter) again until <em><i>L–B–H</i></em> is highlighted in the display.</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> across the entire value range and dial in the default value <em>[0.0 %]</em> (Lowpass).</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Using the L–B–H parameter, you can morph continuously from lowpass through bandpass to highpass. 0.0 % is fully lowpass, 100.0 % fully highpass. The width of the bandpass is determined by the Spread parameter.</li>
        </ul>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Cutoff FM:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>FM</em> (State Variable Filter).</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> across the entire range.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now the filter input signal is modulating the Cutoff frequency. Usually, the sound gets increasingly nasty and abrasive. Please note that positive and negative FM can produce quite different results.</li>
            <li>Press <em>FM</em> (State Variable Filter) until A – B is highlighted in the display.</li>
            <li class="indent-b"><em>A – B</em> blends between the Oscillator/Shaper signals A and B and determines the signal ratio which is modulating the Filter Cutoff. Depending on the waveshape and pitch of both Oscillator/Shaper signals, the results can differ considerably from each other.</li>
            <li>Reset <em>FM</em> and <em>A – B</em> to their default values.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>
    
</div><!-- Ende Tutorial (Listen) -->

        <a href="./documents/tut-sound-generation/index.html">Sound Generation Tutorial</a>
        <span>/</span>
        <a href="./documents/tut-sound-generation/05-output-mixer.html" data-number="5">The Output Mixer</a>
    </label>
</div>
<!-- document content -->
<div id="content-wrapper">
<main>
<div class="tutorial">

    <section>
        <h2 data-number="5">The Output Mixer</h2>
        <p>You have already laid your hands on the Output Mixer. Here you will find some more info on that module.<br />If you are only popping in at this point, we should first set the oscillator section to produce a sawtooth waveform:</li>
        <ul>
            <li>First, please load the Init sound – do not forget to crank up <q>A</q> on the Output Mixer!</li>
            <li>Set Oscillator A’s <em>PM Self</em> to <em>[90 %|</em> for a nice-sounding sawtooth-wave.</li>
            <li>Set Envelope A’s <em>Sustain</em> to <em>[60 %|</em> in order to produce a steady tone.</li>
        </ul>
        <p>Now carry on, please:</li>
        
        <h3 class="heading secondary">Using the Output Mixer:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>S.V. Filter</em> (Output Mixer).</li>
            <li>Set the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[50.0 %]</em>.</li>
            <li>Press <em>A</em> (Output Mixer).</li>
            <li>Set the <em>Encoder</em> to approx. <em>[50.0 %]</em>.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">You have just combined the output signal of the S.V. Filter with the direct (unfiltered) signal of Oscillator A.</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> across the entire value range and back to [50.0 %].</li>
        </ul>

            <p>Positive Level values add signals. Negative Level values subtract the signal from the others.<br />&#xE172;&ensp;Because of phase cancellation, positive and negative values may produce different timbral results here and there. It is worth trying out both polarities of the Levels.<br />&#xE172;&ensp;Please note that high input levels can produce audible saturation effects that make the sound edgier and/or more aggressive. To avoid unwanted distortion in the subsequent stages (e.g. effect section), please compensate for the gain boost by reducing the output level of the mixer by using Level (Output Mixer).</p>
    
        <h3 class="heading secondary">The Drive Parameter:</h3>
        <ul>
            <li>Press <em>Drive</em> (Output Mixer).</li>
            <li>Sweep the <em>Encoder</em> across the entire value range.</li>
            <li class="indent-b">Now the output signal of the mixer is passing through a flexible distortion circuit that produces everything from mild fuzzy distortion up to wildest sound mangling.<br />Check out the Drive parameters <em><i>Fold</i></em> and <em><i>Asymmetry</i></em> as well. To avoid unwanted distortion in the subsequent stages (e.g. effect section), please compensate for the gain boost by reducing the output level of the mixer by using <em>Level</em> (Output Mixer).</li>
            <li>Reset all <em>Drive</em> parameters to their default values.</li>
        </ul>
    </section>
    
</div><!-- Ende Tutorial (Listen) -->
</main>
